text:
Qaws al-Nur (1)
Praise be to Allah, the Bestower of blessings and their Sustainer, and peace and blessings upon the Guide of creation and their Intercessor. To proceed:
The books of Abu Hafs al-Sayrafi were until a few years ago considered non-existent. No one knew of them, nor sought guidance to them in any way, nor did anyone rise to search for them, thinking they were rarer than the eggs of the Anuq (a mythical bird) or the ablq 'aqq (a mythical piebald horse), and then due to the overwhelming despair of finding them, given the long time that has passed between us and the last possessors of them or those who referred to them... However, a measure of abundant grace kept a solitary copy of the book of Al-Ilal (Defects) for a long period of time sitting in the library of Ibn Yusuf in Marrakesh under number 684. Individual scholars and the general public would pass by it morning and evening. They never paid attention to it, nor gave it its due care. The lack of a title on the collection diverted them from examining it and gaining insight into it. It is the nature of people to be reluctant to endure difficult paths and to be fond of the easy route, especially that whose veil has been lifted and whose brilliance has appeared; because it relieves them from the distress of choice and its difficulties - and not everyone is praised for their exploration. So you see them rushing for that reason to work on a single book, one of them uncovering it like moths rushing to a flame. If they had the capacity to search for this abundant, rare, hidden material that was unknown, this scrambling would not have occurred, nor would they have disputed the book with its owner who was exhausted from searching for it and was the first to present it, nor would they have intended to steal it or almost did so... And in that lies a waste of effort and time by converging on a work where gathering is not required, and an indication of thinness in religion and boldness in fabrication, which does not suit this noble and lofty science.

text:
This book is not one whose value is hidden, as it is evident in several matters:
- It is the third book on Al-Ilal (Defects) - after the books of Ali bin al-Madini (d. 234 AH) and Imam Ahmad (d. 241 AH) (1) - to be found and unveiled for the first time, after remaining in the realm of the lost for many centuries. Its Andalusian transmission chain (Isnad) and Moroccan manuscript and origin make it the only one in the world, as far as I reckon.
- It is one of the most precious critical artifacts of the school of Imam Al-Bukhari's sheikhs, in the first half of the third century; as it contains the most famous critical opinions of the two great Sheikhs of Basra, Yahya bin Sa'id al-Qattan and Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi. It is thus considered the most extensive single compilation gathering their statements (2).
- It retains a detailed, indicative, and rare title: "A Book Containing the Defects of Hadith and the Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak, as Agreed Upon by the Scholars of Basra"; in addition to the issues it raises regarding the methodology of classification; such as its singling out the distinction between trustworthy and weak narrators specific to a certain region like Basra.
- It is a model that reveals the early signs of establishing the historical method among the Hadith scholars in Basra, and the climate of issues that were prevalent there.
- It contains many texts and athar (narrations) unique to it, not found elsewhere; thus, they are among its exclusive contents.
- Comparing its texts with what was transmitted from it resulted in correcting many attribution errors and adjusting some critical judgments.
One of the most difficult things we encountered in this part was that the author wrote it specifically for a particular recipient at a particular time, presupposing a set of technical and methodological competencies, and a degree of knowledge of texts, issues, and technical assimilation. This led him to fold...

text: ...the contexts of texts and be concise in mentioning the Mutun (texts of hadith), sometimes shortening them and sometimes sufficing with a part of some without completion, especially in what he narrates as accounts of the critics' gatherings. As you know, these are sources of issues circulating among the people of the craft, containing abbreviation, referral, implication, limiting to the Kunyas (nicknames) and mere names of narrators, abridging texts and hinting at them with the heads of issues, sending terminology that had not yet become doubtful, establishing critical judgments with phrases folded away from circulation, and citing the Isnad (chain of narration) stripped of its Matn (text) relying on its fame at the time, while it is not famous today. If a confusing misspelling or a hidden omission is added to the above, understanding the intent becomes even harder to reach and rarer to grasp. For example, he narrated from his Sheikh Al-Qattan that he used to say regarding the pledge (Rahn): If it is worth more than its value, it is for what it is worth, and if it is less, the surplus is returned to him (1). In this issue, there is obscurity caused by brevity necessitated by the fame of the issue at the time; its detail is: "Regarding the pledge: it perishes in the hands of the pledgee; if its value and the debt are equal, it is lost against the debt, and if its value is less than the debt, it is returned to him" (2). This is not something grasped intuitively. Among the difficulties of verifying this book is also the hesitation in considering what constitutes a single sentence or multiple sentences from the author's speech; for some paragraphs contain a critical judgment on a narrator deserving to be singled out with a special number, and sometimes some relate to a question or issue concerning multiple examples. Is it permissible to single them out because each is a specific issue, or is it permissible to combine them due to the semantic thread that organizes them? One of the results of examining the correction of the book was that one of the aids in understanding the context of the reported news, especially in criticism, is seeking it from various sources, not just one. For the story narrated - for example - from Yahya al-Qattan, you might find it narrated attributed to Ibn...

text: ...Al-Madini or Abu Musa al-Zaman or Al-Fallas or Bundar... And it is necessary that one of the predecessors be more comprehensive and explicit in mentioning what unveils the ambiguity of the meaning than others. One of the sources of the report might add a necessary addition without which the meaning would not be clear. So comparing their speech with one another is an investigation to understand the climate of the text in which it was produced. The prevailing opinion - based on induction and repeated examination - is that if the heritage of many of Al-Fallas's contemporaries, like those we mentioned, had reached us, we would have found that one of them alone carries the bulk of their narration and transmits, following their example, what they transmit, so nothing remains for each of them to be unique in except a little thing (1). We reached this conclusion after pausing often at news and texts in Abu Hafs's book that were only illuminated by the narrations of his peers and contemporaries in Iraq specifically. This is what we might call the common amount in narration usually produced by the unity of Sheikhs, time, and place. Therefore, the meaning produced by projecting a text onto another text on its subject - provided the conditions of reliability are met for both - is more correct and precise than the meaning produced by reading an isolated text, no matter how armed the reading is with sound mechanisms. One of the benefits of the book of Al-Ilal is that it determines where the author's speech ends, to distinguish it from the speech of those who transmitted from him; because some of the critical texts that originally return to him, parts of them are usually attributed to their transmitters, especially if the transmission is long, so it is thought at first glance that only its beginning belongs to Al-Fallas without the rest; as in the report related to the mursal (disconnected) narration of Ibn Jurayj (2). It is known that correcting the text without commenting on it is an elegant escape from responsibility, but it is...

text: ...a missed opportunity for two great matters: practicing understanding the issues of the texts, and revealing them to students. So whatever commentary I made on the texts of the book is from this category. It is axiomatic that correctness may be my ally occasionally and oppose me more often, and in both cases, I resort to a sound intention and a high aim, God willing. perhaps a reader perusing this work might whisper to himself: How excessive this investigator has been upon himself, and how much he has obligated himself unnecessarily, and these papers are barely fit to become a volume. To this type and others, I say: Suffering through the texts of early critics is not that easy. A word might strike the illusion of a hasty reader as deviating from correctness, and consequently, he suggests returning it - arbitrarily - according to his claim to the modern usage, which is the face his view has settled on and his knowledge has reached. Thus, he corrupts the original without restraint. His ignorance of what that word meant at the time it was said, due to its gradual withdrawal from circulation over time, is what led him to this. If he had lingered for a while and consulted the class of works corresponding in art and history, they might have illuminated his path and corrected his stumble. He errs who thinks that these texts brought by the author are compliant in revealing what is in them. They require profound knowledge of the sum of issues that were current in the arena of Hadith, the Mutun (texts) that were circulating, and a sharp perception of the specific circumstances and contexts that govern a particular critical issuance. What I have described is what made me fear most that I might underestimate opposing the texts of the book with what is transmitted from them, even if by a later scholar, thus missing a hidden correctness or an alert from an intelligent person. For the investigator, no matter how high his ranks in the craft, does not pay attention to all the dilemmas of the copy except with a notification from abundant guiding copies. If they are lacking, quotations from the original - if found - take their place, although this is one of the necessities committed, due to the varieties of alteration that usually befall the transmitted material. As for our method in Takhrij (referencing), it is pointing to the face mentioned by the author...

text: ...for the Hadith and not others, bringing its corroborations, mentioning bits of difference in its wording or additions to it, and trying to approximate the judgment on it - not judging it, as we are not capable of that - without citing oppositions or supports, nor caring to mention other faces; because that is outside our condition, and because it leads - even with its application - to mixing the authentic with the weak, necessarily because the author's path to the Hadith may be authentic or weak, and there may be another path or paths whose judgment varies accordingly, and we cannot deal with them. Whatever is in the transmitted sources from the author's path, I do not include in the Takhrij at all, but rather refer to it to correct the text and document it. I was active - at first thought - in collecting the critics' statements on the narrators disagreed upon mentioned in this part, and I covered a not short distance in that, especially when the names of these interspersed the issues of history and defects at the beginning and middle of the book. But when the majority of the issues at the end of the book became specialized in talking about them, and it appeared that the footnotes were dominating Al-Fallas's text and strangling it, and the commentary became undutiful to its origin, I desisted from my initial course. I limited myself to referring for each narrator to two books that gathered and contained everything, namely Tahdhib al-Hafiz al-Mizzi and its Ikmal by Al-Hafiz Mughlatay. In them are gathered transmissions and rare imports that are not hidden from scholars. It was decided by me not to annotate the text with the transmission of critical judgments except for a group of critics united by a specific time frame, which is the time of Al-Fallas or shortly after him. So these transmissions do not go beyond the layer of his Sheikhs, peers, and students, either originally from their books or through other trusted intermediaries even if they are late. Necessarily, seeking familiarity with these judgments, whether confirming what we have or differing from it, is more beneficial in discerning the scientific atmosphere and the climate of issues than the judgments of later scholars, which are nothing more than a probed reading of the total judgments they encountered. Their ijtihad framed by the rules of the art led them to a choice or preference that usually became binding only in the absence of foundational books or their loss or lack of trust in the transmitter from them. text: ...what resembles it if found - it is from the foundational period, so it is absolutely incorrect to judge what is in it except by what corresponds and resembles it at the level of structure and significance. We were called to this methodological limitation - although we did not succeed in applying it consistently due to its extreme difficulty - by the attempt to foresee the thinking patterns of the third-century Hadith scholars, and to smell the issues that contributed to building their judgments, whether doctrinal, ideological (1), or technical. This is not, God forbid, a burying of the serious scientific accumulation of later scholars nor neglecting it, but rather an intent to become saturated with the spirit of these texts on the day they were produced, by "temporarily" (2) detaching from the authority of later readings. For applying the judgments of "Al-Taqrib", for example, arbitrarily on the narrators of this part, completely removes the desired benefit from it; because we thereby waste the opportunity for utilization and scientific independence in knowing the principles, rationale, and evidence for adopting such judgments by a great critical scholar like Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him. Such practice is what made the critical aspect in the science of Hadith wither as much as possible. If we hoped for the book to guide us to the paths of those early ones, let your thoughts not go elsewhere. I declare my innocence to Allah, may His power be exalted and His name be high, from intentionally disparaging an Imam of Hadith or one affiliated with it, except what the pen swerved to without my intent. For speaking against the bearers of the Sharia of the Messenger of Allah is severe, and its consequence is dire. And if we have any status - and I do not think so - it is by the honor of our affiliation to them and our declaration of their virtue. "We seek refuge in Allah from deficiency after increase." This said, whoever engages in Hadith today meets difficulties, due to the lack of his group, the loss of discussion in it, the weakness of benefit in engaging with it, and the delay in sparking understanding for the one involved in it except after a long time, due to its reliance on deferred [reward/result], so it does not produce immediately. 2 - His maternal grandfather, Bahr bin Kunayz al-Saqqa:
This grandfather of his was a friend of Amr bin Ubaid. There is no doubt that the line uniting them was what they both emulated from the path of righteousness and seeking integrity, even if they were together peers in weakness and abandonment (1) - each according to his [degree]!.. Since it was not transmitted to us that he was stigmatized with any of the beliefs of the Mu'tazila (Adliyyin), perhaps he accompanied Amr before the doctrine took hold in him, or before he raised his head with it. He also had a connection with Al-Mansur before he assumed the Caliphate, either independently or through Ibn Ubaid, as indicated by a report cited by Al-Baladhuri from Al-Tawzi, from Abu Zaid; he said: "Al-Mansur came to Basra before the Caliphate, so Amr bin Ubaid said to Bahr bin Kanz (2) al-Saqqa: This man has arrived, and he was a frequent visitor when he came to our city, so let us go to him. So they came to him; when they stood at his door, Amr called out: O girl. A girl answered him, so he said: Tell Abu Ja'far: Abu al-Fadl and Abu Uthman. So he gave them permission, and they entered upon him. Behold, he was on a worn-out perfumed prayer rug, and before him was a tray with a bowl containing broth with no meat in it. He said: O girl, do you have anything to increase us with? She said: No. He said: Do you have a dirham to buy fruit for Abu Uthman? She said: No. He said: Take it away; {They said, 'We have been harmed before you came to us and after you have come to us.' He said, 'Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and grant you succession in the land and see how you will do.'} [Al-A'raf: 129] (3). ...Akhbar Asbahan by Abu Nu'aym (1), and it does not contain "my grandfather". His student Al-Nasa'i narrated it from Al-Fallas in Al-Sunan al-Sughra (2) and Al-Kubra (3), stripped of the addition in both places. This Abu Sufyan Salih bin Mihran is a Shaybani from Isfahan, a freedman of Zakariya bin Masqalah bin Hubayrah al-Shaybani, then he is of Khurasani origin, and was called: Al-Hakim (4). If the authenticity of the preceding addition is established - and there is some doubt about it - it would result in Al-Fallas's grandfather being a client from Isfahan, who came (or his son Ali came) to Basra and settled there, and this one proposed to Bahr bin Kathir for his daughter, so she gave birth to Amr... (5). Between Al-Fallas's grandfathers on the father's and mother's side are common denominators not hidden from one who examines their biographies (6), except that Al-Fallas declared the first trustworthy and weakened the second. Perhaps in the suspicion of Al-Fallas's knowledge of Persian, there is something to support correcting the addition, for this knowledge would be easy if he were of Khurasani origin since that is the language of the land. We only based this suspicion on a single misspelled report cited by Ibn Abi Hatim in the entry of Umar bin Riyah Abu Hafs al-Darir; he said: I heard my father say: Abu Hafs al-Sayrafi said: "Hawrad"" (7). I said: Perhaps he meant "Huwa: Rad" (He is: Rad), and "Rad" is a Persian word meaning: Rejected. But this possibility is somewhat strained.
4 - His relationship with Yahya al-Qattan and his reverence for him:
Al-Fallas's intense adherence to Yahya appeared in various matters, including seeking his approval for what he transmitted from him in his books over what he transmitted from others; and his narration from him of some of his usual phrases and answers outside the path of the art (of Hadith), related to his person only. He liked to praise him; he mentioned in his book that he narrated a hadith to him and he approved of it (1), and informed him of another and he approved of it as well and asked him to repeat it more than once (2). He was persistent in his questioning, yet he would not get annoyed with him but would oblige him, as in his saying: "I asked Yahya about the hadith of Thawr, from Hariz, from Abu Khidash. He said to me: Mu'adh heard it from Hariz, so ask him about it. But I did not leave him until he narrated it to me" (3). He never ceased to be concerned with transmitting Yahya's positions on various issues; such as his position on the preference between Ali and Uthman (may Allah be pleased with them); as revealed by this report: "I heard Mu'adh bin Mu'adh say: Shu'bah narrated to us, from Husayn, he said: I said to Abu Wa'il: Is Ali better or Uthman? He said: Ali; until he did what he did. But as for today, it is Uthman. Mu'adh said: So I narrated it to Bishr bin al-Mufaddal, and he said: Uthman was better before and after. So Yahya got angry and said: This one did not know Umar bin al-Khattab, when he made it a consultation (Shura) among six!" (4). In this, there is a denial and refutation by Yahya of this speech using the action of Al-Faruq, may Allah be pleased with him, for if a preference had appeared to him, he would not have resorted to the Shura. So it appeared that Ali and Uthman (may Allah be pleased with them) are to Yahya like two racehorses or like the two knees of a camel; or withholding judgment (Tawaqquf), and this is what is famous about him. Abu Zakariya Yahya bin Ma'in said: "Yahya bin Sa'id said: Sufyan al-Thawri's opinion was: Abu Bakr and Umar, then he would stop (Tawaqquf). Yahya bin Ma'in said: And it is the opinion of Yahya bin Sa'id" (5). As for his politeness with him, it is proverbial; suffice it to say that prominent figures would stand before Yahya for long hours, not daring to sit unless he permitted them. Al-Khatib narrated from Ishaq al-Shahidi his saying: "I used to see Yahya al-Qattan pray Asr and then lean against the base of the minaret of his mosque. Ali bin al-Madini, Al-Shadhakuni, Amr bin Ali, Ahmad bin Hanbal, Yahya bin Ma'in and others would stand before him; asking him about Hadith, and they...

What distinguishes Al-Fallas from those who transmitted Al-Qattan's sayings on narrators and defects, is that he narrated from him many of his jurisprudential choices and fatwas and was unique in transmitting them. He mentioned that he used to raise his hands in every lowering and raising (in prayer). And that his knees would touch the ground before his hands (3). And that he would not perform ablution from what fire had changed (cooked) (4). And that he disliked all Nabidh (fermented drinks) (5). And he used to say regarding the pledge (Rahn): If it is worth more than its value, it is for what it is worth, and if it is less, the surplus is returned to him (6). And he was asked about fish eating excrement, and he saw no harm in it (7). And Al-Fallas asked him about a man who left out a prostration from a rak'ah, then remembered it while he was in the second. He said: He prostrates it when he remembers it, and he owes two prostrations for forgetfulness (8). And he also asked him about a woman with two children in her womb, and she delivered one of them. He said: She (9) is in postpartum bleeding (Nifas). And he transmitted from Yahya his resentment of the Imamate of the Qadariyyah, and labeling them as performing prayer badly (10), and similar instances recurred for him, such as his saying: "Yahya saw me once while I was coming from the direction of the mountain after we had prayed Fajr. He said: Where did you come from here? I said: I did not catch the prayer with them, so I prayed in this mosque. He said: Do not pray in it; for their Imam is a Mu'tazili (11)."

6 - His stance on Abu Hanifa:
Abu Hanifa was one of the pillars of Opinion (Ra'y) and proponents of Irja', and the Hadith scholars considered him weak in Hadith. Thus, he received considerable criticism from them for this reason. Others, claiming jurisprudential bias, went beyond criticism to demolition. Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Mu'allimi al-Yamani, may Allah have mercy on him, undertook the refutation of these aimed arrows on the path of fairness in his comprehensive book "Al-Tankil" in the most creative and extensive manner possible, establishing valid criticisms and rebuttals that cannot be repelled, and contextualizing much of it. Al-Fallas was among the group who directed this scorching criticism, but it was not an individual stance; rather, it reflects the viewpoint of the entire Basran school, as it has many parallels. Here is the context of his words, stripped of commentary except for a small slice: Amr said (3): "And Abu Hanifa the proponent of Opinion, his name is Al-Nu'man bin Thabit, is not a Hafiz (memorizer), confused in Hadith, flimsy in Hadith." And he added in Tarikh Baghdad (4): "And a proponent of desire (innovation)." And he said (5): "Abu Ghadir al-Filastini narrated to me, a man informed me that he saw the Prophet, peace be upon him...

Look at his precision as he remembered the hadith recalling how he received it from his sheikh by dictation. And also from him; his saying: 'I heard a trustworthy man from our companions say: I heard Yahya bin Sa'id say in his prostration: "O Allah, forgive Khalid bin al-Harith and Mu'adh bin Mu'adh." So I mentioned it to Yahya, and he did not deny it.' In this, Al-Fallas was not content with the narration of the trustworthy person from Yahya until he heard it from him directly, even though he could have dropped the intermediary, yet he did not do so, which indicates his investigation. Indeed, this deep scrutiny in controlling the origins of narration appears in some of his stories in this part; like his saying: I heard a man asking Yahya about the hadith of Abdullah bin al-Sa'ib, from Zadhan regarding trustworthiness. Yahya said to him: It is from Sufyan and Al-A'mash; so which of them do you want? He said: The hadith of Al-A'mash. He said: You want the name! I heard Sufyan say: I went with Al-A'mash to Abdullah bin al-Sa'ib until he heard it.' His story showed that Sufyan preceded Al-A'mash in receiving the hadith of Abdullah bin al-Sa'ib, and he was the one who guided Al-A'mash to it. This precision, investigation, and perception is what he expressed as 'insight into hadith' in his critical judgment on Abu Hudhayfah Musa bin Mas'ud when he said about him: 'No one who has insight into hadith narrates from him.' 9 - Description of the last dictation session held by Al-Fallas one day before his death: From the manuscript 'Al-Fawa'id al-Muntakhabah wa al-Hikayat al-Mustaghrabah' by Hafiz Ibn Bashkuwal (d. 578 AH); he said:

text: Glimpses of the Book and its Methodology 1 - Is this the Book of Weak Narrators (Kitab al-Du'afa)? One of the cautions of mentioning 'weak narrators' in the title of this book of ours is that one who contents himself with it without the rest of the author's books might imagine it to be the one frequently mentioned in the folds of books on narrators under the name 'Al-Du'afa' or 'Tad'if al-Rijal' (Weakening of Men), which is also implied by the phrase of Ibn Khalfoun al-Awnabi: 'And he has a book on the weak narrators of Basra.' However, the distinction between the books of 'Al-'Ilal' and 'Al-Du'afa' is established. The least that suffices to prove it is that Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi possessed both books and arrived with them in Damascus, naming them without combining them; rather, he mentioned the second one later than the first with two titles. Perhaps the Book of Weak Narrators is more comprehensive than our book, which Al-Fallas restricted to the trustworthy and weak narrators of Basra, in addition to mentioning issues of defects ('Ilal); so it is not purely for weak narrators, evidenced by the fact that much of Al-Sayrafi's speech on weak narrators is not contained in the part before you. Furthermore, the sayings of Al-Fallas transmitted from him outside the books of History and 'Ilal are more indicative of his personality in Jarh and Ta'dil (disparaging and declaring trustworthy), and they are lengthier and broader in their apparent freedom from mere transmission and his boldness in criticism, unlike what is in the Book of 'Ilal, where he adhered strictly to narrating from his sheikhs only, adhering to his condition which he elaborated in the long title of the book, which is referring to the sayings of the sheikhs of Basra. text: Impact of the Two Sheikhs on the Book 1 - The narration formula in Al-'Ilal regarding the two Sheikhs narrating or abandoning and its value among critics: Books of Rijal are filled with transmitting the judgments of the two greatest sheikhs of Basra regarding narrators, and Al-Fallas and others meant by their narrating from a narrator or abandoning him: Using him as proof or lack thereof. This became established in critical convention among the ancients and moderns alike, rather their narrating from an unknown person lifts the obscurity from him and validates him, for Ahmad was asked: 'If Yahya or Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrates from an unknown man, is his hadith used as proof? He said: It is used as proof.' They did not differ about them when they both narrated from a narrator or abandoned him, but they differed if one narrated and the other abandoned; Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Abi Bakr al-Muqaddami quoted Ali Ibn al-Madini saying: 'If Yahya bin Sa'id and Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi agree on abandoning a man, I do not narrate from him, and if they differ, I take the saying of Abd al-Rahman; because he is the more moderate of the two, and there was strictness in Yahya.' Al-Dhahabi said about them: 'They undertook the criticism of men, and suffice you with them in majesty, nobility, knowledge, and virtue. So whomever they disparage, by Allah, his wound hardly heals, and whomever they deem trustworthy is the accepted proof, and whomever they differ upon, effort is exerted in his matter, and he descends from the degree of Sahih to Hasan, and they have deemed trustworthy...

text: ...many people, and weakened others.' No wonder the critics distinguish the two peers with this methodological characteristic; for in addition to their refraining from narrating from weak narrators, they used to track their narrations in the books of their students and mark them as errors; as Bundar recounted, he said: 'Yahya and Abd al-Rahman took the pen from my hand, and crossed out about forty hadiths from the hadith of Al-Harith from Ali.' The matter reaches with the two Sheikhs to the point that they would complain against whoever did not cease narrating from those perished ones whom they both agreed to abandon, recounted by Abu Dawud who said: 'Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi complained against Isa bin Maymun, the companion of Muhammad bin Ka'b, regarding these hadiths, so he said: I will not return [to it].' This practice of the formula of negating the narration of the two Sheikhs or affirming it became a trodden path in the layer of the author and the layer of his students, and from them those after them picked it up, so you find it with Imam Ahmad and the philosopher of the craft Ibn al-Madini - and he dedicated a separate work to this in five parts which did not reach us - and Muhammad bin al-Muthanna al-Anazi - and I think...

text: And Al-Fallas's argument of not hearing the narration of the two Sheikhs from a narrator despite the availability of motives, is an indication for him in weakening him; as is known regarding: Burayd bin Abdullah bin Abi Burdah, Isma'il bin Rafi', Jamil bin Zayd al-Ta'i, Abu Bakr al-Hudhali, Hurayth bin Abi Matar, Salim al-Khayyat, Ya'qub bin Ata' bin Abi Rabah, Abu Sufyan al-Sa'di, Al-Asbagh bin Nubatah, and Yunus bin Khabbab. However, it is not consistent with our companion to accept everything he recounts about the two Sheikhs, nor do I think he considered the mere narration of one of them - without them both - from a narrator as validation absolutely, evidenced by his saying: 'And Yahya narrated to us, from Bakr bin Khunays' then Amr said following it: 'And he is weak', so if his acceptance of mere narration was decisive he would not have commented, or perhaps he meant that Yahya's narration was discussion (Muzakarah) not transmission (Riwayah). There is no doubt that his saying: 'And people differ about him' - after saying: 'I heard Yahya and Abd al-Rahman, both narrating from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil': does not impugn for him the principle of argumentation with what the two Sheikhs agreed upon, so the addition is merely recounting a situation, and does not result in his adopting a critical judgment contrary to the two Sheikhs. The ideal value remains for what the book 'Al-'Ilal' contained of recounting about the two peers, in its correction of some of what was transmitted from the two Sheikhs - outside Al-'Ilal - incorrectly, resulting in confusion in the critical judgment attributed to them, and also in establishing the truth regarding those narrators who underwent critical monitoring, so they narrated from them at first then...

The editor voweled the Kaf in both cases with Damma (Kull), and it appeared to me at first that it was a misspelling (Tashif), and that it is more worthy that the voweling be with Fatha (Kall), so the meaning would be that so-and-so is weak and only takes from his like; derived from the saying of Allah Almighty: {And he is a burden (Kall) upon his master; wherever he directs him, he brings no good} [Al-Nahl: 76]; but what returned me to the right path is the author's saying afterwards: 'And he praised him', which is an indication diverting from the immediate meaning; not to mention that Ibn Juhada is from the narrators of the group (Jama'ah) and not weak at all. However, despite that, the expression 'Kull la ya'khudh illa 'an kull' remains furthest from the spirit of the Muhaddithin, rather it is closer to the spirit of the theologians (Mutakallimin), in addition to being an unheard expression, as we did not find it with other than Abu Dawud despite extensive searching, and it is likely that what is in the transmissions from the book of Al-Ajurri is better if it were free from confusion; for in 'Tahdhib al-Kamal': 'Kana la ya'khudh illa 'an kull ...', and he did not complete it, and it is in Tahdhib...

text: Tahdhib': 'He would not take from just anyone.' I suspect it underwent alteration in it. Despite all this, the expression remains obscure, needing decoding. Phrases like the one that passed are often problematic, and their inherent indication is not definitive; rather, they require external direction to set their context and define their concept. We do not lack such expressions from Yahya and Abd al-Rahman in the book 'Al-'Ilal'. Among them: Yahya: 'This is from the old (Atiq) hadith of so-and-so': In a predominant context, this phrase may mean the inclusion of the intended hadith in the narrations of the narrator before his confusion (Ikhtilat), and thus the judgment of its acceptance, as in the context of Yahya's saying about a hadith of Ibn Abi Arubah: 'This is from the authentic hadith of Sa'id, and from his old hadith.' However, Yahya's use of the phrase in various situations led to the conclusion that it is not always governed by the aforementioned context. It might be used with no effect on the acceptance of the hadith and trust in its transmitter, or distinguishing between two phases of his life; as is clear in Al-Fallas's saying: 'And I heard Yahya mention Ubaydah bin Mu'attab, so he narrated from him the hadith of Abu Ayyub, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "Whoever prays four before Zuhr..." Then he saw me writing it, so he said: "Do not write it; indeed, it was from his old hadith".' Ibn Ma'in alluded to the same meaning we mentioned; in the book 'Al-Du'afa'' by Abu al-Qasim al-Balkhi, Abu Bakr said: 'I asked Ibn Ma'in about Ubaydah, the companion of Ibrahim? He said: Weak, he is nothing. I said: What about whoever heard from him long ago? He said: He is nothing, recently or long ago.' Yahya: 'So-and-so was not on the coin (Sikkah)': This phrase is unique to Yahya and not transmitted from anyone else. Al-Fallas said:

text: 'And I asked Abd al-Rahman about a hadith from the hadith of Al-Hasan bin Salih, but he refused to narrate it to me; and he had narrated three hadiths from him then abandoned him. And Yahya bin Sa'id mentioned him and said: "He was not on the coin (Sikkah)".' The meaning of the phrase: The critics tested Al-Hasan bin Salih bin Hayy as a dinar is tested, and he was found counterfeit, or that he departed from the upright, beautiful, satisfactory state to crooked, impassable paths. No wonder Yahya described him as such, for he used to abandon Friday prayer and held the view of the sword (rebellion), we ask Allah for safety. 'Al-'Afw' (Pardon/Ease) according to Yahya: Al-Fallas said: 'And I heard Yahya bin Sa'id say: I used to take the pardon ('Afw) in Hadith.' I say: Perhaps the meaning is: He used to take what the narrator's mind allowed freely without initiating him with a question, insistence, or annoyance; as understood from Yahya's saying: 'I never spoke to Ash'ath, and I only took his pardon (what he gave freely).' The term 'Al-'Afw' may mean the opposite of strictness, and this is realized by comparing it to a question by Ali Ibn al-Madini, for he said: 'I asked Yahya about Muhammad bin Amr bin Alqamah, how is he? He said: Do you want pardon or strictness? I said: Rather, strictness. He said: Then he is not whom you want. He used to say: Our sheikhs are Abu Salamah and Yahya bin Abd al-Rahman bin Hatib. Yahya said: And I asked Malik bin Anas about him, and he said about him similar to what I told you; meaning: Muhammad bin Amr.' It results from what passed that 'Al-'Afw' has two sides: First: Not pressuring the narrator...

Ibn Mahdi: 'So-and-so is among those who increase in goodness': Some reports point to specific issues or terms like the term 'stability of the trustworthy narrator'; meaning: the narrator remaining in a beautiful state, and his safety from what happens to him that corrupts his precision or integrity; as in Al-Fallas's saying: 'And I heard Abd al-Rahman mention Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad, so he said: He was among those who increase in goodness.' This report of Ibn Mahdi indicates the good condition of Abd al-Wahid, and Abu Dawud's saying about him: 'He intended to hadiths that Al-A'mash used to obscure (Yudallis) and connected them,' removes him from that state of Tadlis. Rather, Yahya denies him knowledge of Al-A'mash's hadith entirely, in his saying: 'I never saw Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad seek hadith at all, neither in Basra nor in Kufa. We used to sit at his door on Friday after prayer, and discuss Al-A'mash's hadith, and he did not know a letter of it.' However, this story does not yield Yahya's weakening absolutely, so Mughlatay criticized Ibn al-Jawzi for understanding from it that 'Yahya weakened him.' Yet, Abd al-Wahid's knowledge - even some knowledge - of Al-A'mash's hadith cannot be denied, for Imam Ahmad used his corroboration to correct Masruq's narration from Al-Mughirah. If he were completely devoid of knowledge as Yahya's story implies, Ibn Hanbal would not have considered him in corroboration, and that is evident from his saying: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id when the hadith of Al-A'mash, from Muslim, from Masruq, from Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah was mentioned in his presence. Yahya said: Masruq from Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah?! - twice or thrice - and Yahya denied it most intensely. Abdullah bin Ahmad said: I said to my father: Who corroborated him?

text: He said: More than one; I think among them is Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad...'. Reconciling these stances is possible if we consider a time gap between them. Each of them described the reality of the narrator's matter at his time. So Al-Qattan's words when discussing Al-A'mash's hadith with Abd al-Wahid are interpreted as being at the beginning of his era with narration. Abu Dawud's words about his Tadlis are interpreted when his condition improved in it and he ascended in knowledge and trustworthiness. And Ibn Mahdi's stance is interpreted when he deserved to be 'among those who increase in goodness', thus transforming from the weak to the trustworthy, and in this is an invalidation of Yahya's stance. In the phrase above, there is a clear stipulation of the cause of the critical revision, for he expressed it in the present tense which indicates his increase in goodness and his persistence in it. It cannot be said: This phrase is not a text in the point of dispute; because it is a value judgment unrelated to narration; because we say: It notifies the hypothetical recipient of the transmitter's knowledge of the judgments of preceding critics. Therefore, he did not say 'there is goodness in him', nor 'there was goodness in him', because that involves refraining from explicit declaration, suitable for the continuation of what was as it was - i.e., in weakness - so it does not indicate an elevation in condition. Thus, his choice of the phrase is intentional as produced by the styles of Arabic. It remains that Ibn Mahdi's phrase regarding Ibn Ziyad might be interpreted - contrary to what passed - as referring to righteousness and worship. The term 'Trustworthy' (Thiqah) according to Ibn Mahdi is relative and cannot be generalized: Al-Fallas said: '... I heard Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi ... say: Abu Khaldah narrated to us, from Abu al-Aliyah ...; a man said to him: Was he trustworthy? He said: He was truthful (Saduq), and he was chosen (Khiyar), and he was trustworthy (Ma'mun). The Trustworthy (Thiqah) are: Shu'bah and Sufyan.' Among Ibn Abd al-Barr's criticisms is his saying following it: 'This has no meaning in the choice of words, and interpretation in it is according to desire.' And Al-Baji said: 'He only intended...

text: Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi, may Allah have mercy on him, intended the utmost in leadership (Imamah). If none of the Hadith scholars were deemed trustworthy except those at the level of Shu'bah and Sufyan al-Thawri, the trustworthy ones would be few and most traditions would be nullified.' Thus, it appears that applying such distinctions is relative and not subject to disciplined logic, and it requires examination specific to each critic individually. While Ibn Mahdi considers the term 'Thiqah' higher than the term 'Khiyar', we find the opposite with Ahmad; as revealed by his answer to Abu Dawud when he asked him about Sayyar Abu al-Hakam: 'Is he among the trustworthy?' He said: 'Yes, and above trustworthy, he was among the chosen (Al-Akhyar).' However, this note is only applicable with the meaning that 'Khiyar' allows for inclusion in the plural 'Al-Akhyar'. Yahya: 'I have seen him': Al-Fallas said: 'I never heard Yahya nor Abd al-Rahman narrate anything from Isma'il bin Rafi'. Yahya said: And I have seen him.' He also said: 'And Abd al-Rahman used to narrate to us from Abbad bin Rashid; and Yahya would say when he was mentioned: I have seen him.' The meaning of this: He is not satisfactory to him; and it involves avoiding explicit declaration of weakness mostly, and an additional meaning: That I abandoned narrating from him deliberately, despite having seen him. This is supported by Al-Bukhari's saying in 'Al-Du'afa'' and 'Al-Tarikh al-Kabir': 'Ibn Mahdi narrated from him, and Yahya al-Qattan abandoned him.' 'Whoever has insight into Hadith': This is one of the phrases indicating one who has realized the description of entering the spaciousness of Hadith, smelling its issues, and understanding criticism. Abu Hafs said: 'I narrated to Abd al-Rahman from Abdullah bin Dawud, from Sufyan, from Mansur, from Ibrahim, from Shurayh, who said: "The Qarin performs Tawaf twice...

I say: Perhaps Ibn Mahdi's defense of them - contrary to Ibn Ma'in, and after the necessary critical reason - was due to the nobility of their lineage among Arabs and their politeness with him and his companion Al-Qattan, even if they were Mawalis (clients) - for it was said regarding the first: He is a Mawla of Al-Azd, and regarding the second: He is a Mawla of Tamim. Yahya bin Sa'id's stipulation of this cause supports this in his saying: 'I sought Hadith with two men from the Arabs: Khalid bin al-Harith bin Salm al-Hujaymi, and Mu'adh bin Mu'adh al-Anbari, and I am a Mawla of Quraysh to Taym, so by Allah, they never preceded me to a Muhaddith and wrote something until I arrived.' It has a witness from the saying of Ya'qub bin Sufyan, regarding Ibn Muhajir: 'He has honor and nobility, and there is softness in his hadith.' Furthermore, Ibn Mahdi narrated from Sufyan from Ibn Muhajir. See an example of it in the history of Ibn Abi Khaythamah. And I did not find anyone who addressed this report with an explanation to satisfy me; perhaps it is correct, God willing. text: Traces of the Book in the Heritage of Successors 1 - Al-Fallas's books as palatable resources for Al-Bukhari's works: We could have done without this highlight, were it not that the claims of many orientalists about the delay of Hadith writing and the occurrence of a leap in authorship in the third century without antecedents and precedents to follow, makes neglecting this matter without pointing to its contrary, a dictation to these people, and silence amounting to admission, which is incorrect... Otherwise, how did Hadith authorship follow winding paths before reaching this degree of blatant maturity, with the generation of Al-Bukhari and his subsequent students? A maturity that manifests through the choice of resources, arrangement of narrators, consideration of narrations, and distinguishing between origins and fragments, what is suitable for the chapter and what is appropriate for commentary (Ta'liq), and what is by way of contradiction, or support, like the Follow-up (Mutabi') and Witness (Shahid)... and so on. Do not think that Al-Bukhari was generous in revealing the secret of his craft and indicating the place of his transparency in it, for he tightly locked the doors between that and his seeker, with extreme brevity, fleeting allusion, penetrating compressed headings, and different intentions concealed in one body... It is incumbent upon whoever seeks to realize that and enters its domains, to pay its dowry, and to show his skill, and to bear heavy burdens of continuous examination if attainment and determination support him, and care and success follow him after that, and before him after that are successive rounds in which he captures the strays and binds the wild ones. Because of what passed, Al-Bukhari deserved to be truly an example of the culmination of knowledge maturity in his generation and the generation of his sheikhs and its guide, so he folded in his great books the knowledge of the great critics from his sheikhs and those before them, whether that which he received by hearing and reading, or that...

text: for which he acquired the right of narration from collections, parts, compilations, histories, and books of men, and he learned from his sheikhs the arts of classification. Thus, Al-Bukhari's works deserved to represent the spirit of all the classifications of the second and third centuries. We are not in the process of discussing his apparent or hidden resources in their entirety, for what concerns us from them is only the works of Al-Fallas. The opportunity has enabled us to discern that after we unveiled, praise be to Allah, the Book of History, and followed it in this work with the part on 'Ilal, so what we intended became straightforward for us without others, as there was nothing in hand before by which Al-Bukhari's intakes from books could be distinguished and separated from others. Specifications of Al-Bukhari's quotes from Abu Hafs: The first thing that confronts the contemplator in the totality of quotes from Al-Fallas: a - Their abundance and breadth of arts: Al-Bukhari did not leave any of his books without quoting from Al-Fallas - except the part on Birr al-Walidayn - so he quoted from him in Al-Sahih, the two Histories, Al-Du'afa', Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, and Al-Qira'ah Khalf al-Imam, combining texts, reports, and criticisms. In the indexes of these books is sufficiency from tracking. b - Al-Ju'fi's pride in taking from his sheikh: This is a matter the eye does not miss in the folds of all the books, but some places articulate it clearly, like Al-Bukhari's saying: 'Abu Asim narrated to us; and Abu Hafs bin Ali made me understand some of it from him...' He admitted that he heard the hadith from Abu Asim and did not clarify some of it except with the help of Al-Fallas. Were it not that he takes pride in what he takes from him, he would have folded this detail and remained silent about it, but the etiquette of Muhaddithin in attributing benefits to their owners called him to what you see; and it is a great chapter of veneration; because in it, besides the honor of acquisition, is the honor of affiliation.

While Ibn al-Qattan (d. 628 AH) quoted from it in his comprehensive explanation, it did not happen for his countryman after him Ibn al-Mawwaq al-Marrakushi (d. 642 AH), so no mention of it appeared in 'Bughyat al-Nuqqad al-Naqalah'. What draws attention is that the book entered the sphere of scientific circulation in the Andalusian shore early; as the author's direct students introduced it there. However, the atrophy of actual benefit from the book did not cut off the right of its narration and attribution, and therefore, among these chains of transmission coming next, are what books of indexes revealed...

text: Unique Contents of the Book The total number of reports which their absence in sources suggests are unique to the book is ninety-four reports (94), of which 37 are in history, Jarh and Ta'dil, and recounting from Sheikhs, and the rest are shared equally between issues of defects and jurisprudential choices. In reality, the unique contents are more than the number we mentioned; because some of them like (127; 307) contain two or more reports, but we treated all paragraphs sharing a specific issue as a single report due to the unity of the subject, except in a few places. Most of the jurisprudential choices unique to the book are narrated from Yahya bin Sa'id al-Qattan, and the Muhaddithin generally did not pay attention to them, so their collections were devoid of them, and Al-Fallas's book remained an original and sole source for them. It is worth mentioning that Al-Qattan loved Sufyan al-Thawri, and followed his school; i.e., in jurisprudence. text: Corrections of the Book: It appears that the reports of the book are authentic, and a group of them you will not find in other than it, so they are from its unique narrations. The majority of it is useful when presented against its likes and counterparts in correcting much of what has befallen them; among them is what is useful in restoring what happened to some reports regarding obliteration; such as the saying of Al-Fallas: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id say: The mother of Shu'bah died, so I, Sulaiman al-Taimi, and Ibn Awn went to console him; So Al-Taimi said: Abu Nadrah told us. So Ibn Awn said to him: We have seen Abu Nadrah. So Sulaiman said to him: So you saw him, so what? So Ibn Awn remained silent' (1). This is useful in restoring what fell from the report itself in the history of Ibn Abi Khaythama (2). Or in detailing some reports that were transmitted in a brief, squeezed manner; such as in the statement of Abu Hafs: 'I mentioned to Yahya bin Sa'id the Hadith of Muhammad bin Amr al-Ansari, so I said to him: Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi told us, he said: Muhammad bin Amr told us, from Al-Qasim, from Aisha regarding the Aqiqah. So he said: He is more firm than Abd al-Rahman bin al-Qasim, yet he did not approve of him' (3). For this is a detailing of what befell the report of brevity in Ibn Hibban's *Al-Majruhin* (4), and Abu Ahmad al-Hakim in *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* (5). text: two men: Ibn Nadbah and Yusuf al-Samti. In Al-Du'afa' by Al-Uqayli from the Algerian copy (C), unlike all printed editions: 'Yusuf bin Musa'; this is undoubtedly an error; it is actually Yusuf bin Khalid. And in the editions of Al-Du'afa' (Al-Salafi and Al-Sarsawi): 'Al-Sha'bi', without the editors discussing it; all of this is misspelling (Tashif), and the correct citation is in Al-Kamil. The attribution of the narrator to 'Hasan al-Samt' (good conduct/appearance) is excellent and unblemished in Al-Du'afa' itself in copy (C); in it: 'Ahmad bin Umar narrated to us; he said: I heard Amr bin Ali say: Yusuf al-Samti is a liar (Kadhdhab)'; his phrase is not in this book of ours, and an indication confirming the attribution is Abu Dawud's saying in his answers: 'He used to pray for a long time.' Comparing what is in the original with some of its transmitters revealed errors in transmission, leading to naming narrators who do not exist except due to misspelling. From it is that the author's story about Yahya bin Sa'id saying: 'I and Awf went to visit Al-Salt bin Dinar, so Al-Salt mentioned Ali and spoke ill of him. So Awf said to him: What is wrong with you, O Abu Shu'ayb, may Allah not lift your fall!', was cited by Abu Ahmad al-Hakim in his Kuna (Kunyas), but strangely he mentioned it in two entries: the entry of Abu al-Hasan Musa bin Dinar al-Makki - and this is its correct place - and the entry of Abu al-Tayyib Musa bin Yasar al-Makki, and accordingly he established the narrator's father's name as 'Dinar' in the first, and 'Yasar' in the second. What mostly led him into this error is the misspelling of the name in one of the copies he relied on. There is no relation between these two narrators, for Abu al-Hasan Musa bin Dinar is a weak Makki. And Abu al-Tayyib Musa bin Yasar is a Marwazi who lived in Al-Mada'in, so he is not Makki, and moreover he is trustworthy; as in Talkhis al-Mutashabih regarding the drawing (Rasm);

text: editions of Al-Du'afa' by Al-Uqayli contradicted this transmission by way of misspelling, distortion, and omission. The report should have ended at his saying: '"Ata narrated to us", when he did not hear!', then resume speaking about Fitr in a following report, which is our practice, but the editions merged two reports into one, and were excessive in omission, thus disturbing the meaning horrendously. We placed what was omitted from them and rectified by our book between brackets, so the comparison becomes valid, although I think the origin of the defect is in Al-Uqayli's book itself, for Al-Dhahabi followed him in it, and Allah knows best. The danger of the omitted part appears in that it changes the critical judgment or impugns its direction; for Yazid bin Harun's narration is a witness to Fitr's hearing (Sama') from Al-Walibi, and Waki's narration is a witness to refuting his hearing, and it is the intended one, and with its loss the disturbance occurs, and it has happened!. Sometimes quoting parts of the author's single speech on a critical issue without the rest corrupts the intended judgment; as happened with Al-Fallas's saying: 'Yahya used not to narrate to us from Al-Walid bin Jami', then shortly before his death, he took them from Ali al-Sa'igh and narrated them to me; and they were six hadiths.' Ibn Hibban in Al-Majruhin, and Al-Hakim in Al-Madkhal quoted from it: 'And Yahya used not to narrate from Al-Walid bin Jami''; and did not cite its remainder, so their restriction led to the opposite of the author's intent, and entailed not considering Yahya's return to narrating from him, even though this stance of his undoubtedly stems from a justified critical revision. Another example of this sort; Amr bin Bahr's saying: 'And I heard Bishr bin al-Mufaddal say: Khalid narrated to us, he said: I heard Ali bin al-Aqmar say: [I heard Abu al-Ahwas say: I heard Abdullah bin Mas'ud say]: "Whoever does not catch the bowing, the prostration is not counted".'

And I heard Abdullah bin Dawud say: I heard Ishaq bin al-Sabbah] - a man from the descendants of Al-Ash'ath bin Qays - narrating from Abd al-Malik bin Umayr, he said: Musa bin Talha bought land from the land of Al-Sawad, so he sent to Al-Qasim bin Abd al-Rahman to witness it but he refused, so Musa said: Then I testify against your father - meaning: Abdullah bin Mas'ud - that he bought land from the land of Al-Sawad, and made me a witness to it. I say: With this report, an error in transmission is known in Al-Uqayli's Du'afa', leading to reversing the case; for Abu Ja'far, when he needed to distribute the text between two places, was confused in attributing the second part, so instead of attributing the speech to Yahya bin Ma'in, who is intended above by 'the man' as I explicitly stated, he attributed it to Yahya bin Sa'id, and explicitly named him saying: 'Ibn Sa'id', although the rest of the speech refutes it effortlessly, for how can Al-Qattan speak [critically] about a narrator then narrate from him outside of discussion sessions? The fulfillment of the comment in the speech brought after, signals an intention of objection by Ibn Mahdi, and this rarely happens with him against Al-Qattan. Al-Uqayli's intended phrase: 'Amr bin Ali; he said: I heard Yahya bin Sa'id mention one day Yunus bin Abi Ishaq and speak about him; so Abd al-Rahman said: There was no harm in him; Abu Hafs says it...'. And the transmission ends with a slight difference in wording to the text's saying: 'from Sufyan from him'. Attached to this is Abu Hafs's saying: 'Yahya bin Sa'id narrated to us; he said: Hisham narrated to us, he said: Yahya bin Abi Kathir narrated to us, from Hafs bin Farafisah, he said: I heard Urwah bin al-Zubayr saying in his prostration: "O Allah, forgive Al-Zubayr bin al-Awwam, and Asma' bint Abi Bakr".' One of the strongest examples of mutual support between text correction and critical authentication (Takhrij), is at Al-Fallas's saying: 'Yahya narrated to us, he said: Abd al-Rahman bin Khudayr narrated to us, he said: Abu Najih narrated to me, he said: I heard Abu Hurayrah say: That the ears of the son of Adam be filled with molten lead, is better for him than to hear the call [to prayer] and then not answer.' I say: In the original manuscript of 'Al-'Ilal': 'Hudayn'; a misspelling that passed by the editors of Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah, so they wrote it with Sad and Nun, and it was also misspelled in his entry in Du'afa' Al-Uqayli to 'Hadir' - with Ha' - and under the letter its unpointed counterpart in small script as usual. Al-Khatib cut off the dispute of every disputant; when he transmitted this very text from Al-Fallas, in his book Talkhis al-Mutashabih fi al-Rasm; but he prefaced it by saying: 'As for the second with Kha' and Dad with dots and with Ra', he is: Abd al-Rahman bin Khudayr al-Hana'i al-Basri'; then he cited the report. Before him, Al-Askari in Tashifat al-Muhaddithin pointed out the occurrence of misspelling for this name. Among what relates to clear misspelling that changes the realities of narrators, is what you find in Al-'Ilal from Amr: 'And I heard Yahya say: I was born in the year one hundred and twenty at its beginning, and Mu'adh was born in the year nineteen at its end; he was older than me by two months.' For the report is in Al-Kamil also but with a heinous misspelling that corrupted the meaning; in it: 'And Khalid was born in the year twenty at its beginning.' So his saying: 'Khalid', is a misspelling, the correct is 'Yahya'; for he is the intended one.

text: Attached to what passed, is what Ibn Adi quoted in Al-Kamil from our book, which is Al-Fallas's saying: 'I heard a man narrating to Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi from Yahya bin Sa'id, from Ubaydullah, from Nafi', that Ibn Umar used to return [greeting] just as he was greeted...'. The transmission in Zakkar's edition suffered from the omission of 'Ubaydullah' between Yahya and Nafi', and in it and Al-Sarsawi's edition the misspelling of 'kama' (just as) to 'kullama' (whenever); and there is a difference between them. Among what Al-Sayrafi's words alerted to is the existence of fabrication by some transmitters from him between two biographies and attributing what concerns one to the other; what he said in the entry of Muhammad bin Abi al-Ja'd: 'And I never heard Abd al-Rahman mention this Sheikh', and he is the one meant by him as 'the Sheikh'. Ibn Asakir transmitted this phrase textually, in the biography of Sulayman bin Arqam, although the speech is about someone else; and the dominant thought is that the transmission is an error; because the speech in the copy of Al-'Ilal about Sulayman bin Arqam comes immediately after the speech about Ibn Abi al-Ja'd, and that is a cause for confusion and ambiguity, and the origin of it as it appears is from someone above Ibn Asakir. Mughlatay fell into the same confusion in his Ikmal; and this was also attributed to Ibn Hajar in Tahdhib al-Tahdhib. Al-Uqayli quoted correctly from the author in the entry of Muhammad bin Abi al-Ja'd, so he did not mix him up with Sulayman bin Arqam. Related to what passed, is that what is in Al-Tarikh al-Kabir by Al-Bukhari is problematic if authentic; for it contains Ibn Mahdi's mention of the narrator, contrary to Abu Hafs's statement; which contradicts everyone's transmission; and its text is: 'Muhammad bin Abi al-Ja'd: He heard Al-Sha'bi. His saying; Ibn Mahdi said it from Sufyan', and in the phrase as you see is anxiety we did not feel comfortable with, especially with the absence of this detail in the books of transmitters benefiting from Al-Bukhari, especially Al-Jarh...

text: 4 - Methodology of Investigation: I undertook correcting the text and comparing it with what was transmitted from it, while noting many of the scribe's errors, habits, additions, and minor mistakes, not to bloat the footnotes, but to inform the reader about a part of the text's history and the subsequent changes that befell it. I accompanied this with extracting the follow-ups (mutaba'at) of the book's hadiths, identifying its notables, correcting its illusions, and comparing the author's critical statements with their counterparts among the prominent figures of the stage, especially from books of histories, questions (su'alat), and books of 'Jarh and Ta'dil'. Part of the methodology of identifying narrators was that I bring Al-Fallas's words about the narrator outside the book of 'Al-'Ilal' if I find them, if I do not find them, I transfer his narration of his sheikhs' sayings, if I do not find that, I descend to transferring the words of the notables of his layer and his students, and I may combine all that if possible. text: Ibn Awn said to him: We have seen Abu Nadrah. So Sulaiman said: So you saw him, so what? So Ibn [1] Awn fell silent (1).
foot_note:
1. [1] (Saad): 'Bin'. _________ = And in accordance with it, it appeared in the history of Amr, and in the book *Tabaqat Al-Fuqaha wa Al-Muhaddithin* by Ibn Zanjawiyah (94). Al-Dawlabi reported it in his *Kuna* (3/1088) from Yahya bin Sa'id, saying: 'I heard Yahya bin Ma'in say: Abu Nadrah is Al-Mundhir bin Malik bin Qi'ah; this is what Yahya said; he did not say: Ibn Qati'ah.' Likewise, it appeared in his history from the narration of Al-Duri (4/141; No: 3597), *Ilal Ahmad* (3/224; No: 4976), *Su'alat Abi Dawud* (191; No: 110), and others. Abu Ali Al-Ghassani said in *Taqyid Al-Muhmal* (1/109): 'With a Kasra on the Qaf and a Sukun on the Ta', and Al-Khazraji recorded it similarly in *Al-Khulasah* (387), and I do not know their source for it. Yahya bin Ma'in was asked about him and said: Trustworthy (*Al-Kamil*: 9/591; No: 16200), and likewise he said in the narration of Ishaq bin Mansur from him (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/241; No: 1088). Abu Zur'ah: Trustworthy (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/241; No: 1088). Abu Hatim: I know nothing but good (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/241; No: 1088). Al-Uqayli did not bring anything in his biography in *Al-Du'afa* more than the report above, but with differing outlets. Ibn Adi said: If a trustworthy person narrates from him, his hadith is straight, and I have not seen any objectionable (Munkar) hadiths from him; because I did not find any objectionable hadith when a trustworthy person narrates from him, therefore I did not mention anything for him (*Al-Kamil*: 9/591). I say: It is as if he deemed him acceptable with this. 
1. Among the benefits of the report - which is the primary intent - is that Ibn Awn did not find a way before these knowledgeable critics to disparage Abu Nadrah as was his habit - if it is established that the following story is a different incident than the one mentioned by Al-Fallas above; for in *Al-Kamil* by Ibn Adi (9/590; No: 16197): 'Yahya bin Zakariya bin Abi Za'idah said: Abu Nadrah was mentioned to Ibn Awn. He said: We have seen Abu Nadrah!'. Abu Dawud said (2/40; No: 1046): 'Ibn Awn signaled a defect in him (Ghamazahu).' This is the implication of the story. If Ibn Awn's statement had any weight, these Imams would have acknowledged it, but since they did not, it became apparent that he criticized him without proof. Furthermore, Al-Taimi is not rejected regarding Abu Nadrah, for he heard from him, and that is why Ibn Awn could not give an answer. Even if he saw him, he cannot say like Al-Taimi 'He told us (Haddathana)', as he has no hearing from him, let alone impugn him, and Allah knows best. A parallel to this is that Abu Hatim said: A group in Basra saw Anas bin Malik but did not hear from him; among them is Ibn Awn (*Marasil Ibnihi*: 113; No: 412).

He said: None of them are established except what he said: 'I heard'; they are around ten. Indeed, his hadiths from Mujahid are from Abu Yahya Al-Qattat, and Hakim bin Jubair, and these (*Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 6/92; 2227: and Ibn Hajar quoted it in *Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib* briefly: 4/225). Al-Tirmidhi said: I said to Muhammad [meaning: Al-Bukhari]: They say: Al-A'mash did not hear from Mujahid except four hadiths. He said: Wind, it is nothing; I have counted many hadiths for him, around thirty or less or more, in which he says: Mujahid told us (*Ilal Al-Tirmidhi Al-Kabir*: 388). Yahya bin Ma'in said: Al-A'mash only heard four hadiths from Mujahid, or five (*Tarikhuhu* from the narration of Al-Duri: 3/327; No: 1570). Abu Hatim: I fear that Al-A'mash did not hear from Mujahid; indeed Al-A'mash has little hearing from Mujahid, and the generality of what he narrates from Mujahid is Mudallas (*Ilaluhu*: 2/210; No: 2119). Waki' said: Al-A'mash did not hear from Mujahid except four hadiths (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 1/224). I say: Their disagreement on the number of hadiths is due to the variation in their capabilities in the breadth of narration, the induction of chains, and the intent to track; for whoever mentioned four or five, mostly intended what occurred in his memory at the moment, unlike one who took the path of investigation and exhaustion like the affair of Muhammad bin Isma'il (Al-Bukhari), for he mentioned more than before. Therefore, it is not far-fetched that some found what others did not, although all of them are united in establishing the scarcity of what Ibn Mahran (Al-A'mash) heard from Mujahid, and his Tadlis of what is other than that.

I say: Meaning: when he is solitary, and that is why Al-Bukhari did not extract for him in his *Sahih*, but extracted for him in *Al-Adab Al-Mufrad* supported by others. And in the speech of Ali bin Al-Madini appeared an explanation of why he was weakened: 'There was no one in Medina more knowledgeable about Maghazi (campaigns) than him, so he fell into need; so it was as if they accused him!' (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 1/37; and with its meaning in *Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythama*: Volume Three: 2/227; No: 2595). Its interpretation from Ali's wording also: 'They used to fear that if he came to a man and asked him for something and he didn't give him, he would say about him: His father did not witness Badr' (*Du'afa Al-Uqayli*: 2/187; No: 713). End quote. Ali did not confirm this wound definitively as you see, but it is within the realm of possibility. For ultimately, the confusion of senility and the necessity of poverty combined for him. In my opinion, the accusation by Ibn Dhi'b and others is directed towards this, as his hearing is old. If he had been branded with lying at first, his narration would not have lasted long. It appears that if what was heard from him early on could be separated from what came later, the first would be accepted and the second rejected. But since that was difficult - along with the accusation whether true or not - Al-Barqi listed him in the chapter of those whose hadith is predominantly weak, and some scholars of Hadith abandoned narrating from him as in *Ikmal Ibn Qulayj* (6/228). So the most correct view regarding his hadith is confusion (Ikhtilat).

I say: Meaning: I will ruin him; he intends the consequence, which is striking out his hadith and abandoning narration from him. Then followed Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan from Shu'bah's students, and it is gathered from the transfer of his students from him that he used to approve of Mujalid then turned away from him, or the opposite - and we do not determine which is earlier or later - and sometimes he appears in some transfers as hesitant; but his weakening of him is more famous and common. As for the proofs of all that from him, they are many; from the first is that Ibn Al-Muthanna Al-Anzi said: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id narrating from Mujalid (*Du'afa Al-Uqayli*: 6/96; 5986; *Al-Kamil*: 10/14; No: 16551). From the third is the saying of Ali bin Al-Madini: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id: What about Mujalid? He said: In my soul (mind) there is something about him! (*Al-Kamil*: 10/14; No: 16549). Yahya bin Ma'in almost joins Yahya bin Sa'id, for they resembled each other in their stance on our companion, until Ibn Abi Khaythama said: I heard Yahya bin Ma'in say: Mujalid bin Sa'id is trustworthy. foot_note:
1. [1] (S): 'Harun'. [2] In the original: 'Al-Wali'; misspelling. And added for emphasis in Al-Du'afa' and Al-Siyar: 'himself'. _________ 
1. Al-Du'afa': 1/355; no. 565; and misspelled to 'Ajlaj' ten times in Al-Salafi's edition (1/139-140); Al-Majruhin: 1/175; Al-Kamil: 1/426-427. In the reason for linking this report to the one before it is a point; which is that Fitr was compared to Al-Ajlah; Abdullah bin Ahmad said: 'I heard my father say: How close Al-Ajlah is to Fitr bin Khalifah' (Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal: 2/413; no. 2849). And add to it that both are Shi'a. This is from aspects of mental association in Al-Fallas's mind during composition, which is rich with analogous and similar narrators. However, gathering the statements of Imams regarding both - even if they are close - shows that Fitr's condition is better than his peer's condition, and Allah knows best. 
2. He is: Ajlah bin Abdullah Al-Kindi, and Ibn Zanjuyah named him 'Yahya', as in his Tabaqat al-Fuqaha' wa al-Muhaddithin (manuscript): (78). And Ajlah is his nickname. Al-Fallas said in his History (400): 'He died in the year one hundred and forty-five'. Ibn Sa'd: He was very weak (Al-Tabaqat al-Kabir: 8/469; no. 3380). Ibn Ma'in said about him in Al-Duri's narration (3/269; no. 1276): Trustworthy. And said once: There is no harm in him (3/454; no. 2232). And said also in the narrations of Al-Kawsaj (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 2/347; no. 1317) and Al-Daqqaq (42; no. 52): 'Salih' (Good/Righteous). Ibn Shahin recounted from him (Tarikh Asma' al-Du'afa': 118; no. 333) via Al-Kawsaj contrary to the above, saying: 'Weak'; and I consider it an illusion from him in transmission. He attributed similar via Al-Mufaddal. Ibn al-Madini: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id: Ajlah? He said: There is something in my heart about him (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 2/347; no. 1317). Abu Hatim: Al-Ajlah is soft, not strong, his hadith is written but not used as proof (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 2/347; no. 1317). Abu Dawud via Al-Ajurri (1/318; no. 531): 'Ajlah is weak'. And added: And Yahya has narrated from Ajlah'. Al-Fasawi: Kufan trustworthy, in his hadith there is softness (Al-Ma'rifah wa al-Tarikh: 3/104). Al-Saji: Weak, and he is truthful (Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 2/14; no. 239). And in Ibn al-Jarud's book: He is nothing (Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 2/14; no. 239). Abu al-Qasim al-Balkhi and Abu al-Arab mentioned him among the weak (Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 2/14; no. 239). Abu Abd Allah al-Hakim mentioned him in Ma'rifat Jama'ah min =

text: Ali bin Al-Husayn, and Al-Husayn bin Ali (1). He said [1]: And I heard him [2] say: Habib bin Abi Thabit narrated to us, he said: We were
foot_note:
1. [1] Not in Al-Du'afa' nor in Al-Majruhin nor in Al-Kamil, and the context of the report with the first two is more correct than in our copy. [2] In the original: 'And I heard Yahya say', and it contains a corrupting insertion. The meaning in reality is that Yahya heard Al-Ajlah say ... the report. In Al-Kamil: 'I thought he said'; and I think it is a misspelling. Accordingly, 'He said' occurring above belongs to Yahya not Al-Fallas, and whoever joined the two paragraphs without pause did well, as Al-Uqayli did. _________ = the Narrators of the Successors and those after them whose hadith was not used as proof in the Sahih and were not dropped' (Ma'rifat 'Ulum al-Hadith: 337). I say: It is synonymous with the words of Al-Fasawi and Al-Saji; and it is one of the most just opinions. No one was excessive in disparaging him as Al-Juzjani did - and he is obstinate in disparagement - for he said: 'Fabricator (Muftarin)' (Ahwal al-Rijal: 59), and no critic denied his truthfulness, so perhaps it is a terminology of Abu Ishaq al-Sa'di whose significance we did not grasp, and Allah knows best. Sufyan bin Uyaynah considered him having better memory than Muhammad bin Salim (Al-Kamil: 9/136; no. 14835). And [Ibn Ma'in] prioritized him over Mujalid and Hajjaj bin Arta'ah and Ibn Abi Layla (Al-Takmil by Ibn Kathir: 2/23). Al-Qattan reversed the case regarding Mujalid specifically, for Ali bin Abdullah said: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id: Where was Al-Ajlah compared to Mujalid? He said: He was below him (Al-Du'afa' by Al-Uqayli: 1/356; no. 566). In Al-Kamil (2/367; no. 2721): 'Worse condition than him'. Ali Ibn al-Madini said from Yahya bin Sa'id al-Qattan: Mu'arrif bin Wasil is more established than Al-Ajlah (Tahdhib al-Kamal: 28/261; no. 6084). Ahmad bin Hanbal: Ajlah and Mujalid are close in hadith; Ajlah has narrated more than one rejected hadith (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 2/347; no. 1317). In Su'alat Abi Dawud to Ahmad (316-317; no. 426): I said to Ahmad: Is Ajlah more beloved to you or Hurayth? He said: Ajlah. I said: Do you narrate from him? He said: Yes'. Al-Uqayli: 'And Al-Ajlah is not followed on this despite his confusion in it, except by one who is below him: Muhammad bin Salim' (Al-Du'afa' by Al-Uqayli: 1/357; no. 572). Ibn Adi: 'Al-Ajlah bin Abdullah has good hadiths ... The Kufans and others narrate from him, and I did not find anything rejected from him exceeding the limit neither in Isnad nor text, and I hope there is no harm in him, except that he is counted among the Shi'a of Kufa, and he is, in my view, straight in hadith, truthful (Al-Kamil: 2/373; no. 2737). 
1. See: The author's example following it.

text: with [1] Al-Husayn bin Ali (1) and he said: "No divorce except after marriage [2]" (2). 26 - He said (3): And I heard Yahya [3] say: I did not write from anyone among
foot_note:
1. [1] Al-Du'afa': 'with him'. [2] In Al-Majruhin: 'Al-Nikah'. [3] In Al-Tarikh: 'Yahya bin Sa'id'. _________ 
1. Meaning: He inverted the name, and it should be Ali bin Al-Husayn. 
2. The defect in it is from Ajlah; because Habib bin Abi Thabit is trustworthy, all good is not denied from him; - as Ahmad said in his Answers (299; no. 363) - and it was narrated from him correctly - i.e., from Ali bin Husayn, Sa'id bin Mansur extracted it in his Sunan (1/292; no. 1033), saying: Hammad bin Shu'ayb narrated to us, from Habib bin Abi Thabit with it with a fuller context, and Hammad is weak. Indeed, the hadith is also straight from Al-Ajlah, narrated by Sa'id bin Mansur in his Sunan (1/292; no. 1034) from Hushaym, Al-Ajlah informed us, from Habib, he said: A man came to Ali bin Husayn, and said: What do you say about a man who said: 'If' I marry so-and-so she is divorced?? He said: 'It is nothing, Allah began with marriage before divorce, then He said: {O you who have believed, when you marry believing women and then divorce them} [Al-Ahzab: 49], so Allah began with marriage before divorce, and his saying is nothing.' Hushaym bin Bashir Al-Wasiti is trustworthy with much memorization but practices Tadlis (See: Ikmal Mughlatay: 12/156-161; no. 4960), but he declared hearing, and it is not thought of him to hear an illusion from Al-Ajlah and correct it, so it remains only that Al-Ajlah narrated the hadith well when Hushaym heard it from him, then poor memory or confusion occurred to him at the time Yahya Al-Qattan narrated it, which took the hadith out of its proper form. The hadith after this was extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in Al-Musannaf (4/64; no. 17828) from Ghundar, from Shu'bah, from Al-Hakam - meaning: Ibn Utaybah - from Ali bin Husayn; and he mentioned it. Ibn al-Ja'd followed Ghundar from Shu'bah with it in his Musnad (1/54; no. 425), and from his path Abu Bakr al-Bazzar extracted it in Al-Ghaylaniyyat (134; no. 91). And every narrator of the correct version of the hadith above has a trustworthy follower; Yahya bin Sa'id was followed by Hushaym bin Bashir in Sunan Sa'id bin Mansur (1/292; no. 1034) and he was discussed. Al-Ajlah was followed in Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah (4/64; no. 17827) by Mu'arrif bin Wasil, and Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy in the narration of Al-Kawsaj and Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i (Tahdhib al-Kamal: 28/261). And Habib was followed by Abu Ishaq al-Sabi'i - and he is who he is - in Al-Sunan al-Kubra by Al-Bayhaqi (7/256; no. 14891). 
3. Tarikh Amr bin Ali Al-Fallas: 306; Al-Kamil: 1/369; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 3/283. =

publisher: Markaz Ihsan li-Dirasat al-Sunnah al-Nabawiyyah, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: The hadith of Hamzah Al-Dabbi from Al-Hasan, that a man said: O Messenger [1] of Allah, when does dead meat become forbidden [2] to us? He said: 'When you have quenched your thirst with milk, and the provision of your family has come.' And the hadith [3] of Ziyad Al-A'lam, from Al-Hasan, from Abu Bakra, that he bowed before reaching the row. And the hadith of Uthman [4] Al-Batti [5] from Al-Hasan, from Ali regarding deliverance (Al-Khalas) (1). Mu'adh said: So I narrated it to Wuhaib [6] bin Khalid (2) and he said: If I had heard this from you, I would not have left anything with him.
foot_note:
1. [1] (S): 'Ya Rasul'. [2] The word is forbidden (missing/illegible) in the original. [3] The scribe imagined the matter related to a new report, so he drew the separator circle, and misspelled the word to 'Haddathani', while the speech is still connected. [4] (S): 'Uthman'. [5] In the original: 'Al-Taymi'; misspelling. [6] In the original: 'Wahb', magnified, which is a misspelling and its correction is from the author's history (307). _________ 
1. These three hadiths from Al-Hasan's narration share one thing, which is that they were not heard by Ash'ath al-Humrani al-Basri from Al-Hasan, despite his frequent narration from him, and that is due to his truthfulness and extreme caution. As for the first hadith, the hadith of Hamzah Al-Dabbi: I did not find anyone who extracted it after long searching. As for the second, Ahmad extracted it in Al-Musnad (34/44; no. 20405), and Ibn al-Jarud in Al-Muntaqa (88; no. 318) via Yahya Al-Qattan, and Al-Bazzar via Mu'adh bin Mu'adh (9/107; no. 3651); both from Al-Ash'ath from Ziyad Al-A'lam with it, and the hadith has paths from Ziyad, and from Al-Hasan that we will not prolong mentioning, and Al-Bukhari - and others - extracted it in Al-Sahih via Hammam Al-Awdhi from Ziyad with it (1/156; no. 783). As for the third, Ibn Abi Shaybah extracted it from Ibn Ulayyah, from Uthman Al-Batti, from Al-Hasan with it (10/551; no. 20646). 
2. Al-Fallas said about him in this book of ours - and it will come later -: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id mention him and praise him well', and he quoted it in Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil (9/35; no. 158) and Tahdhib al-Kamal (31/167).
