text: 28 - And I asked (1) Yahya about the hadith of Matar (2), from Al-Hasan, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: 'I do not pardon a man who kills after taking the blood money', he said [1]: Musa bin Sayyar [2] narrated to us, he said [3]: Al-Hasan narrated to us [4] that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: 'I do not pardon anyone who kills after taking [5] the blood money'. So I said: I want [6] the hadith of Matar; so he narrated it to me after difficulty (3).
foot_note:
1. [1] Al-Du'afa'; Al-Kamil: So he said. [2] Thus correct in the original, and misspelled to 'Yasar' in Al-Uqayli's book in its two editions (Al-Salafi and Al-Sarsawi). He is Al-Aswari. [3] Not in Al-Du'afa'. [4] Al-Uqayli's book: 'From'. [5] Added in Al-Kamil: 'After his pardon and taking'. [6] Al-Uqayli's book: 'I want it from'. _________ 
1. Al-Du'afa': 1364/4; no. 1812; Al-Kamil: 396/6. 
2. The author said in his History (303): 'Matar Al-Warraq died in the year one hundred and twenty-nine, and he is Matar bin Tahman'. Abu Dawud in Su'alat Al-Ajurri (2/71; no. 1164): He is not a proof according to me. And Matar is not relied upon in a hadith if there is disagreement. 
3. Yahya bin Sa'id al-Qattan deliberately turned away from the hadith of Matar from Al-Hasan to others in both cases - this one and the one immediately following - and the reason is his disapproval of him; therefore he did not narrate from him except with reluctance, evidenced by Al-Fallas's saying in both instances: 'So he did not narrate it to me except after difficulty'. His turning to Musa bin Sayyar Al-Aswari Al-Basri is only proof of his extreme hesitation to narrate from Matar, and it does not necessitate or imply at all that his Isnad is straight, so do not rejoice in it; for Al-Qattan said: 'His hadith is nothing' (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 8/146; no. 659), and he was 'among those pointed at for Qadar (free will dogma), weak in hadith', said by Al-Daraqutni in his comments on Majruhi Ibn Hibban (230; no. 299). And Abu Dawud said in Su'alat Al-Ajurri (2/16; no. 978): 'Yahya narrated from him then abandoned him', so perhaps this hadith is from Yahya's narration from him before abandoning him. The discussion is about the Isnad below Al-Hasan, but as for what is above him, Al-Hasan's Mursal narrations are disputed; they are weak according to Ahmad and Al-Tirmidhi, while Al-Qattan and Abu Zur'ah Al-Razi saw that these Mursal narrations have bases except for two or four hadiths (See: Sharh 'Ilal Al-Tirmidhi by Ibn Rajab: 1/536). In any case, Mursal is outside the circle of argumentation - mostly -, and the hadith is weak from this aspect, and its defect is Matar; for he is weak, a Mudallis, and used 'an'ana. We do not know if Yahya heard from Matar or not? Although history allows it, for Matar died in the year =

text: And I asked him [1] about the hadith of Matar, from Al-Hasan, that Ali said: Whoever marries while in Ihram, we separate [2] his wife from him, and we do not validate [3] his marriage (1).
foot_note:
1. [1] Al-Du'afa': 'And I asked Yahya'. [2] (S): 'Tara'na'; misspelling. [3] In Al-Du'afa': 'Yujaz' (is validated), and it has a basis. _________ = 129 AH according to Amr bin Ali in his History (303) - which is the source - and he died before that according to others by four years, and Yahya was born in the year one hundred and twenty as Al-Fallas transmitted in this book of ours (110), so he was a discerning boy the day Al-Warraq died, so his hearing from him is possible, but we did not find anyone who affirmed or mentioned it, and had Amr bin Ali recounted Yahya's Isnad in this hadith as he did in the one following it, we would have verified this matter. What remains at hand is that Yahya does not narrate from Matar except through an intermediary, who is here Sa'id bin Abi Arubah, and he is likewise from Al-Hasan via Mursal in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra by Al-Bayhaqi (54/8; no. 15824); and its defect is as preceded. As for Sa'id, although he used 'an'ana for the hadith from Al-Hasan, they affirmed his hearing from him, and did not mention him among those who practiced Tadlis from him (See: Tarikh Amr bin Ali: 586-587). The hadith with its paths is weak from this aspect. And Sayyar's narration - despite its weakness - is one of the benefits of the book, for I did not find it with anyone other than Al-Fallas, and he is the authority on it for the transmitters. The hadith was narrated from Al-Hasan connected, from Jabir elevating it, via Hammad also, from Matar with it, by Abu Dawud in his Sunan (293/4, 4509), and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (96/8; no. 16046), and Ahmad in his Musnad (363/3; no. 14954), but in all of them is: 'I reckon it from Al-Hasan' with uncertainty, and it is further defective due to Al-Hasan not hearing from Jabir (See: Al-Marasil by Ibn Abi Hatim: 36; no. 112). Likewise - i.e., via Hammad - Al-Tayalisi extracted it in his Musnad (3/320; no. 1872), with ambiguity of the narrator from Jabir, and it is interrupted (Munqati'). 
1. Musaddad bin Musarhad extracted it in his Musnad (quoted from Ithaf al-Maharah al-Khayarah: 4/104; no. 1/3238; Al-Matalib al-Aliyah: 6/385; no. 1197; 8/76; no. 1558), he said: Yahya narrated to us, from Ibn Abi Arubah, from Matar, with it. Al-Busiri said following it: 'This is an Isnad whose men are trustworthy'. And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (7/347; no. 14216), via Muhammad bin Yahya, Abdullah bin Bakr narrated to us, Sa'id narrated to us, from Matar; and he mentioned it similarly. I say: Al-Busiri's previous comment is a general authentication, otherwise Matar is not approved by Al-Qattan due to his poor memory, for he used to compare him to Ibn Abi Layla - specifically regarding Ata - (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 8/288) =

text: He said: Maymun (1) Al-Mara'i [1] narrated to us, he said: 'Al-Hasan narrated to us, from Ali [2]',
foot_note:
1. [1] So in the original, with Aleph after Ra, and this narration is not rejected, but what analogy requires is: 'Al-Mar'i', attributed to Imru' al-Qays. [2] 'From Ali': missing from both editions of Al-Du'afa'. _________ = for that reason he turned away from him. The hadith is Mursal, for Al-Hasan did not hear from Ali; 'because Ali went out to Iraq following his pledge of allegiance, and Al-Hasan resided in Medina so he did not meet him after that' (Jami' al-Tahsil by Al-Ala'i: 162; no. 135). 
1. Al-Fallas said: Maymun bin Musa Al-Mar'i, weak (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 237/8; no. 1065), and said another time: Truthful (Saduq) (Al-Kamil: 415/6). I say: There is no contradiction, if he meant truthful in himself, weak in hadith. And Al-Fallas also said: 'I heard Abd al-Samad bin Abd al-Warith say: I heard Khalid Al-Abd - weak - say: Al-Hasan said: I prayed behind twenty-eight Badris (veterans of Badr) all of whom performed Qunut in Fajr after bowing. So I said to him: From whom did you hear this? He said: From Maymun Al-Mar'i. Abd al-Samad said: So I met Maymun Al-Mar'i and asked him, he said: Al-Hasan said: I prayed behind twenty-eight Badris. So I said: From whom did you hear this? He said: Khalid Al-Abd narrated to me. (Al-Tarikh al-Awsat: 556/3; no 843; Al-Tarikh al-Kabir: 165/3; no. 567; Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 237/8; no. 1065; and the context of the report is from the second, and there is difference in it). If both parties were equal in the probability of lying - since it is necessary that one of them is lying in this report at least - our companion would have been cleared, but the dominant opinion is directed towards the defect being Khalid Al-Abd, not Maymun, for Al-Bukhari said: 'Amr bin Ali accused him of fabrication' (Al-Tarikh al-Awsat: 408/3; no. 619), not to mention that Maymun was not explicitly criticized for other than Tadlis. Ahmad: Maymun used to practice Tadlis, and used not to say: Al-Hasan narrated to us, and I see no harm in him. (From Ibn Shaqla's quotes from Al-Saji: 256; no. 342; Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal: 523/2; no. 3450; Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 237/8; no. 1065). Al-Bukhari said: Abu al-Walid - he is: Al-Tayalisi - said: Maymun brought out a book to us and said: If you wish I will narrate to you what I heard from him, and if you wish I wrote in it from everyone. So we said: Narrate to us what you heard; so he narrated four things to us that have no Isnad (Al-Tarikh al-Kabir: 342/7; no. 1470). Abu Hatim: Truthful (Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil: 237/8; no. 1065). Abu Dawud: He narrated from Al-Hasan three things; meaning: by hearing. From (His Answers to Abu Ubayd: 439/1-440; no. 932). And Abdullah bin Ahmad said: I heard =

text: So I said: I want the hadith of Matar, but he did not narrate it to me except after difficulty (1).

1. Al-Fallas followed his rival Bundar, via Al-Saji in Al-Kamil by Ibn Adi (9/699; no. 16505), and from the same path Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (5/106; no. 9163); and in both Maymun used 'an'ana; unlike what is with the author where there is declaration of hearing, which is an added benefit for defects; Ibn Adi said (9/699): 'And this Maymun is rare in hadith, and if he says "Haddathana" (narrated to us), he is truthful; because he was accused of Tadlis'. I say: And he has declared hearing so there is no problem. This hadith might be among what was authentic for Yahya Al-Qattan from Maymun, for Ibn Shaqla Al-Baghdadi in his Turar from Al-Saji (257; no 343), attributed to Yahya his saying: 'I came to Maymun Al-Mar'i, and he did not validate for me except these hadiths which you heard', then Zakariya bin Yahya cited after it examples of his hadiths, including this hadith. I do not know if he counted it among his rejected narrations or among what is authentic from him, and the apparent is that it is from the first; because the custom of authors on weak narrators is to append the biography with examples of the narrator's rejected narrations, and Al-Saji has an excuse in citation, for Maymun used 'an'ana in his narration, and the narration of declaration did not occur to him. In any case, this alternative Isnad which Yahya approved and sought to shift to from Matar's hadith, is more exemplary and a better guided path, but it is necessary to point out that Yahya's narration from Maymun in this context is closer to exercising comparison than to abstract authentication, for the story is in discussion (Muzakarah), and in it is permitted what is not permitted in dictation and hearing sessions. We conclude with that, that the hadith from this aspect has gathered two conditions strengthening it: First: The narrator who practices Tadlis declaring narration in it. Second: Its inclusion in what Yahya heard from Maymun, and his condition has passed with us - in addition to being strict -. Thus; it may rise to be Hasan by this consideration, and Allah knows best.

We did not find the narration of Sahl bin Hassan and his question to Ibn Abi Adi. But the hadith from Ibn Abi Adi, Al-Tabari extracted it in his Tafsir (15/297), from Muhammad bin Bashshar, from Ibn Abi Adi with it. And its completion: 'He said: A deep valley separating the people of misguidance and the people of guidance, and the people of Paradise and the people of Hell'. It is suspended from Al-Bakali in Tafsir Ibn Abi Hatim (7/2368; no. 12858). There is a defect in the chain, which is that Ibn Abi Adi's hearing from Sa'id was after confusion, Ibn Rajab quoted in Sharh 'Ilal Al-Tirmidhi (2/745) from Al-Ijli saying: 'Narrated from Ibn Abi Arubah during confusion Yazid bin Harun, Ibn Al-Mubarak, and Ibn Abi Adi, everything narrated from him by such young ones is during confusion'. I say: But this speech from Al-Ijli is cited in Ma'rifat Al-Thiqat (1/394; no. 576) in the biography of Sa'id bin Iyas Al-Jurayri, and I think it is an error in attribution, occurring during arrangement by Al-Subki or Al-Haythami or the one transmitting from them. More upright than it for what we seek is the saying of Imam Ahmad: 'Yahya bin Sa'id used to say: Ibn Abi Adi came to Sa'id bin Abi Arubah at the end; meaning: while he was confused' (Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal: 1/353; no. 671), and via his son Al-Uqayli extracted it from him in Al-Du'afa' (2/467; no. 2117). As for Al-Bukhari's narration from him - despite what passed - from Sa'id in one hadith, perhaps it was authentic to him from other less elevated paths. Ibn Abi Adi was followed in similar to the hadith above in Tafsir Al-Tabari (15/297) from Yazid bin Zuray', from Sa'id, from Qatadah, from Amr Al-Bakali and added - from Amr bin Abdullah -, but this chain is also interrupted, for between Qatadah and Al-Bakali is a man, Abu Ayyub or someone else. Were it not for that, it would have been better, for Yazid bin Zuray' is more correct in Ibn Abi Arubah from Qatadah than others; Ahmad said in his Answers to Abu Dawud (336; no. 492): 'Sa'id bin Abi Arubah used to memorize Tafsir from Qatadah, and if you wrote it from Yazid bin Zuray' from Sa'id, then do not mind not writing it from anyone else' (347; 532).

I say: In none of what passed via Al-Thawri is there any mention of 'Ubaidah' at all. I found a follow-up (Mutaba'ah) for Ibn Abi Layla from Al-Sha'bi, which is the follow-up of 'Al-Haitham', via Abu Hanifa from him, in *Al-Sunan Al-Kubra* (8/140; No: 16187), and *Ma'rifat Al-Sunan wa Al-Athar* (12/108; No: 16056), and *Awali Al-Imam Abu Hanifa* (10; No: 3), and *Al-Arba'un min Hadith Abi Hanifa* (16; No: 3), regarding specifically silver. From the same path with a more complete context in Abu Yusuf's *Al-Athar* (221; No: 980), but in it is the ambiguity of the follower of Ibn Abi Layla by saying 'From whom he narrated'. The sources of this follow-up did not exceed naming 'Al-Haitham', without identifying him or removing the ambiguity, and I found Abu Hanifa narrating from Abu Ghassan Al-Haitham bin Habib Al-Sarraf, and Shu'bah advised Abu Awanah upon his departure to Kufa to stick to him (*Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 3/414; No: 5800), and Imam Ahmad praised him and said: How good are his hadiths, and how strong is their uprightness, unlike what the People of Opinion narrate from him. End quote. And Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy. Abu Hatim and Abu Zur'ah said: Truthful, trustworthy (See: *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/81; No: 327). But Al-Mizzi in *Tahdhib Al-Kamal* (14/32 - 33; No: 3042) and his sources and followers did not mention this - as far as I strived - among those who narrated from Al-Sha'bi according to their habit in attempting to investigate the Sheikhs of the subject and narrators from him, so his being him in reality remains subject to doubt. Then I verified that it is him, praise be to Allah, when I found a weak hadith for him narrating from Al-Sha'bi from Jabir as stopped (Mawquf) in *Lisan Al-Mizan* (2/511; No: 3319), and the calamity in it is from someone below him; meaning: from Zaid bin Nu'aim, who is of unknown status (Majhul Al-Hal). Whatever the case, our intent is what witnesses to the occurrence of Haitham Al-Sarraf's narration from Al-Sha'bi, and it has occurred. The benefit of identification is confirming the follow-up for Ibn Abi Layla from this aspect in not mentioning 'Ubaidah', and prioritizing it, in addition to the narration of Al-Qattan and Sufyan and this one, which in their aggregate are stronger than Waki's narration, and that is why Yahya hesitated in accepting it - even though it falls within his hearings as indicated by the word 'I heard him' - citing the poor memory of Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman as a defect.

I say: His narrators are trustworthy, except that Ibn Artah is Salih Al-Hadith (good in hadith), in the saying of Yahya bin Ma'in (Al-Daqqaq: 76; No: 213), and he sends (Mursal) and obfuscates (Tadlis) (See: *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 424/5), so his solitude is objectionable (Munkar). There is another problem, which is: Is the correction - Ibn Abza catching the Prophet - from his son Sa'id, or is it an appendix by Ibn Abi Khaythama on the chain? Whatever the case, Abd al-Rahman's young age does not harm; because his hadith with 'An' recounts the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in his prayer, which is a repeated action that is easily established in the narrator's memory, unlike a mere saying, for in addition to possibly not being repeated, it requires greater discrimination. I have tracked some of Abd al-Rahman's hadith, and it appeared to me that most of it recounts the actions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in prayer specifically. Of it is what Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi narrated from him - with a chain containing discussion - he said: 'I prayed with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and he used not to complete the Takbir' (*Musnad Al-Tayalisi*: 2/616; No: 1383); and what Abu Nu'aym narrated from him also, he said: 'I attended a funeral with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him ...' (*Ma'rifat Al-Sahabah*: 4/1823; No: 4604), except that its chain contains Muhammad bin Salim Al-Kufi, who is weak ... In addition to the hadith of clasping (Al-Salb) above, and these hadiths as you see are in the Book of Prayer, and I do not think this or what is in its meaning - if its chain is connected - falls into the Mursal of Companions, rather it is a purely connected transfer, and Allah knows best. Yunus bin Habib followed Al-Fallas from Dawud with it in *Al-Sunan Al-Kubra* by Al-Bayhaqi (3/60, No: 3869). And Bahz bin Asad and Khalid followed Abu Dawud from Shu'bah from Salama coupled with Zubaid, in *Sunan Al-Nasa'i* (3/244; No: 1732; 3/245, No: 1733), and Ali bin Al-Ja'd in his *Musnad* (1/86; No: 487), and from his path Abu Nu'aym extracted it in *Al-Hilyah* (7/181). Mansur bin Al-Mu'tamir followed Shu'bah in *Amali Al-Mahamili* from the narration of Ibn Al-Bayya': 1/337; No: 368), from Salama, and he did not mention Dharr. The hadith has a connected chain, and it has various paths.

I say: I reviewed Ibn Al-Kharrat's summary of Al-Rashati's Genealogies (Azhar copy: 188 Z), and I found the speech in it on the clear path; for in it is Abu Khadash, Hibban bin Zaid Al-Shar'abi, narrated from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him.. So is the illusion in the original, and the correction from the summarizer Abdul-Haq; I do not know?. It appears that Ibn Qulayj rejoices in critiques so his guard goes down.

text: and Hafs bin Ghiyath, and suddenly [1] Abu Shaykh [2] Jariyah bin Haram [3] was writing from him; so Hafs began to fabricate hadith for him and say [4]: Did Aisha the daughter [6] of Talha narrate to you [5] from Aisha [such and such] [7]? So he would say: 'Aisha bint Talha narrated to me, from Aisha such and such [8].' Then [9] he [Hafs] says to him [10]: And did Al-Qasim bin Muhammad narrate to you, from Aisha such [11]? So he would say:
foot_note: 1. [1] Al-Asami wal-Kuna; Al-Majruhin; Al-Kamil: 'Wa-idha' (And suddenly). And it occurred in Al-Du'afa (T): 'Wa Abu Shaykh'; meaning that he was with Yahya and Hafs, not meaning that they found him with the Meccan Sheikh; so his statement in the printed version 'So he wrote from him' is not correct, rather it is correct to say: 'Yaktubu 'anhu' (he was writing from him/it was being written from him); which is what occurs in copy (J) of it. [2] In the original: 'Sayh'; misspelling; Tarikh al-Islam: 'Fa-idha huwa Shaykh Jariyah' (And suddenly he is Sheikh Jariyah); distortion. [3] Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Wa Abu Shaykh'. [4] Al-Majruhin: 'Wa-yaqulu' (And he says). [5] Al-Majruhin; Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Haddathatka'. [6] Al-Asami wal-Kuna; Al-Du'afa (J); Al-Majruhin; Al-Kamil; Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Bint'. [7] What is between the brackets is added from Al-Asami wal-Kuna and Al-Du'afa (J) - with the shortened Alif in both places - and Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah, and the lie occurring in Al-Majruhin is one time. [8] 'Wa Kadha' (And such) the second one, is not in Al-Majruhin; Al-Du'afa (J): 'Bi-kadha wa kadha'; and in all its analogues. Al-Baqa'i summarized the report saying: 'Aisha narrated it to me'. [9] Al-Du'afa (J): 'Thumma Yaqulu' (Then he says). [10] The phrase 'Thumma Yaqulu Lahu': Missing from Al-Baqa'i's book. [11] Al-Du'afa (J); Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah similar to it. And the lie is repeated in Al-Hakim's book. _________ = There is no relation between these two narrators, for Abu Al-Hasan Musa bin Dinar is Meccan and weak. And Abu Al-Tayyib Musa bin Yasar is from Marw, lived in Al-Mada'in, so he is not Meccan, then he is after this trustworthy (Thiqah). See: Talkhis al-Mutashabih in Entry: (2/597); and Al-Dhahabi also verified this matter saying: 'Abu Al-Tayyib Musa bin Sayyar has passed, and thus Ibn Abi Hatim named him, and I think this is a misspelling.' Ibn Hajar mentioned in Al-Lisan (8/231; No: 8045) 'Musa bin Yasar Abu Al-Tayyib Al-Makki. From Aisha bint Talha. Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim said he is not strong according to them.' End of his speech; if his source is the book Al-Asami wal-Kuna alone, then he has added a narrator who has no existence except due to misspelling.

text: 'Al-Qasim narrated to me [1], from Aisha [2] [similar to it] [3].' And he [Hafs] says: Did Sa'id bin Jubayr narrate to you, from Ibn [4] Abbas similar to it (1)? So he would say: 'Sa'id bin Jubayr narrated to me, from Ibn [5] Abbas similar to it [6].' When he finished, Hafs struck [7] his hand [8] upon Jariyah's tablets and erased [9] what [10] was in them [11]. He [Jariyah] said: You envy me [12]. So Hafs said to him: No, but this man lies! [13]. I [14] said to Yahya: Who is the man? He did not name him. So I said [15] to him one day [16]: O Abu [17] Sa'id, perhaps I have something from this Sheikh [18], and I do not know him [19]. He said: He is
foot_note:
1. [1] Al-Majruhin: 'Haddathana'. [2] Added in this place in Al-Majruhin: 'Bi-kadha'. [3] Added from Al-Asami wal-Kuna and Al-Du'afa (J) and Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah. [4] (Sad): 'Bin'. [5] (Sad): 'Bin'. [6] 'Bi-mithlihi': Missing from Al-Majruhin. [7] Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Madda' (extended). [8] (Sad; Al-Asami wal-Kuna): 'Yadahu' (his hand), and the correction is from Al-Du'afa (J); Al-Kamil. [9] Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'Mahs'; misspelling. [10] (Sad): 'Mahaha' (erased it). [11] Al-Majruhin; Tarikh al-Islam: 'Fa-mahaha'. [12] In the original: 'Yahsuduni' (they envy me); and added in Al-Du'afa (J) and Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Bihi' (for it). And in Al-Kamil: 'Tahsudunani'. [13] Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'This Sheikh lies'; Al-Majruhin; Al-Kamil: 'Kadhab' (He lied). The phrase is according to what is in our copy in the original of Al-Du'afa (J), were it not that one of the readers changed it to 'Wa lakinnaka takdhibu' (But rather you are lying). [14] In Al-Du'afa (J); Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Qila' (It was said); passively. And here the questioner is identified. [15] Al-Du'afa (J): 'Qultu' (I said). [16] 'Lahu yawman' (to him one day): Missing from Al-Nukat; and its deletion is not permissible even for brevity, for the narration of the original indicates a delay occurred, and the narration of Al-Nukat implies the comment happened immediately. [17] (Sad): 'Ya Baba'. [18] Added in Al-Du'afa (J) and Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah: 'Shay'an' (something). [19] The context of speech in the printed Al-Du'afa is corrupt; in it: 'Perhaps with this Sheikh is something, he said: I know him, he said: He is Musa bin Dinar.' From this, the correctness of what is in the original is known. _________ 
1. The fabrication/lying is more primary in this place.

text: Musa [1] bin Dinar (1). [Ab]u [2] Hafs said: And I have not [3] seen anyone narrate from this Sheikh except two men: Ibn [4] Nudbah (2) and Yusuf [5] Al-Samti (3).
foot_note:
1. [1] 'Bin Dinar': Not in Al-Asami wal-Kuna. [2] What is between the brackets is punctured in the original, and its restoration is from Al-Du'afa. [3] Al-Kamil: 'Fama'. [4] In the original: 'Bin Badabah'. [5] In the copy of Al-Du'afa (J) - which is not in all the printed versions -: 'Bin Musa'; which is undoubtedly an illusion; rather it is Yusuf bin Khalid, and see the comment in the counterpart. And it occurred in the original: 'Al-Sabti'; and in all editions of Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 'Al-Sha'bi', without the investigators addressing it with discussion; and all of that is misspelling, and the transmission is correct in Al-Kamil. And his attribution to good conduct (Husan Al-Samt) is excellent and dust-free in Al-Du'afa itself in copy (J); and in it: 'Ahmad bin Umar told us, he said: I heard 'Amr bin Ali say: Yusuf Al-Samti is a liar'; and his phrase is not in this book of ours, and its proof is the statement of Abu Dawud in his Jawabāt (2/62; No: 1135): 'He used to pray long prayers.' _________ 
1. Al-Fallas transmitted from Hafs bin Ghiyath that he said: Musa bin Dinar lies. From Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 8/142; Bio: 639. And Yahya bin Sa'id said about him: His hadith is wind. (Sahih Muslim: 1/21). 
2. Al-Mu'allimi, may Allah have mercy on him, commented: In Al-Lisan: And 'Amr bin Ali said: 'I have not seen anyone narrate from him except Abu Shu'ayb Al-Taymi and another', thus, and perhaps it is 'Abu Shaykh Al-Fuqaymi'. So verify it. And this Ibn Nudbah is Abu Sa'id Al-Hasan bin Habib bin Nudbah Al-Tamimi Al-Basri; Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim said it in his Kuna: 3/300; No: 1385. 
3. Al-Fallas said: I heard Yusuf Al-Samti say: Muqatil bin Sulayman said in Mecca: Ask me about what is below the Throne. So Qays Al-Qayyas stood up and said: Who shaved Adam's head during his Hajj? So he remained... (Thus; and perhaps it needs completion; like his saying: 'bewildered'. From Tarikh Baghdad: 15/215; Tarikh Dimashq: 60/128). And Ali bin Al-Madini said: Al-Darawardi said to me: Tell Yusuf Al-Samti to fear Allah Almighty and return the book of Musa bin 'Uqbah (Al-Ma'rifah wal-Tarikh: 3/32). The intended one is: Yusuf bin Khalid Al-Samti, and he is him, no one else, and bearing witness to him is that some of his narration you find in Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat (8/26; Hadith No: 7854): Yusuf bin Khalid, from Musa bin

They agreed that I should say [11]: He is not reliable (Thabt) [12], and that I should make his matter clear (2).
foot_note:
1. [1] Kitab Al-Majruhin: 'Al-Sa'id'. [2] (Sad): 'Sufayan'. [3] Added in Kitab Al-Majruhin: 'Bin Al-Hajjaj'. [4] (Sad): 'Wa Malik'. And 'Bin Anas' is not in Sahih Muslim. [5] 'Sufyan': Not in Sahih Muslim. [6] 'Yakunu': Not in Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil. [7] Sahih Muslim; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 'About a man who is not reliable in Hadith'. [8] Kitab Al-Majruhin: 'Ya'tini'. [9] (Sad): 'Yasaluni'. And in Sahih Muslim; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 'Fa-yas'aluni'. [10] Instead of the phrase 'Fa-ya'tini... 'anhu': 'Fa-us'alu 'anhu' (So I am asked about him); in the book of Al-Ramahurmuzi. [12] Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil: 'Thabtan'. _________ = Dinar Al-Makki, from Musa bin Talha, from Aisha bint Sa'd, from Aisha the Mother of the Believers, she said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Let Abu Bakr lead the people in prayer.' Al-Tabarani said following it: 'No one narrated this hadith from Aisha bint Sa'd except Musa bin Talha, nor from Musa except Musa bin Dinar; Yusuf Al-Samti was alone in narrating it.' And Al-Saji said: He was the first to bring [the opinion of] Abu Hanifa to Basra, and he was a man of theological rhetoric (Kalam) in religion. From the transmissions of Ibn Shaqla: 288; No: 405. 
1. Sahih Muslim: 1/17; Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal: 3/154; No: 4685; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 2/24; Kitab Al-Majruhin: 1/20; Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil: 593-594; No: 850. text: 76 - 'Affan (2) narrated to us (1), he said: I was [1] with Ismail bin Ulayyah, and a man narrated [2] from a man a hadith [3], so I said: Do not narrate from this one [4], for he [5] is not reliable (Thabt). So he said [6]: You have backbited him [7]. Ismail [8] said: He did [not] [9] backbite him, but he judged that he is not reliable. 77 - And I heard (3) Yahya [10] mention [11] Abu Bakr Al-Hudhali (4) and he said: He [was] [12]

And in Tarikh Baghdad: 'Meaning: Ibn Sa'id Al-Qattan'. [11] Al-Du'afa: 'Wa dhakara' (And he mentioned). [12] Added from Tarikh Baghdad. _________ = by Al-Juzjani (21-22), and from the path of Ahmad also (Al-Ilal - from the narration of his son - 3/154; No: 4684; and from the narration of Salih: 175; No: 311) and Uthman bin Abi Shaybah and Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Hulwani from him, in Su'alat Abi Dawud li-Ahmad (197); No: (134) all of them mention it from 'Affan, from Yahya bin Sa'id, he said: I asked Sufyan Al-Thawri, Sufyan bin Uyainah, Malik bin Anas, and Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj, about a man who errs in Hadith or lies in it? 1. Al-Tamyiz by Muslim: 178; No: 32; Sahih Muslim: 1/26; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 2/23 - and Ibn Abi Hatim wrote a chapter header on it; and in it: 'Haddathani' (Narrated to me); Kitab Al-Majruhin: 1/18-19; Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil: 594; No: 853. 
2. He is: 'Affan bin Muslim. 
3. Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Al-Hakim: 2/152, No: 538; Al-Du'afa (J): Folio 137a; Tarikh Baghdad: 10/309. See: A brief part of the report joined to two other reports about the same narrator by Al-Fallas in Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/313; Bio: 1365.

text: saying: 'Abu Abd al-Rahman Al-Sulami narrated to us'; I have not seen anyone in Kufa [1] narrating from Abu Abd al-Rahman [2]!, and he did not approve of him (1). 78 - I heard (2) Yahya say: I did not see anyone in Basra narrate from Abu Qilabah (3) except word for word and the slight [3] thing (4).
foot_note:
1. [1] 'Ahadan' (Anyone): Missing from the printed Al-Asami wal-Kuna. [2] 'Al-Sulami' added in Al-Du'afa. And this is establishing a basis for Yahya's judgment, so the criticism (Jarh) is explained. [3] 'Al-Yasir' (The slight): Not in Al-Tarikh. _________ = Shu'bah was mentioned, so he said: Let me be, so I do not vomit (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 1/143; 4/313; No: 1365; Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 3/39; No: 2460; Al-Kamil: 5/360; No: 8033). Ghundar: He was not trustworthy (Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 3/40; No: 2462). And he also said: He was a great liar (Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 3/41; No: 2466). Yahya bin Ma'in: He is nothing (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/313; No: 1365). Al-Bukhari: Not a Hafiz (preserver) according to them (Du'afa'uhu: 73; No: 162). Abu Zur'ah: A weak Basran (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/314; No: 1365). Abu Hatim: Not strong, lenient in Hadith; his hadith is written but not used as proof (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/313; No: 1365). Al-Nasa'i: Abandoned in Hadith (Du'afa'uhu: 183; No: 233). 
1. From his rejected reports (Manakir) is what Ibn Shaqla cited in his margins (126; No: 143): 'Abu Bakr - meaning: Al-Hudhali - narrated, from Muhammad bin Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, granted dispensation regarding poetry of the Days of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah) except the poem of Umayyah bin Abi Al-Salt, and the poem of Al-A'sha mentioning 'Amir and 'Alqamah.' 
2. Tarikh 'Amr bin Ali Al-Fallas (357), with the wording: 'I did not meet anyone in Basra'. 
3. Abdullah bin Zaid, a Basran Tabi'i (Tarikh Al-Fallas: 338). Al-Fallas counted him in his Tarikh (544) among those who narrated from Ibn Abbas from the people of Basra, then he said: 'And according to us he has no hearing [from him].' The Group (Al-Jama'ah) narrated from him. Abu Hatim was asked: Is Abu Qilabah from Mu'adh more beloved to you or Qatadah from Mu'adh? He said: Both are trustworthy (Al-Ta'dil wal-Tajrih by Al-Baji: 2/914; No: 800). And Hammad bin Zaid said: I heard Ayyub - that is: Al-Sakhtiyani - mention Abu Qilabah, so he said: By Allah, he was of the jurists possessing intellects (Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir: 9/182; No: 10090). He died in the Levant (Sham) (Su'alat Abi Dawud: 192; No: 114). See regarding the claim of his Mursal narrations and its discussion: Al-Marasil by Ibn Abi Hatim: 109-110; No: 173; Jami' al-Tahsil by Al-Ala'i: 112; No: 68; Tuhfat al-Tahsil by Abu Zur'ah Al-Iraqi: 176-177. 
4. The reason for the scarcity of narration from him is not what the weakness of a narrator necessitates such that students avoid him =

text: 79 - And I heard Yahya and Mu'adh [1] say: [The Jinn] [2] to the last of them are the offspring of Iblis; and for them is reward, and upon them is punishment (1). 80 - And I heard Yahya say: One does not perform Qunut (supplication) in the Fajr prayer, but if he performs Qunut, he recites aloud (2). 81 - And I heard (3) Yahya say: 'Ismail [3] narrated to us, he said [4]:
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Wa Mu'adh'. [2] Appended in the left margin. [3] Added in Kitab Al-Hakim: 'Meaning: Ibn Abi Khalid'; and in Tarikh Dimashq: 'Bin Abi Khalid'. [4] 'Qala': Not with Ibn Asakir. _________ = nor the paucity of his hadith, for we have presented that he is a trustworthy jurist, and Ibn Sa'd added: 'He was trustworthy, possessing much Hadith' (Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir: 9/182; No: 3886), and there is no contradiction between this statement and the story of Al-Fallas, so the meaning comes down to the man being difficult for those taking from him, or that due to his verification he had much Hadith but little narration; Imam Ahmad narrated saying: 'Abu Qilabah came to Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. So he said to him: Narrate, O Abu Qilabah. He said: By Allah, indeed I dislike much of Hadith, and much of silence' (Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal: 2/211; No: 2045), and more explicit than it for what we seek is the statement of Khalid Al-Hadhdha': 'We used to come to Abu Qilabah, so if he narrated three hadiths to us he said: I have done much' (Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir: 9/184; No: 10102). 
1. The first half of the speech without its remainder is also attributed to Al-Hasan; as in Tafsir Yahya bin Salam (1/344) and its abridgment by Ibn Abi Zamanin (4/327). 
2. This is the school (Madhhab) of Sufyan Al-Thawri, and in another narration from him: 'If he prays behind one who performs Qunut, he remains silent.' See: Al-Istidhkar by Ibn Abd al-Barr (6/201). It appears that Sufyan and his follower Yahya acted contrary to their narration, for in Sunan Al-Nasa'i Al-Kubra (1/339; No: 667): 'Amr bin Ali informed us, he said: Yahya narrated to us, from Shu'bah and Sufyan, they said: 'Amr bin Murrah narrated to us, from Ibn Abi Layla, from Al-Bara' bin 'Azib, that the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to perform Qunut in Fajr and Maghrib.' See: Tahdhib al-Athar: 1/366. 
3. Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim: 3/218-219; No: 1267; Tarikh Dimashq: 40/45-40; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 21/357; Bio: 4240; Tahdhib al-Tahdhib: 7/451. Yahya refrained from narrating from him, indicated by a story Al-Fallas also cited; and it is in =

text: Al-Ayzar bin Hurayth narrated to us, from Umar bin Sa'd (1). So a man from Banu Dubai'ah [1] called: 'Abu [2] (Musa) said to him: O Abu [3] Sa'id, this is the killer of Al-Husayn!. So he remained silent. Then he said: 'From the killer of Al-Husayn you narrate to us?', so Yahya remained silent [4]. 82 - And I heard (2) Yahya [5] say: I saw Al-Mas'udi (3) in the year
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Subay'ah' misspelling; Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'Dub'ah'; misspelling. [2] 'Abu': Missing from all sources of extraction, and what is in the original is more appropriate; because if he did not intend the Kunya he would have said 'Yusamma' (named). [3] (Sad): 'Yaba'. So a man stood up to him and said: Do you not fear Allah? You narrate from Umar bin Sa'd. So he wept and said: I will not return to narrating from him ever.' 
1. Ibn Abi Khaythamah said in his Tarikh (Volume Two: 2/645; No: 4033): I said to Yahya bin Ma'in: Is he trustworthy? He said: How can one who killed Al-Husayn be trustworthy?! And with Abu Bakr's chain also (646/2; No: 4034) to Abdullah bin Sharik, he said: I caught the people of marked cloaks and the people of hooded cloaks from the people of the pillars (worshipers), when Umar bin Sa'd passed by them they said: This is the killer of Al-Husayn; and that was before he killed him. 
2. Al-Majruhin: 2/48; Al-Du'afa (J): Folio 191b; Tarikh Baghdad: 11/480; Tarikh Dimashq: 21/35. 
3. He is: Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Utbah bin Mas'ud Al-Mas'udi Al-Kufi. Abu Zur'ah: His hadiths from other than Al-Qasim and 'Awn are disturbed, he errs much (Su'alat Al-Bardha'i: 151; No: 199). Yahya bin Ma'in: Trustworthy, but he used to err if he narrated from Asim and Salamah bin Kuhayl. And his hadith was correct [narrated] from Al-Qasim, and Ma'n bin Abd al-Rahman (His Tarikh from the narration of Al-Duri: 3/333; No: 1607). And he said: His hadiths from Al-A'mash are inverted and from Abd al-Malik bin Umayr also. And his hadith... from Abu Hasin and Asim is nothing (His Tarikh from the narration of Al-Duri: 3/429; No: 2105). And he said: Whoever heard from Al-Mas'udi in the time of Abu Ja'far then it is correct hearing, and whoever heard from him in the time of Al-Mahdi then his hearing is nothing (Tarikh Baghdad: 11/480; No: 5308). text: Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi [2] saw him [1], so I did not speak to him (1).
foot_note:

Al-Uqayli: He changed in the end of his life, there is disturbance in his hadith (Du'afa'uhu: 3/409). Ibn Hibban: Al-Mas'udi was truthful (Saduq) except that he became mixed up in the end of his life, a severe mixing up until his mind went. And he used to narrate what came to him, so he was carried [along], thus his old hadith mixed with his recent hadith, and it could not be distinguished, so he deserved abandonment (Al-Majruhin: 2/48; and Ibn al-Qattan inclined to this in Bayan al-Wahm wal-Iham: 4/176). And it is not permissible to discard all his hadith due to the claim of disturbance, but it should be tested and looked into; if it is distinguished by his time or place or his narrators, [it is accepted], otherwise it is weak. 
1. And with Al-Uqayli's chain to Ali bin Al-Madini from a long report: 'Yahya bin Sa'id said, and he was next to Mu'adh, and that was in Safar year one hundred ninety: The last I met Al-Mas'udi was the year forty-seven, or forty-eight, then I met him in Mecca the year fifty-eight, and Abdullah bin Uthman was with me that year, and Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi. Yahya said: And I did not ask him about anything' (Al-Du'afa: 3/411; No: 3274). I say: It appears from this report the specification of the year which was ambiguous in the text and that it is year 58, and Al-Mas'udi was then mixed up completely. The summary of combining between this report of Al-Fallas and the two that follow after an intervening report: - Year 53: Al-Mas'udi was correct/healthy, written from, Abu Qutaybah wrote from him. And Yahya Al-Qattan wrote from him before that in year 48 AH. - Year 54: His memory changed so he looked into the book, but Mu'adh met him this year in Baghdad, and did not deny anything from him, so perhaps that was the beginning of his mixing up without it overwhelming him, then everyone who heard from him was in Baghdad, so [it was] during the state of his mixing up. - Year 57 and after: He mixed up completely. Among those who wrote from him then was Abu Dawud. And Yahya and Ibn Mahdi met him in Mecca in the year that followed it so Al-Qattan did not ask him. So every story about the signs of his mixing up refers to this year and what is above it, so if it is correct that he died in year 160 AH, it is known that the duration of his mixing up was between two and three years, no more.

And Al-Hasan was the oldest of them, and Ammar was among the Weepers (Bakka'in).' I say: And the reason for specifying Sa'id without the other, even though Al-Hasan is older than both of them, is that Ammar - as it appears to me and Allah knows best - has very little narration, so for that Ali Ibn Al-Madini did not mention him in the naming of those narrated from among the children of the ten (119; No: 81), and he mentioned his two brothers. As for Sa'id, Ibn Sa'd wrote a biography for him in Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra (9/178; Bio: 3884) and described him with narration saying: 'He was younger than Al-Hasan, and he narrated, and it was narrated from him.' And he also has a biography in Al-Hidayah wal-Irshad: 1/297-298; Bio: 411; Al-Ta'dil wal-Tajrih: 3/1239; Bio: 1292. As for Ammar, his biography is rare; yes, Al-Muqaddami mentioned him - by his bare name - in his Tarikh (88; No: 692), but I have not found for him except one hadith with his chain without its text, narrated by Al-Dinawari in Al-Mujalasah (6/334; No: 2728) he said: 'Ahmad narrated to us, Ibrahim bin Fahd narrated to us, Muhammad bin Kathir narrated to us, Hammad bin Salamah narrated to us, from Thabit, from Ammar bin Abi Al-Hasan a hadith he narrated; he said: And he was of the Weepers.' And the chain after this is weak due to the weakness of Abu Ishaq Ibrahim bin Fahd Al-Basri, Ibn Adi said (2/38): The rest of his hadiths are rejected (Manakir), and he is of dark/obscure matter.

And see: Models of his narration from his father in Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah: 3/73 No: 3126; 3/317; No: 3955; 17/419; 33360. And the thought regarding Ibn Abi Khaythamah in his Tarikh (Volume Three: 3/16; No: 3657) is that he cited the report mostly following Al-Fallas in the biography of Al-Hulb the father, according to what remains of it, as the place is deprived. And Hulb is a nickname/title, and his name is Yazid bin Qunafah (Tabaqat Khalifah: 69; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 9/284; No: 1199). Ibn Abd al-Barr said in Al-Isti'ab (4/2710): 'He came as a delegation to the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, while he was bald, so he wiped over his head and his hair grew.' I say: So perhaps this is the reason for the nickname, indicated by the saying of Ibn Duraid in Al-Ishtiqaq (482): 'And Al-Hulb: Hair. And Al-Hulbah: A lock of hair. And it is said of the hair of the foal's tail when it first appears: Hulb.' Ibn Kathir said in Al-Takmil (4/133): And the People of Hadith say: 'Hulb', and some of them said: The correct is 'Hulab'. 
3. The author cited him in his Tarikh (474), among those who narrated from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, from Banu Layth bin Bakr.

End quote. I say: Al-Bukhari's citing of a defect specifically for this hadith is apparent, but some critics applied the ruling of his phrase 'he is not followed in his hadith' absolutely, such that it includes this mentioned one and others, and it appears it is so. For an induction of the usage of this phrase by the Imam - may Allah grant him the Abode of Stability out of His bounty - indicates that he is very cautious in restriction, and decisive in the return of the pronoun. However, the point of confusion is that he brought an example and followed it with an absolute judgment. His habit is that if he cites an example, he restricts the judgment to it, but if he uses the phrase absolutely without an example, it covers all the narrator's hadith, and this is clear. His habit is to say in restriction: He is not followed in *this*; he is not followed in his hadith from *so-and-so*; he is not followed *on it*; he is not followed in *this hadith*; and *this is a hadith* on which he is not followed; it is not authentic in my view and he is not followed *on it* ... among other phrases. So if he says 'He is not followed in his hadith', it is a judgment =

I say: Al-Tabarani said in the course of a chain in *Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat* (5/215; No: 5124) 'from Abu Madinah Al-Darimi, and he had companionship (Suhbah)', but the critics rejected it. This report is relied upon from its context in counting the Companions, like Ibn Al-Athir in *Al-Asad* (3/110; No: 2896), and his source in it is Abu Musa Al-Madini; that is why Al-Dhahabi said in *Al-Tarikh* (2/1208; No: 278): 'It was said: He has companionship, but it is not correct.' text: Yahya used not to narrate to us from Al-Walid bin Jami' (1), but when it was shortly before his death,
foot_note:

1. He is: Al-Walid bin Abdullah bin Jami' Al-Zuhri, from themselves [not a client]; Al-Fallas stated this in the chapter mentioning the people of Kufa in his history (436), and Ibn Zanjawiyah also mentioned him among the scholars of Kufa in his *Tabaqat* (79; my investigation). Yahya bin Ma'in said in *Ma'rifat Al-Rijal* from the narration of Ibn Muhriz (143; No: 403): Trustworthy, he is Zuhri, trusted, pleasing. And he said in *Al-Tarikh* from the narration of Al-Duri (1/221; No: 838): Trustworthy. Ahmad was asked about him and said: I know nothing but good (*Masa'il Harb bin Isma'il Al-Kirmani*; Last Section: 1269/3; No: 2165). And he said once: There is no harm in him (*Su'alat Abi Dawud*: 303; No: 378; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/8; No: 34). Likewise said Abu Zur'ah regarding him (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/8; No: 34) and Abu Dawud in *Su'alat Al-Ajurri* (1/155; No: 21). Abu Hatim said: Salih Al-Hadith (Good in Hadith) (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/8; No: 34). Ibn Sa'd declared him trustworthy (*Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir*: 8/473; No: 3395) and Al-Ajli (*Ma'rifat Al-Thiqat*: 2/342; No: 1943). The sum of Ibn Abi Hatim's words in his biography (9/8; No: 34) leads to the prevalence of his documentation over his weakening and its preponderance, as he did not cite a cause for disparagement in it. He has two hadiths in *Sahih Muslim* (3/1414; No: 1787; 4/2144; No: 2779), and one hadith in *Al-Adab Al-Mufrad* by Al-Bukhari (195; No: 555). Neither Al-Uqayli (6/221; No: 1925) nor Ibn Adi (10/267; No: 17410), despite their great celebration in collecting [weak narrators], found a foothold for his weakness from the words of the Imams other than this statement of Amr bin Ali alone, although they quoted it in full so they are absolved of liability; then Al-Uqayli added saying: 'There is disturbance (Idtirab) in his hadith.' If we do not consider Amr's statement brought by them - which is the cornerstone - and remove it, their quiver is empty of the best arrows. It is strange that Ibn Hibban lists him in *Al-Thiqat*, then says in *Al-Majruhin* (3/78 - 79): 'He was among those who were solitary from the firm narrators with what does not resemble the hadith of the trustworthy; so when that became excessive from him, arguing by him became invalid.' Al-Busti [Ibn Hibban] also made the truncated statement of Amr a support for his judgment. As for Al-Hakim, he said in *Al-Madkhal* (4/106 - 107): '[Muslim] narrated from him, from Abu Al-Tufail, from Hudhaifah, the hadith of his father in the Book of Jihad. He narrated from him in another place in the book as corroboration, and if he had not mentioned him it would have been more appropriate. For they narrated to us from Amr bin Ali, who said: Yahya bin Sa'id used not to narrate from Al-Walid bin Jami'. However, Muslim followed his condition in corroborating with lenient narrators if the origin was presented via a firm trustworthy narrator.' I say: As for Amr's statement regarding Al-Walid, I do not think it was hidden from Muslim, who is his student, and if it was hidden

foot_note:

[1] Thus in the original, and in *Al-Du'afa* and *Al-Kamil*: 'I took them'; and I see, and Allah knows best, that the narration of the original is more correct; because it conveys an additional meaning not conveyed by the other. Its explanation: If Al-Fallas had verified Yahya's refusal to narrate from Al-Walid, then brought him his hadiths to make him hear them, that would be pushing his Sheikh away from his stance and duping him, and closest to detested prompting (Talqin), and that would not be hidden from the Sheikh, nor would the student dare to fall into such a prohibition. So the most likely is that it appeared to Yahya what inclined his opinion towards acceptance, so he took the hadiths that were previously discarded by him, and his student narrated them, and Allah knows best. [2] (Saad): 'Al-Hammal' _________ = from him even, inference by it has become irrelevant like yesterday; because Yahya retracted his abandonment, and narrated from him a hadith of hearing (Sama'), not a hadith of negotiation (Mudhakarah). Arguing by it for negligence is exactly like arguing by it for action. So rejecting his position at the end without evidence is stubbornness; because it takes the status of the abrogator over the abrogated. Al-Hakim repeated his statement relying on Amr's words also without completing them (4/158). The agreement of the strict critics in wounding him based on Amr's statement weakens their argument as passed, so it remains that the man is neither clearly weak nor a famous trustworthy narrator, but he is upright between that, and this is most similar to the condition of corroboration by him according to Muslim bin Al-Hajjaj, may Allah have mercy on him, and Allah knows best. Ibn Hazm - may Allah forgive him - ventured in *Al-Muhalla* (11/224) saying he is: 'Destroyed' (Halik), and added in his *Ihkam* (5/607) going further: 'Fallen, discarded.' I say: We have not known Muslim to establish hadiths in whose chains are destroyed people, and receiving Ibn Hazm's speech regarding narrators requires extra caution.

'He did not hear anything from Anas'; Abu Hatim said this in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil* (2/80; No: 1732), and added: 'He is Salih Al-Hadith (Good in Hadith), there is no harm in him, Abu Nu'aym narrated to us from him' (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 44/7; No: 246). Yahya Al-Qattan narrated from him with dislike, so he narrated from him from Zaid bin Wahb' (*Thiqat Ibn Qutlubugha*: 7/121; No: 7754). Al-Bukhari cited a defect in *Al-Awsat* (3/555, No: 839) for the hadith which Yahya Al-Qattan rejected due to its contradiction to the famous Sahih from Ibn Umar, so he said: 'Isma'il told us, he said: Malik told me, from Nafi', from Ibn Umar, he said: The cow, the camel, and the sheep are not slaughtered except for one person. Then Al-Ju'fi added: And this is more correct than that.' I say: Al-Bukhari meant the apparent correctness of the chain, not the correctness of the ruling, for the non-sufficiency of the cow and the like for seven is among what Ibn Umar was contradicted in and retracted or paused upon. So if it is based on the correctness of the text - and that is far-fetched - then citing a defect in the hadith due to that is invalid; because it is founded on a ruling which Ibn Umar hesitated in and was contradicted. See the detail of his disagreement in *Al-Muhalla* by Ibn Hazm: 7/381 - 382. Perhaps Yahya, when he verified that the ruling of sufficiency for seven is reported and famous from various outlets and paths, found no escape from returning to narrate from Arif after refusing, due to the presence of witnesses corroborating this hadith of his.

See the critics' words on him in *Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir*: 8/45; No: 2411; *Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 1/402; No: 825; *Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythama*: Volume Three: 1/240; No: 790; *Al-Ma'rifah wa Al-Tarikh*: 2/24; *Du'afa Al-Uqayli*: 6/256; No: 6351; *Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir*: 8/45; No: 2411; *Al-Kamil*: 10/339; No: 17640; 10/340; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/54; No: 228; *Ilal Ahmad*: 3/30; No: 4024; 1/401; No: 824; 1/385; No: 752; *Ma'rifat Al-Thiqat*: 2/327; No: 1896; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/54; No: 228; *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 12/138; No: 4941; *Al-Thiqat*: 5/567; No: 11503. The benefit of the report - if authentic, given the place of 'claimed' in Ali's phrase - is that his disturbance is incidental after rectitude, so he is subject to review, not like one weak from the beginning who is discarded. It is gathered from what passed that the narrator's weakness is not of that severity, and that is why he is on the degree of approaching trustworthiness but not reaching it; Ali bin Al-Madini said: 'Yahya bin Sa'id mentioned: Amr bin Muslim, the owner of Tawus's hadith, so he moved his hand and said: I do not see Hisham bin Hujayr except as better than him.' Even though Amr's condition is close to Hisham's condition. And he added: I said to him: Should I strike out the hadith of Hisham bin Hujayr? He said: Yes.' This opinion of Al-Qattan - despite his abstaining from narrating from him - aligns with Ahmad's opinion that he is not strong and not extremely weak; so he is 'average' (Wasat) according to the expression of the Sheikh of the Craft Ali bin =

Muhammad bin Hisham Al-Mu'assim came and with him was Al-Zuhri and a group other than him, so Ibn Uyainah heard from them except Sulaiman bin Musa, so Ibn Jurayj discussed with him: From whom did you hear?, until he said: Did you hear from the tall blue-eyed one? That is Sulaiman bin Musa. Ibn Uyainah said: So I wanted to go out to seek him, but it was said: He left days ago (abbreviated from *Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat*: 3/266; No: 424). Ahmad with his chain from Ibn Jurayj, said: Sulaiman bin Musa was, and was; praising him (*Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 2/564; No: 3667). Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz Al-Tanukhi Al-Dimashqi addressed Abu Mushir saying: I have not seen anyone with better questioning than you after Sulaiman bin Musa (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 1/287). Ibn Sa'd: He was trustworthy, Ibn Jurayj praised him (*Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir*: 9/460; No: 4693). Al-Darimi: I said to Yahya bin Ma'in: What is the condition of Sulaiman bin Musa regarding Al-Zuhri? He said: Trustworthy (*Tarikhuhu* via Al-Darimi: 46; No: 26; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 4/141; No: 615; *Asma Shuyukh Malik bin Anas*: 206). Ali bin Al-Madini: Sulaiman bin Musa is criticized (Mat'un fihi) (*Du'afa Al-Uqayli*: 2/536; No: 2260). And it occurred in *Du'afa Al-Bukhari* (from the narration of Musabbih bin Sa'id: 5 - F): 'Sulaiman was - meaning: Ibn Al-Fadl - and he had Manakir (objectionable reports).' He attributed it in *Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat* (3/225; No: 360) to Ibn Jurayj. And it appeared in the printed *Al-Du'afa* (69; No: 149): 'Ibn Jurayj said: And Sulaiman used to praise him.' I say: Attributing to Ibn Jurayj is undeniable, but attributing the aforementioned speech to him is the strangest misspelling, and for that reason, all sources were confused in transmitting it, and those who suspected the transmission added and estimated, without removing the anxiety of the text. The correct phrasing is what occurred in the copies of *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir* as a single saying (4/39; No: 1888): 'Sulaiman used to give Fatwa on Al-Adal (complex issues/constraints), and he had Manakir.' Al-Adal is the plural of 'Adalah' (muscle) and 'Mu'dilah' (dilemma); which is a sound meaning, indicating that the man is a jurist capable in new issues. How excellent is Imam Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, for he coupled his judgment on him regarding containing narrations of Manakir, with a phrase suggesting the source of his weakness, which is his saying: 'He used to give Fatwa on Al-Adal', meaning that he is a jurist dominated by the language of jurists, so he conveys the meanings of Hadith with their wordings, and that is what Ibn Rajab, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified in *Sharh Al-Ilal* (1/424) when he said: 'And likewise Sulaiman bin Musa Al-Dimashqi the Jurist; he narrates hadiths with strange wordings'; he said it =

Abu Hatim said: His place is truthfulness (Sidq), and there is some disturbance in his hadith, and I do not know anyone from the companions of Makhul more knowledgeable in Fiqh than him nor more firm than him (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 4/142; No: 615. See also: 4/141, No: 615; 9/297; No: 1262). I say: It is among the fairest of opinions. Al-Nasa'i: One of the jurists, not strong in Hadith (*Al-Du'afa wa Al-Matrukun*: 186; No: 252) - he declared him acceptable (Mashshahu) -. Ibn Adi: A jurist narrator, trustworthy people narrated from him, and he is one of the scholars of the people of Sham, and he narrated hadiths in which he was solitary and no one else narrates them, and in my view he is firm and truthful (*Al-Kamil*: 5/241). Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim: There are some Manakir in his hadith (*Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*: 1/289; No: 180). Abu Nu'aym: The most truthful truthful one, the most skillful jurist, Sulaiman bin Musa Al-Ashdaq (*Hilyat Al-Awliya*: 6/87). Ibn Hazm: Sulaiman is the jurist of the people of Sham, he caught the senior Tabi'in (*Al-Muhalla*: 7/324). Ibn Abd al-Barr: 'Most scholars of knowledge authenticate his hadith, because he is an Imam among the Imams of the people of Sham, and a jurist among their great jurists' (*Al-Istidhkar*: 14/154; No: 19803). As for citing a defect in some of his hadith narrated from Al-Zuhri due to the latter not knowing him, it does not necessitate removing trustworthiness from him; due to the possibility of Al-Zuhri forgetting, and that has happened to those higher than him. Al-Hakim said in *Al-Mustadrak* (2/182; No: 2709): 'The hearing of narrators from each other has been authenticated and established by the narrations of the firm Imams, so these narrations are not defected by the hadith of Ibn Ulayyah and his questioning of Ibn Jurayj about him and his saying: "I asked Al-Zuhri about him and he did not know him"; for a trustworthy Hafiz may forget after having narrated it, and more than one of the Hafizs of Hadith have done so.' 1. *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 14/464; *Tarikh Al-Islam*: 5/339; No: 198; both up to his saying: 'nor anyone else'. 
2. In *Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat* (4/939; No: 1506): 'Amr bin Ali told me, he said: Husayn bin Hafs Abu Muhammad Al-Hamdani Al-Asbahani died in the year ten or eleven.' 
3. See: Two reports with this meaning from Ibn Shubrumah also in *Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythama* (A piece from the Kufans): 189 - 190; No: 476 - 477.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 117 - And I heard (1) Ibrahim bin Ar'arah (2) say to Yahya: [Affan] told us, from Hammam (3), from Qatadah [1], so he said: Be silent, woe to you! (4).
foot_note:
1. [1] 'From Qatadah': Not in Al-Dhahabi's book. _________ 
1. *Tarikh Al-Islam*: 4/534; No: 419; *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 392 A, and an omission occurred in this copy, we rectified it from the printed version; *Al-Kamil*: 10/381; No: 17763; and immediately after it, from Amr's words also: 'And the firm ones among Qatadah's companions are: Ibn Abi Arubah, Hisham, Shu'bah, and Hammam is the fourth of the people in my view.' 
2. Ibrahim bin Ar'arah bin Al-Barand Al-Sami, Abu Ishaq, a great trustworthy Hafiz, agreed upon, extracted in the Two Sahihs; Al-Khalili said this in *Al-Irshad* (2/591; No: 298). Abu Hatim said: Truthful (Saduq) (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 2/130; No: 409). Ibn Abi Hatim said: My father and Abu Zur'ah wrote from him, and narrated from him (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 2/130; No: 409). Imam Ahmad had a bad opinion of him (See: *Tarikh Baghdad*: 7/75 - 78; No: 3139). 
3. He is: Hammam bin Yahya bin Dinar Al-Awadhi. 
4. Al-Fallas said (*Al-Kamil*: 5/385; 7/131; *Tarikh Al-Islam*: 5/398; No: 273): 'Yahya bin Sa'id told us, Shu'bah and Hisham told us, from Qatadah, from Jabir bin Zaid, from Ibn Abbas: - Shu'bah raised it (to the Prophet) - he said: 'The dog, the donkey, and the woman cut (interrupt) the prayer.' Abu Hafs said: So Affan said to him: Hammam told us, from Qatadah, from Salih Abu Al-Khalil, from Jabir bin Zaid, from Ibn Abbas. He said: So Yahya wept! And said: You have become bold against me ... my companions Khalid bin Al-Harth and Mu'adh bin Mu'adh are gone.' This report must be combined with a coming report under number 297, and see: The comment on it is necessary. I say: I think the story is evidence of Yahya's bad opinion of Hammam, Al-Muqaddami said in his history (202; No: 1000): 'My father told me, he said: I heard Ali say - and he mentioned Qatadah's companions - he said: Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i was the most withdrawn from him. Sa'id was the most knowledgeable of them about him. Shu'bah was the most knowledgeable of them about what he heard and what he didn't hear. Ali said: And Hammam in my view was not less than the people in Qatadah, but Yahya did not have a [good] opinion of him, while Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi had a good opinion of him.' Indeed, Ibn Abi Khaythama quotes Ibn Mahdi saying: 'Yahya bin Sa'id wronged Hammam bin Yahya, he did not have knowledge of him, nor did he sit with him, yet he attacked him' (*Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 12/167; No: 4967). A group declared him trustworthy, and those who spoke against him spoke regarding his memory, but his book is good (Salih). See: Detailed sayings about him in *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed

text: 118 - And I heard (1) a man narrating to Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi [from] Yahya bin Sa'id, from Ubaid Allah [1], from Nafi', that Ibn [2] Umar [3] used to return [the greeting] just as [4] it was greeted to him; so Abd al-Rahman rejected it and said: This is only the hadith of Abu Ja'far Al-Qari (2). So I mentioned it to Yahya and he narrated it to me. Then I saw Yahya, and behind me [5] was Abd al-Rahman bin [6] Mahdi [7] in the Congregational Mosque on Friday [8], so he said: You rejected the hadith of Nafi'?! You asked me about it thirty years ago. So Abd al-Rahman remained silent. 119 - Yahya told us (3), from Muhammad bin Mahran (4),.
foot_note:
1. [1] 'From Ubaid Allah': Missing from *Al-Kamil*. [2] (Saad): 'Bin'. [3] *Al-Kamil*: 'Abdullah'. [4] In *Al-Kamil*: 'Kullama' (Whenever); and it is incorrect. [5] In *Al-Kamil*: 'Wa ra'ani' (And he saw me). [6] (Saad): 'Ibn'. [7] Without 'Abd al-Rahman' in *Al-Kamil*. [8] In *Al-Kamil*: 'In the Jami' (Mosque) he said'. _________ 
1. *Al-Kamil*: 1/262; No: 567. 
2. He is: Yazid bin Al-Qa'qa' Abu Ja'far Al-Qari Al-Madini. See: *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*: 8/353 - 354; No: 3307; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/285; No: 1207. 
3. *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 349 B; *Al-Kamil*: 243/6. The report is fabricated and reformulated in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil* in two places (1/260; 8/78; No: 325); except that in it the specific Rak'ah is the second - and likewise it occurred in *Al-Kamil* - but it is not so in the original, for in it is the third, and this aligns with what is in Al-Uqayli's book. 
4. Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim said in his *Kuna* (3/52; No: 1018): Abu Ja'far, and it is said: Abu Ibrahim Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Muslim bin Mahran Al-Qurashi Al-Mu'adhdhin Al-Kufi. And it is said: Ibn Muslim bin Mahran. And it is said: Ibn Al-Muthanna. And it is said: Ibn Abi Al-Muthanna. And the Kunya of Muslim is: Abu Al-Muthanna. Al-Fallas said about him: Muhammad bin Mahran, his Kunya is Abu Al-Muthanna, Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi narrated objectionable (Munkar) hadiths from him regarding the Siwak and other things. (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/78; No: 325). Al-Duri, from Ibn Ma'in: There is no harm in him (*Tarikhuhu*: 4/109, No: 3405). Al-Kawsaj, from Ibn Ma'in: Trustworthy (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/78; No: 325; *Abu Hatim Al-Razi wa Juhuduhu*: 4/225; No: 823). Al-Bukhari did not mention disparagement or praise regarding him (*Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*: 1/23 - 24; No: 20). Abu Hatim: His hadith is written (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/78; No: 325). Abu Zur'ah: Flimsy (Wahi) in Hadith (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/78; No: 325). Ibn Hibban: =

text: from his grandfather (1), that Ibn Umar used to recite in Witr in the third Rak'ah {Say [1], I seek refuge in the Lord of Daybreak} [Al-Falaq: 1] and {Say, I seek refuge in the Lord of Mankind} [Al-Nas: 1]; I mentioned [2] this [3] to Abd al-Rahman so he rejected it, and did not approve of the Sheikh. 120 - And I asked (2) Yahya about the hadith of Mujalid (3), from Al-Sha'bi, that Umar, Ali, Shurayh, and Masruq said: No marriage except with a guardian (Wali). So he refused [4] to narrate it to me [5]. And he said: Abd al-Rahman forbade me from it. So I said to him: 'But Abd al-Rahman narrated to us [6] from Hushaim [7], from Mujalid, from Al-Sha'bi'; so he started to wonder! (4). 121 - And I heard Yahya not prioritize anyone over Mansur among the companions of Ibrahim (5).
foot_note:

[6] *Al-Du'afa*; *Al-Kamil*: 'Haddathana bihi'. [7] (Saad): 'Hasim'. And in *Al-Du'afa*: 'Hisham', which is a distortion, only Hushaim narrates from Mujalid. _________ = He used to err regarding trustworthy narrators: 371/7; No: (10487). Ibn Adi: He has but little Hadith, and the amount of Hadith he has does not clarify his truth from his falsehood (*Al-Kamil*: 9/326; No: 15452). Al-Barqani in his *Su'alat* (62; No: 457): 'I said to Al-Daraqutni: Muhammad bin Muslim bin Mahran bin Al-Muthanna?. He said: Basran, narrating from his grandfather; there is no harm in either of them.' Al-Jawzaqani: Kufan, trustworthy (*Al-Abatil wa Al-Manakir*: 2/17; No: 389). 
1. Al-Fallas mentioned him in his history (558) when naming those who narrated from Ibn Abbas from the people of Kufa. 
2. *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 368 B; *Al-Kamil*: 6/422. The report with slight variation is in *Al-Sunan Al-Kubra* by Al-Bayhaqi: 7/180; No: 13642. 
3. Mujalid bin Sa'id Al-Hamdani, discussion about him has passed sufficiently. 
4. Either Ibn Mahdi narrated to Al-Fallas before the prohibition, or he retracted his abstention regarding this specific hadith, due to the presence of a follower (Mutabi') for Mujalid, for he is weak and what he is solitary in is not used as proof, and he used to accept prompting (Talqin) at the end - as indicated by a previous report of the author - not to mention that Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from him from Al-Sha'bi and Qays bin Abi Hazim as in Al-Bukhari. The critics' words about him have been presented, so look where it passed. 
5. This was the opinion of many critics, like Ali bin Al-Madini, for he said: 'The most firm of people regarding Ibrahim are: =

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 122 - I heard Abu Dawud say: I heard Ubaid Allah bin Al-Hasan (1) say: The divorce of the drunkard is not valid (2). 123 - And I mentioned (3) to Yahya [1] bin Sa'id, that Abu Mu'awiyah (4) told us from
foot_note:
1. [1] *Al-Awsat*: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id. _________ = Mansur and Al-Hakam (*Al-Ma'rifah wa Al-Tarikh*: 3/12). And he said another time: 'There was no one in Kufa in the time of Mansur more firm ... the most knowledgeable of people regarding Ibrahim and the most firm of them regarding him, and he did not obfuscate (Tadlis)' (*Tarikh Al-Muqaddami*: 204; No: 1003). 
1. He is: Al-Anbari, from Basra, its judge, whose opinion was considered in disagreement. Ibn Sa'd said: He was praiseworthy, trustworthy, intelligent among men (*Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir*: 9/286; No: 4133; *Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 2/352; No: 2557). Ibn Hibban said: Among the masters of the people of Basra in Fiqh and knowledge, he narrates from a group of the Tabi'in (*Al-Thiqat*: 7/143; No: 9380). His biography was repeated so he added (7/152; No: 9426): 'He died in the year one hundred and sixty-eight and was a jurist.' In *Su'alat Al-Ajurri* to Abu Dawud: Is Ubaid Allah bin Al-Hasan a proof (Hujjah) in your view?. He said: He was a jurist (*Tarikh Baghdad*: 12/7; No: 4509). I say: This is avoiding the answer. Al-Nasa'i declared him trustworthy (*Tarikh Al-Islam*: 4/450; No: 262). See: *Thiqat Al-Ajli*: 2/109; No: 1153; *Tarikh Asma Al-Thiqat*: 166; No: 971. Ibn Qutaibah spoke harshly about him in *Ta'wil Mukhtalif Al-Hadith* (44); see: The account of that and the defense of him in *Al-I'tisam* by Al-Shatibi (1/147 - 148). 
2. Ibn Al-Mundhir attributed the view to Ubaid Allah bin Al-Hasan in *Al-Ishraf*: 8/114; No: 5262. 
3. *Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat*: 3/448 - 449; No: 669; up to his saying: 'two and forty', except his saying: 'and that other than Abu Mu'awiyah said "I saw Salim"'. Comparing what is in Al-Bukhari's book with the original alerted to the existence of an omission in it resulting from shifting gaze, and that missing part is his saying: 'And I heard Yahya say: We came to Medina', and it comes immediately after his saying: 'In Medina the first; *Tarikh Al-Fallas*: 260 - 261; from his saying: 'So he said to me: Ubaid Allah told us' to 'Al-Hajj'. The investigators of *Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat* did not know Salim, thinking that the author's saying after this 'the brother of Ubaid Allah bin Umar' refers to him, but it is not so, rather the intended by that is Abu Bakr bin Umar, and they have an excuse, for the text is obscure. 
4. Muhammad bin Khazim Al-Darir, previously mentioned.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Ubaidullah (1), from Abu Bakr bin Salim, that Salim (2) used to cut his hair [1] in the middle of Shawwal, and that someone other than Abu Muawiyah said: 'I saw Salim'; so he said to me [2]: Ubaidullah narrated to us, so he said: Abu Bakr bin [3] Umar informed me, he said: 'I saw Salim [4] cutting his hair in the middle of Shawwal, intending to perform Hajj.' Yahya said to me: He [5] is the brother of Ubaidullah bin Umar, and he died while we [6] were in Medina. And I heard (3) Yahya say: We came to Medina in the year one hundred and forty-two [7]; and Musa bin Uqbah had died a year before that [8]. 124 - And I heard Yahya say: Abu Al-Anbas (4) narrated to us, he said:
foot_note:
1. [1] The copies of Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat were confused regarding it; and this is what the investigators preferred, it is safe in our copy. 'Ijtazza' means he cut his hair. [2] Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat: 'So Yahya said'. [3] In the original: 'Abu Bakr, from Umar'; the correction is from the author's Tarikh and Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat. [4] Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat: 'I saw him'. [5] Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat: 'Hadha' (This). The intent is Abu Bakr bin Umar, for Al-Fallas said in his Tarikh (260-261), narrating from Yahya: 'And I arrived in Medina in the year forty-two, and Abu Bakr bin Umar, the brother of Ubaidullah bin Umar, died in it while we were there.' [6] Thus in the original, and its correction occurred in a margin that was lost due to damage, perhaps the missing part is 'Yahya', but it has no meaning; because the speaker is Yahya himself, and he specified the place. [7] (Sad - copy code): 'And one hundred'; the word is missing from Al-Baji's book. [8] Al-Ta'dil wal-Tajrih: 'Bi-'am' (by a year). _________ 
1. Meaning: Ubaidullah bin Umar Al-Umari. 
2. Meaning: Ibn Abdullah bin Umar. 
3. Tarikh Al-Fallas: 260; with similar wording to Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat: 3/443-444; No: 662; Al-Kamil: 4/196; Al-Ta'dil wal-Tajrih: 2/778; No: 612; Tarikh Dimashq: 60/468. See: Tarikh Ibn Zabr Al-Raba'i: 1/331. 
4. Al-Fallas said in his Tarikh (409): And Abu Al-Anbas, the companion of Zadhan, his name is: Sa'id bin Kathir. And in the narration of Al-Kawsaj from Ibn Ma'in: Trustworthy (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/56; No: 246). Al-Ijli: Kufan, trustworthy (Ma'rifat al-Thiqat: 1/403; No: 612). Abu Hatim: Righteous in Hadith =

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Zadhan [1] narrated to us, he said: Umar bin Al-Khattab wanted to pray over a funeral, but he saw a woman, so he did not pray over it (1), and he said: 'There is no prayer over a funeral when a woman is with it.' So I said to Yahya: But Al-Aftas (2) narrated to us from this [man] around [2] fifteen hadiths? Yahya said: He used to say in them: 'Zadhan said, Zadhan said,' but in this one he said: 'Zadhan narrated to us'; so I wrote it (1). 125 - I heard Yahya say: Uqbah bin Abi Al-Ayzar (2) narrated to us, he said: I asked Ibrahim (3): How much does a woman cut from her hair? He said: Like this; and he placed his finger on the second joint of the index finger. I said to him: Abd al-Rahman (4) narrated to us saying: Sufyan narrated to us, from Uqbah bin Abi Al-Ayzar, he said: I asked Ibrahim and he said: 'She cuts the length of a fingertip' (5), and I asked Sa'id bin Jubayr and he said: 'Women know best.' Yahya said: I indeed heard Uqbah say: I asked Sa'id bin Jubayr and he said: 'Women know best.' So I said to Yahya: Should I write it? He said: Yes. 126 - Yahya [1] narrated to us (6), he said: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abi
foot_note:
1. [1] In the original: 'Zadan'. [2] 'Bi-nahwi min': Not clear in the original. _________ = (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/56; No: 246). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Kitab al-Thiqat (6/368; No: 8141). And Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim said: Medinan, trustworthy (Al-Mustadrak: 4/11; No: 6729). 
1. The pronoun refers to the funeral (Janazah). 
2. He is: Abdullah bin Salamah Al-Aftas Al-Basri. Al-Fallas narrated in his Tarikh (268) - incidentally - a story about him while he was still a boy, indicating the extent of his boldness against the Sheikhs. He said about him in other than the Tarikh: He was one who attacked people's characters (Al-Kamil: 6/535; No: 10354). Yahya bin Sa'id said: He is not trustworthy (3/241; No: 2906; Al-Kamil: 6/535; No: 10352). Ibn Al-Madini: His hadith is gone (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 5/69; No: 329). Ahmad said: People abandoned his hadith (Al-Ilal; his son's narration: 2/494; No: 3256; Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat: 4/885; No: 1403). He was one of Yahya's companions, and he had bad character, and we abandoned his hadith, and the people abandoned him (Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli: 3/240; No: 2905). Muslim in his Kuna (1/521; No: 2073) and Al-Nasa'i in (Du'afa'uhu: 202; No: 342): Abandoned in Hadith. Ibn Hibban said: He had bad memory, made atrocious errors, had many delusions, Ahmad and Yahya abandoned him (Al-Majruhin: 2/20). Al-Bardha'i from Al-Razi (79; No: 17): He was truthful (Saduq) in my view, but he used to speak against Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad, and Yahya Al-Qattan. Al-Daraqutni: Not strong (Al-Ilal: 4/420). Ibn Shaqla: Yahya Al-Qattan used to accuse him of lying (Ta'liqat Al-Daraqutni 'ala Al-Majruhin: 147; No: 176). Ubaidullah bin Umar Al-Qawariri said about him: He did not use to lie, but there was confusion in his tongue (Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythamah: Volume Three: 1/197; No: 509; in it 'In his tongue for the people'; Tarikh Asma' al-Thiqat: 128; No: 647). Ibn Shahin said following it: 'This statement regarding Abdullah bin Salamah is heard from Ahmad bin Hanbal, due to his truthfulness regarding Sheikhs and his knowledge of what they narrated. As for the statement of Al-Qawariri from Yahya Al-Qattan, it is as others said; that whoever listens to Sheikhs and mixes up what he heard, what he heard is worth nothing (Dhikr man Ikhtalafa al-Ulama...: 64; No: 19). See: More reports about him in Al-Ma'rifah wal-Tarikh by Al-Fasawi: 3/47-49.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Maryam (1) narrated to us, he said: A fingernail of mine split [1] while I was in Ihram, so I asked Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib and he said: 'Cut it' (2). I said to Yahya: Al-Aftas (3) said regarding it: 'I asked [2] Salim bin Abdullah and he forbade me.' Yahya said [3]: If [it contained] [4]: 'And I asked Salim [5] and he forbade me', it would have been a hadith [6], but he said [7]: 'I asked [8] Salim [and he did not say anything regarding it] [9]', so I did not write it. 127 - And I heard (4) Yahya bin Sa'id [10] say: Ubaidullah bin Abi
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Shaza'. The meaning: It cracked. See: Al-Sihah: 6/2392. [2] Al-Du'afa: 'Sa'altu' (I asked); without the Waw. [3] Al-Du'afa: 'Fa-qala'. [4] What is between brackets is from Al-Uqayli. [5] Al-Du'afa: 'Salim bin Abdullah'. [6] Al-Du'afa: 'Hadith' (indefinite). [7] Al-Du'afa: 'Kana'. [8] Al-Du'afa: 'Wa sa'altu'. [9] What is between brackets is added from Al-Du'afa; and in it 'shay' (anything). [10] Added in Al-Minhaj: 'Al-Qattan'. _________ 
1. Among the benefits of this report: - Yahya's hearing from Sa'id bin Kathir. - Abu Al-Anbas's hearing from Zadhan. - The frequency of Al-Aftas's Mursal narrations from Zadhan, even if he heard from him, which indicates his mixing things up. - Yahya's disregard for Al-Aftas's Mursal narrations. - Yahya's precision in his narrations; such that he estimated the number of what he heard from Al-Aftas from Zadhan as hadiths, and restricted himself to writing only one of them. - The report itself is beneficial, as this book appears to be unique in mentioning it. 
2. Ibn Sa'd: He had few hadiths (Kubra Tabaqatihi: 8/482; No: 3434). Ibn Al-Madini said: I asked Yahya Al-Qattan about Uqbah bin Abi Al-Ayzar and he said: There was no harm in him (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 6/315; No: 1754). Ahmad: Righteous in Hadith (Ilaluhu bi-riwayat ibnihi: 3/104; No: 4407). Ibn Hibban: His hadith is considered if not from the narration of his son Yahya from him; because Yahya bin Uqbah is weak in Hadith (Al-Thiqat: 7/247; No: 9912). Abu Zur'ah: There is no harm in him (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 6/315; No: 1754). 
3. Meaning Al-Nakha'i. 
4. Meaning: Ibn Mahdi. 
5. The disagreement regarding it is from Uqbah. 
6. Al-Du'afa (J): Folio 165a.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Ziyad (1) narrated to us, he said: Al-Qasim narrated to us [1], from Aisha, she said: 'Indeed Tawaf around the House, Sa'i between Safa and Marwa, and stoning the Jamarat [2] were established for the remembrance of Allah.' And I heard Ibn [3] Dawud narrate it from Ubaidullah bin Abi Ziyad, from Al-Qasim, from
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Shaza'. The meaning: It cracked. See: Al-Sihah: 6/2392. [2] Al-Du'afa: 'Sa'altu'; without the Waw. [3] Al-Du'afa: 'Fa-qala'. [4] What is between brackets is from Al-Uqayli. [5] Al-Du'afa: 'Salim bin Abdullah'. [6] Al-Du'afa: 'Hadith'. [7] Al-Du'afa: 'Kana'. [8] Al-Du'afa: 'Wa sa'altu'. [9] What is between brackets is added from Al-Du'afa; and in it 'shay'. [10] Added in Al-Minhaj: 'Al-Qattan'. _________ 
1. Medinan, a client of Khuza'ah, and it is said: A client of Thaqif (Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 1/139; No: 419). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat (7/419; No: 10695). And Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan said: There was no harm in him (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 7/306; No: 1660; and it appeared in Tarikh Asma' al-Thiqat - 201; No: 1206 - as 'Al-Ansari'; which is an illusion in transmission). And Abu Hatim said: Righteous in Hadith (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 7/306; No: 1660). Al-Daraqutni mentioned him in the book Ahadith al-Muwatta (228), among the rest of Malik's sheikhs from whom he narrated in Al-Muwatta and elsewhere but did not attribute chains from them. See: Al-Duri from Ibn Ma'in: 4/251; No: 4216; and Al-Ta'rif by Ibn Al-Hadhdha': 2/217; No 183. 
2. Imam Malik bin Anas followed Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan from Muhammad with it similarly in his Muwatta, from the narration of Yahya (3/522; No: 1313); and Abu Mus'ab (1/469; No: 1196).
