The author said in other than this book of his: If he narrates from the people of his land it is correct, and if he narrates from the people of Medina like Hisham bin Urwah, Yahya bin Sa'id, and Suhail bin Abi Salih, then it is nothing (Tahdhib al-Kamal: 3/176; No: 472). Another text from him about Ismail will come in this book. Ibn Al-Mubarak said: If Ismail and Baqiyyah agree on a hadith, then Baqiyyah is more beloved to me (Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 1/274; No: 391). Abu Ishaq Al-Fazari: That is a man who does not know what comes out of his head (Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 1/275; No: 393). And he said another time: Do not write from Ismail bin Ayyash from those he knows nor from those he does not know (Al-Du'afa: 1/277; No: 401). But Abu Ishaq had narrated from him then abandoned him, it reached him that he spoke ill of him. See: Kitab Al-Uqayli (1/275; No: 394). Yazid bin Harun: I saw Shu'bah with Faraj bin Fadalah asking him about the hadith of Ismail bin Ayyash (Summary from Musnad Umar by Ya'qub bin Shaybah: 102; No: 200). Yazid bin Harun: I have not seen a Levantine nor an Iraqi with better memory than him (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 2/191; No: 650). Al-Duri from Yahya: Trustworthy (His Tarikh: 4/411; No: 5032). And he was more beloved to him than Faraj bin Fadalah (4/457; No: 5278). And Yahya said: He used to sit with three or four people and read a book while they were with him, and people were gathered, then he would toss it to them and they would all write it, and no one looked in the book except those three or four. I witnessed Ismail bin Ayyash narrating like this so I did not take anything from him, but I witnessed him dictating, so I wrote from him (4/384; No: 4901). Al-Darimi said: I said to Yahya bin Ma'in: So Ismail bin Ayyash, how is he according to you? He said: I hope there is no harm in him (Al-Kamil: 2/83; No: 1814). It was said to Yahya: Which of them is more firm, Baqiyyah or Ismail bin Ayyash? He said: Both are righteous (Al-Kamil: 2/83; No: 1818). text: Yahya bin Sa'id narrated to us, he said [1]: Ibn [2] Jurayj narrated to us, [he said] [3]: Ata [4] narrated to us, he said: I heard Jabir say [5]: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him [7], forbade [6] eating garlic and onions...' then he said: 'And it is said [8] onions, or (1) leeks [9]' (2). 129 - He said: And I heard Yahya say: Everything I wrote [10] from Sufyan where he said: 'He narrated to me', except two hadiths, for he said: 'Simak, from Ikrimah'; and 'Mughirah, from Ibrahim', regarding His statement: {If [11] he belonged to a people with whom you have a treaty but was a believer} [An-Nisa: 92]; they said: A man accepts Islam in the land of war and is killed, so there is no blood money (Diya) on the one who killed him,
foot_note:
1. [1] 'Aklahu' (ate it): Not in Al-Kamil. [2] The prayer upon the Prophet was added in Al-Du'afa, Al-Kamil, and Tarikh al-Islam. [3] Al-Du'afa: 'Ta'aman' (food - accusative). [4] In Al-Du'afa: 'Bahir'; misspelling. [5] (Sad): 'Yaba'. _________ = against Ismail, but Ismail is trustworthy and just, the most knowledgeable of people regarding the hadith of Sham, and no rejecter rejects him, and the most they spoke about was saying: He narrates strange things (Gharib) from the trustworthy Medinans and Meccans (Al-Ma'rifah wal-Tarikh: 2/424). Al-Fasawi: From the men of the Levantines, there is no harm in him (Al-Ma'rifah wal-Tarikh: 2/383). See for more information: Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 2/191; No: 650; Du'afa Al-Uqayli: 1/273; No: 389, 1/276; No: 397; Ma'rifat al-Rijal narration of Ibn Muhriz: 385; No: 1596; Su'alat Abi Dawud: 264; No: 300; Al-Ilal from the narration of Abdullah: 3/9; No: 3909; Al-Ilal narration of Al-Marudhi and others: 141; No: 249; Al-Abatil wal-Manakir: 1/548; No: 355; 2/107; No: 468; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 3/177; No: 472. 
1. One of the trustworthy Levantines. 
2. Like the one before him. 
3. Al-Dhahabi said following the transmission: 'Abu Dawud and Al-Nasa'i extracted the first from the hadith of Baqiyyah, from Bahir, so he inserted between Khalid and her: Khiyar bin Salamah.' See: Its extraction in: Al-Musnad Al-Musannaf Al-Mu'allal: 38/454; No: 18426. 
4. Between this report and the one following it in the original, there is a blank space the size of a line, and there is no reason for it; because the speech appears connected, and thus Al-Uqayli transmitted it. Yahya defected the hadith because it contradicts the requirement of the authentic established hadith that follows it. And the fact that it is from his hadith from the Levantines does not intercede for him, even though the speech of the Imams regarding preferring it over what he narrated from others has passed, for it is opposed by what is stronger. But one can escape [the contradiction] by saying the prohibition is not specific to eating leeks and garlic due to them entering the realm of permissible things, as it applies to attending the mosque for one who ate them, and it is answered that the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, refrained from eating them absolutely for the sake of communion (Munajat), and that the hadith has also appeared absolutely without restriction to entering the mosque or otherwise.

The hadith with this chain from Yahya to its end is in Sahih Muslim (1/395; No: 564) and others, it does not contain 'The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade eating garlic and onions', and it is known that the explicit prohibition formula 'The Messenger of Allah forbade...', occurs in the Sahihs from the path of Abu Al-Zubair from Jabir, as in Sahih Muslim (1/394; No: 563), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah narrated to us, Kathir bin Hisham narrated to us, from Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i, from Abu Al-Zubair, from Jabir, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, forbade eating onions and leeks, but need overcame us, so we ate from them, so he said: 'Whoever eats from this foul tree, let him not approach our mosque, for the angels are harmed by what humans are harmed by.' The phrase did not occur from the path of Al-Qattan, according to what research led to, except in this book of ours, so it is among its benefits.

Nor from Abu Bishr Ja'far bin Abi Wahshiyyah'. And similar to it from his saying: 'Nor from Al-Hakam', to 'all of them'. And the transmission ends with him at the saying: 'Ghusl becomes obligatory'. See: Al-Kamil by Ibn Adi: 3/396; and I think the defect in citation is from the scribe not from Ibn Adi's work, for he is trustworthy in transmission according to what appeared to us by tracking. And it appeared in Al-Baji's book (3/1229; Bio: 1273) the transmission from Al-Fallas, but with a difference in wording and sequence, and its context is: 'Ibn Abi Arubah did not hear from Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Ansari, nor from Ubaidullah bin Umar, nor from Abu Bishr, nor from Zaid bin Aslam, nor from Abu Al-Zinad. Yet he narrated from all of these. And he did not hear from Hisham bin Urwah, nor from Hammad bin Abi Sulaiman, nor from Abu Hasin, nor from Ismail bin Abi Khalid'. Al-Dhahabi transferred in Al-Tarikh (4/62; No: 67) the beginning of the report to his saying: 'Bin Urwah'. The reason for the confusion of the transmitters from Abu Hafs is the difference in his own weaving of the speech about Ibn Abi Arubah between his book Al-Tarikh and this book Al-Ilal, then their coinciding in brevity on his speech in the two sources. You find Al-Fallas's speech not purely transmitted in the following sources: Jami' al-Tahsil by Ibn Kaykaldi: 183; Bio: 239; Nihayat al-Sul by Sibt Ibn Al-Ajami: 5/283; Bio: 2300; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 11/10.

The famous wording of the report is: 'I accepted Islam two years before the death of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him', and this amount of it was extracted by Ibn Abi Khaythama in his history (Volume 2: 869/ 2; No: 3671) and Abu Nu'aym in *Ma'rifat Al-Sahabah* (4/ 198; No: 4818), and Al-Khalili in *Al-Irshad* (534/ 2) and Al-Khatib in his history (422/ 12; No: 5767), all three from Yahya bin Sa'id from Hisham with it. The addition to this amount from Yahya's narration from Hisham only occurred with Al-Fasawi in *Al-Ma'rifah wa Al-Tarikh* (229/ 1), and in it is: 'But I did not see him', and in it 'two years' (Sanatain) was replaced with 'two years' (Amayn). Ibn Abi Khaythama extracted it in his history (Volume Three: 134/ 3, No: 4143) from Mu'adh bin Mu'adh from Hisham with it. And Mu'adh added: 'And I did not see him'. He also extracted it from Abdullah bin Bakr Al-Sahmi (Volume Three: 3/ 135; No: 4144), and added: 'But he did not meet him'. The wording of the first person from the report: 'I prayed two years before the death of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him' solely, is extracted by Al-Bukhari in his history (82/ 6; No: 1776), from Abd al-Salam - I think he is Ibn Harb Al-Nahdi - from Hisham with it; and with the addition of the phrase 'and I did not meet him' to the previous amount for three: for Ahmad bin Bashir and Abu Usamah Hammad bin Usamah - and this path is according to Muslim's condition - both from Hisham with it, with Abu Nu'aym in *Ma'rifat Al-Sahabah* (1917/ 4; No: 4816), and for Isa bin Yunus bin Abi Ishaq Al-Sabi'i, from Hisham with it in *Fawa'id Ibn Akhi Mimi* (184; No: 372) - and this chain is according to Al-Bukhari's condition. text: 185 - Abdullah bin Numair told us (1), he said: Muhammad [bin] Ishaq [1] informed us, from Yazid bin Abi Habib, from Marthad [2] bin Abdullah Al-Yazani, from Abd al-Rahman bin Usailah Al-Sunabihi, he said: I came as a delegate [3] to the Messenger of Allah [4], but he passed away while I was in Al-Juhfah, so I arrived in Medina while the Companions of the Messenger of Allah [5] were plentiful, so I asked Bilal about Laylat
foot_note:
1. [1] In the original: 'Muhammad wa Ishaq'. [2] In the original: 'Marbad'; a misspelling. [3] (Saad): 'Waqadtu'. [4] *Al-Marasil*: 'The Prophet'. And the prayer upon the Prophet is added in Al-Hakim's book. [5] The prayer upon the Prophet is added in *Al-Marasil* and *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*. _________ = Al-Askari (2/ 766), and *Al-Mustakhraj* by Abu Al-Qasim Ibn Mandah (3/ 52). The men of the Hadith from Hisham onwards are men of the Sahih; Al-Haythami said this in *Al-Majma'* (10/ 7; No: 16254), and its chain is straight, but Ibn Abi Khaythama added following Yahya's narration: 'Yahya said: I did not find it with me and I fear it', which is a phrase creating ambiguity due to abbreviation, and its expansion occurred with Al-Khalili so its meaning became clear: 'Yahya said: I did not find it except with Hisham Al-Fardusi and I fear it'. If Yahya intended that he doubted his hearing from him or accused his memory of it or imagined it in his writing and did not find it - which is what his phrase at Ibn Abi Khaythama implies - then that is repelled by the follow-up of the trustworthy narrators for him, and their hearing it from Hisham as well. And if he intended Hisham's uniqueness in it as the pivot is on him - which is what his phrase at Al-Khalili implies - then there is no disparagement in it either; because it is the uniqueness of a trustworthy narrator, furthermore he is more trustworthy in Ibn Sirin than others, and Yahya Al-Qattan himself declares this, for Ibn Al-Madini quotes him saying: Hisham bin Hassan in Ibn Sirin is more beloved to me than Asim Al-Ahwal, and Khalid Al-Hadhdha' in Ibn Sirin (*Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 30/ 186; No: 6572). Whatever the case, the critical sense of Yahya is not a small matter, but his phrase alone does not defect the Hadith. The benefit of the report: Negating Companionship for Ubaidah, and making his hadith from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, Mursal.

5. Al-Fallas was followed by Ibn Sa'd in *Al-Tabaqat Al-Kabir* (8/ 216; No: 8515); and Ali bin Muhammad in *Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal* (3/ 476; No: 6035); and both added: 'While I was a beardless boy, and I did not see him'.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 188 - And Mu'tamir (2) told us (1), he said: I heard my father say [1]: He said: I heard Abu Uthman [2] Al-Nahdi (3) say [3]: I reached the Jahiliyyah, and I have never heard the sound of a cymbal (Sanj) [4] nor a lute (Barbat) (4) nor a flute better than the voice of Abu Musa with the Quran, and if [5] he were to lead us in the Morning Prayer (Subh), we would wish that [6] he read Al-Baqarah [7], due to the beauty of his voice. He said: And [8] Safwan bin Isa (6) told me (5), he said [9]: Sulaiman Al-Taimi (7) told us,
foot_note:
1. [1] *Al-Tarikh*: 'Qala'. [2] (Saad): 'Uthman'. [3] In *Al-Tadwin*: 'From Mu'tamir, from his father, from Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi, may Allah be pleased with him, saying'. [4] (Saad): 'Subh'. [5] *Al-Tarikh*: 'Fa-in'. [6] *Al-Tarikh*: 'Law'. [7] *Al-Tadwin*: 'Al-Baqarah'. [8] *Al-Tarikh*: 'Wa sami'tu'. [9] *Al-Tarikh*: 'Yaqulu'. _________ 
1. *Tarikh Amr bin Ali Al-Fallas* (293); up to his saying: 'And he added in it: nor a Nai (flute)'; *Al-Isti'ab* (2/ 855; No: 1461); and it does not contain the narration of Safwan bin Isa; and what is below it is in it; *Al-Tadwin fi Akhbar Qazwin* (456/ 3); up to his saying: 'beauty of his voice'. 
2. Mu'tamir bin Sulaiman Al-Taimi. 
3. The author in *Al-Tarikh* (292): Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi died in the year ninety-five, being one hundred and thirty years old, and his name is Abd al-Rahman bin Mall, and he reached the Jahiliyyah. 
4. Arabization of 'Barbat', which is the Oud in Persian, and the origin of its meaning: the breast of a goose; because it resembles it. Addi Shir stated this in *Al-Alfaz Al-Farisiyyah Al-Mu'arrabah*: 18. 
5. This is another narration from Al-Taimi via Safwan bin Isa, after presenting the path of his son Mu'tamir. The author was followed regarding Safwan bin Isa with it by Al-Baghawi in *Mu'jam Al-Sahabah* (3/ 405; No: 2186), and Yazid bin Sinan in *Mustakhraj Abi Awanah* (483/ 3, No: 3919), and Ubaid Allah bin Umar in *Al-Hilyah* (258/ 1) and *Ma'rifat Al-Sahabah* by Abu Nu'aym (4/ 1751; No: 4434); all of them up to his saying: 'better than his voice'. 
6. Abu Muhammad Al-Zuhri Al-Qurashi Al-Basri, one of the trustworthy sheikhs of the author. See: *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*: 4/ 309; No: 2938; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 4/ 425; No: 1865; *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 13/ 208; No: 2890. 
7. He is Ibn Tarkhan, Abu Al-Mu'tamir.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: from Abu Uthman [1] similar to it; and he added in it: 'and no flute (nay)' (1) So I narrated [2] it to Yahya bin Sa'id, and he deemed it good and asked me to repeat it more than once, and said: How many did Mu'tamir (2) have from his father, from Abu Uthman? I said: One hundred [3]. He said: I have fifty [4]. 189 - He said (3): And Abu Qutaibah (4) narrated to us, he said: Abu Habib Al-Marbadi [5] - and he is [6] Yazid bin [Abi] [7] Salih - narrated to us, he said: I heard Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi
foot_note:
1. [1] 'Al-Nahdi' added in Al-Tarikh. [2] (Sad - copy code): 'Fa-haddatha' (So he narrated). [3] (Sad): 'Mi'ah'. [4] In the printed edition of Al-Isti'ab: 'Sixty'; and in a copy of it 'Fifty' just as in the original. [5] It occurred with a Ba' in the original manuscript of Tarikh Baghdad, and its annotator inclined to it being a misspelling, and replaced it with 'Al-Muridi', but it is not so. It was misspelled as 'Al-Marthadi' in Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Al-Hakim, and the printed edition of Tarikh Dimashq (35/472), and as 'Al-Marwazi' in Tahdhib al-Kamal (17/427), and all of that is an error, for the attribution is to Souq Al-Marbad. Al-Fallas said in his Tarikh (365): Yazid bin Abi Salih, Abu Habib, a man from Banu Sulaym, used to reside in Al-Marbad. See his biography: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 8/342; Bio: 3247; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 9/272-273; Bio: 1148; Kuna Muslim: 1/256; Bio: 880. [6] Tarikh Dimashq: 'Wa-ismuhu' (And his name is). [7] Appended later. _________ 
1. Jarrah bin Makhlad Al-Basri Al-Ijli followed Al-Fallas in the first report up to his saying: 'Due to the beauty of his voice': Imam Ahmad in Al-Ghilaniyyat (190; No: 163). And the report is suspended from Abu Uthman in Al-Kashf wal-Bayan by Al-Tha'labi (3/416); and Fawa'id Abi Al-Faraj Al-Thaqafi (Hadith No: 7); both to his saying: 'Due to the beauty of his voice'. 
2. Ibn Sulaiman Al-Taimi. 
3. The report is fully covered in Tarikh Al-Fallas: 292; Tarikh Baghdad 11/461; and it is in Al-Hidayah wal-Irshad by Al-Kalabadhi (1/441; No: 647) and Tarikh Dimashq (35/469), stripped of the chain; with the wording of address: 'I performed Hajj...'; and in Akhbar Qazwin (3/456) suspended with the wording of third person. And also by transmission from Al-Khatib in a second place in Tarikh Dimashq (35/472). It is also in Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Al-Hakim (4/78 No: (1747) to his saying: 'Salih'. And in the histories of Baghdad and Damascus: Narrated to me. 
4. Salm bin Qutaybah Al-Khurasani Al-Firyabi Al-Sha'iri Al-Basri.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: saying: 'I performed Hajj in the Days of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah) twice' (1). 190 - He said (2): Then Ubaidullah bin Abd al-Majid [2] Al-Hanafi (3) narrated to me [1], he said [3]: Qurrah bin Khalid (4) narrated to us, from [4] Ismah Abu Hakimah (5), he said: I heard Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi say: In the Days of Ignorance, we used to aim for the difficult she-camel upon which no stallion had ever been loaded [5], and we would load [6] our idols upon it, so there would be no camel among the camels more submissive/humiliated than it [7]. 191 - He said (6): And I heard Yazid bin Harun [8] say [9]: Al-Hajjaj bin
foot_note:
1. [1] Al-Tarikh; Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'Na' (Narrated to us). [2] Added in Al-Tarikh in this place: 'Abu Ali'. Al-Daraqutni restricted himself to citing the Kunya and attribution without the name. [3] 'Qala': Not in Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif. [4] Al-Tarikh; Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif: 'He said: Narrated to me'. [5] The word 'Qatt' (ever) is missing from Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif. [6] Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif: 'Fa-tahmilu' (So it carries). [7] Al-Tarikh: 'So there would be no she-camel among the people more submissive than it'; Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif: 'So there would be no she-camel more submissive than it'. [8] (Sad): 'Harun'. [9] In the original: 'Yaqulu: Qala' (He says: He said) thus; and it is an illusion from the scribe, implying he did not understand the terminology of = _________ 
1. Jarrah bin Makhlad Al-Basri Al-Ijli followed Al-Fallas in Kuna Al-Dawlabi (2/441; No: 792); and in it he misspelled the name of Abu Qutaibah 'Salm' to 'Salim'. 
2. Tarikh Al-Fallas: 293; Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif by Al-Daraqutni: 2/566; Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim: 4/210; No: 1878; to 'Hakimah'. 
3. Abu Ali Al-Basri, the six [Imams] narrated from him; he is one of the author's sheikhs. 
4. Sadusi, the Group narrated from him. See: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 7/183; No: 818; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 7/130; No: 747; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 23/577-580; No: 4870. 
5. Al-Basri Al-Ghazzal, Abu Hatim said: His place is truthfulness. See Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 7/63; No: 288; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 7/20; No: 100. 
6. Tarikh Amr bin Ali Al-Fallas: 292.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Abi Zainab narrated to us, he said: I heard Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi say: We were in the Days of Ignorance; and their caller called out [2] [1]: 'Indeed [3] your god (1) has gone missing.' So we went out seeking him on every difficult and tractable mount; then suddenly their caller [4] called out: 'Indeed we have found him,' or something similar, so we dismounted and slaughtered the camel sacrifice at his location (2). 192 - Azhar bin Sa'd [5] narrated to me (3), he said: Ibn [7] Awn informed us [6], he said: I heard Abu Raja' [8] say: We fled from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him [9], into the wilderness [10], and we found a leg of a dead deer, so we tied it [11] with herbs/vegetables and ate it [12].
foot_note:
1. = the scribes, for in the original he copied from, 'Qala' was found above 'Yaqulu'; which is an alert to what occurred in another copy by way of narration, so he combined them, and that is not correct; whatever the case, it contains an alert to the preciousness and precision of the copy transferred from, which is the mother of this branch currently in hand. [1] Al-Tarikh: 'Fa-idha' (Then suddenly); and above it in its original is 'Fa-nada' (So he called) alerting to the difference in narration. [2] (Sad): 'Munadin bihim'. [3] Al-Tarikh: 'Ala inna' (Verily). [4] (Sad): 'Munadin bihim'. [5] Added in Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'Al-Samman'. [6] Al-Tarikh; Al-Asami wal-Kuna: 'Arana'. [7] (Sad): 'Bin'. [8] (Sad): 'Raja'. [9] The prayer upon the Prophet is not occurring in Al-Tarikh. [10] Al-Tarikh: 'Fa-kunna fi al-barriyah' (So we were in the wilderness). [11] Al-Asami wal-Kuna: '... rahal ... fa-amadnahu ...'; misspelling in both places. [12] Al-Tarikh: 'Fa-akalnahu'. _________ 
1. It is: A stone (Hajar) according to what the follow-up narrations interpreted. 
2. Ibn Sa'd followed Al-Fallas from Yazid in his Kubra Tabaqat (9/69; No: 9702), similarly. And Ibn Abi Shaybah in Al-Musannaf (18/351; No: 34615) - and from his path Al-Khatib in Tarikh Madinat al-Salam (11/459). And Ibn Asakir in Tarikh Dimashq (471/35) - and Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik Al-Wasiti in Mu'jam al-Sahabah by Al-Baghawi (4/172; No: 2716). And Abu Hashim Ziyad bin Ayyub Al-Baghdadi in Mu'jam al-Sahabah by Abu Nu'aym (4/1870; No 4707). See other stories also by Al-Nahdi about the Jahiliyyah of the Arabs in Dala'il Qasim bin Thabit bin Hazm Al-Saraqusti: 2/653; 3/1211; No: 547. 
3. Al-Tarikh by Al-Fallas: 316; and in it: 'Na' (Narrated to us); Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim (Manuscript Section) Folio 155a; and in it: 'Na'.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 193 - He said: And Azhar (1) narrated to me, he said: Ibn [1] Awn informed us, he said: I heard Abu Raja' [2] say: 'They come to me while I am like a dried-up basket (quffah) (2), and they carry me and place me in the row, so I recite thirty and forty verses in a rak'ah for them' (3), meaning: the standing prayer of Ramadan. 194 - He said: Hatim bin Wardan (4) narrated to us, he said: Ayub (5) narrated to us, he said: Abu Raja' [3] said to me: 'I recited last night Surah such-and-such and Surah such-and-such.' Ayub said: And our Sheikh was oblivious/unintelligent (ghabiyyan) (6), and were it not for that, I would not have tolerated that from him! (7).
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Bin'. [2] (Sad): 'Raja'. [3] (Sad): 'Raja'. He is Al-Utaridi. _________ 
1. Passed previously. 
2. His saying: 'Like a Quffah'. Al-Qutabi interpreted it (2/578) saying: 'Al-Ziyadi mentioned from Al-Asma'i that the Quffah among men is the one of short stature/body. He says: Parts of me have compressed into others due to old age, so I am like one of small stature; though I am not so.' I say: It bears another interpretation, which is intending to compare to the fungus (faq'ah), Abu Ubaid said in Gharib al-Hadith (4/296, No: 663): It is something similar to a basket (zabil) not large, made of palm leaves, and has no handles; and it is what the people of Iraq call: Al-Quffah. 
3. Al-Qutabi said in Gharib al-Hadith (2/578): 'Sa'id bin Amir narrates it from Asma' bin Ubaid'. And the wording in it is: 'They come to me and carry me as if I were a Quffah, until they place me in the station of the Imam, so I recite thirty and forty [verses] for them in a rak'ah.' End. And the authors of Gharib (strange/uncommon vocabulary) took this hadith from Ibn Qutaibah and transmitted it from him. 
4. Abu Salih Al-Basri, he was the Imam of Ayub Al-Sakhtiyani's mosque, trustworthy. See: Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 3/260; No: 1160; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 5/197; No: 999. 
5. He is: Al-Sakhtiyani. 
6. Meaning: He did not perceive/understand. I say: Thus Al-Khalil explained it as in Ikmal al-Mu'lim by Iyad (1/100). 
7. Abu Al-Fath Nasr bin Al-Mughirah followed Al-Fallas, via the path of Ibn Abi Khaythamah in Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir (Volume Three: 2/96; No 1892) from him similarly with the wording: Allah provided good tonight: I read Surah such-and-such, and Surah such-and-such, until he counted seven Surahs. Ayub said: So I tolerated that for him, and were it someone else I would not have tolerated it for him; because he was an oblivious/unintelligent (ghabiyyan) old man!'.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 195 - He said (1): Hayyan (2) Abu Jabalah [1] narrated to us, he said: Yunus bin Ubaid narrated to us, from Abu Raja' [2], he said: Whoever is pleased to be a God-fearing believer [3], let him be more submissive than a young camel (qa'ud); everyone who passes by it makes it grumble (3). 196 - Abu Hafs said: Hayyan Abu Jabalah recited to us: The man meets [4] the night-traveler [5] by himself ... And the son of the night-traveler, when he travels by night [6], travels with both of them (4)
foot_note:
1. [1] In Al-Dala'il: 'Habalah'; with a Ha', and he marked it there with Sukun, and all of that is incorrect. [2] (Sad): 'Raja'. And in Al-Dala'il: 'He said: Abu Raja' narrated to us'. [3] (Sad): 'Naqiyyan' (pure). [4] (Sad): 'Talqa'. [5] Misspelled in the original as 'Al-Sarir', then corrected. [6] (Sad): 'Sara'. _________ 
1. Al-Dala'il by Qasim bin Thabit bin Hazm Al-Saraqusti: 3/1072; No: 459. 
2. He is: Hayyan bin Abdullah bin Jabalah Al-Darimi Al-Basri (Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim: 3/192; No: 1230). Al-Fallas said: He was a liar and was a goldsmith. I heard Amr Al-Anmati say: I came to him and heard him say: Al-Hasan told us that Umar bin Al-Khattab was brought a thief so he cut off his hand; so he said: What made you do that? He said: Destiny (Al-Qadar), so he lashed him forty times. Then he confessed that he did not hear it from Al-Hasan, and swore that he would not narrate, and I wrote a document against him and called witnesses against him and left him (Al-Kamil: 4/156; No: 5735; Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil: 317; Al-Jami' li-Akhlaq Al-Rawi: 2/169; No: 1510). See: Tarikh al-Islam: 4/841; No: 89. I say: The author granted concession in quoting him despite his solitary weakening of him - as Ibn Adi did not see any statement about him from others - because he only quotes single disconnected reports from him, not raised (Marfu') hadith. 
3. Abu Salamah Al-Bahili Yahya bin Khalaf followed Al-Fallas, in Gharib al-Hadith by Al-Khattabi (3/57); with slight difference. The report occurred suspended in Al-Majmu' Al-Mughith by Abu Musa Al-Madini (2/730); and Al-Durr Al-Manthur (1/62), from Ibn Abi Al-Dunya. And it occurred in Kitab Al-Zuhd by Ibn Hanbal (256; No: 1840): 'Yunus - meaning: Ibn Muhammad - narrated to us, Hammad narrated to us, from Ayub, he said: Abu Raja' said: More submissive than a young camel'. I say: Thus it occurred, and I did not understand an apparent meaning for it independently, and the assumption is that in the original manuscript there is an omission with which the meaning went entirely. Then I was guided to it in Al-Hilyah by Abu Nu'aym (2/306), via the path of Hammad from Ayub, without deficiency; and in it: By Allah, the believer is more submissive in himself...'. 
4. The verse is in Al-Mashuf Al-Mu'lam: 1/394; Tahdhib Islah Al-Mantiq by Al-Tabrizi: 500; =

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 197 - He said (1): And I heard Abdullah bin Dawud say [1]: I heard Ali bin Salih (2) say: Suwaid bin Ghafalah (3) reached one hundred and twenty [2] years, and he was never seen leaning back, nor ever sitting clasping his knees [3], and he deflowered a virgin. Abu Dawud said: Meaning: In the year in which he died [4]. 198 - He said (4): And Ibn [5] Dawud narrated to us, he said: Ali bin Salih informed us [6], from Zubaid [7]; he said (5): I saw Zadhan [8] praying (6).
foot_note:
1. = Al-Sihah: 6/2375;. And the second hemistich is in Islah Al-Mantiq: 214. 
1. Tarikh Amr bin Ali: 393; Al-Ta'dil wal-Tajrih: 3/1297; Bio: 1360. And the report appeared attributed to Al-Khuraybi directly in Tahdhib al-Kamal: 12/267; No: 2647. 
2. He is: Ali bin Salih bin Salih bin Hayy Al-Hamdani, Abu Muhammad, and it is said: Abu Al-Hasan Al-Kufi, trustworthy. See: His biography in Tahdhib al-Kamal: 20/464; Bio: 4084. 
3. Al-Fallas said in Al-Tarikh (393): 'Suwaid bin Ghafalah died in the year eighty-two, and he was one hundred and twenty years old, and his Kunya is Abu Umayyah.' End. He is trustworthy, reached the Jahiliyyah, and arrived in Medina when hands were being dusted off from burying the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. See: Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/234; No: 1001; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 12/265; No: 2647. 
4. Al-Dala'il by Qasim bin Thabit bin Hazm Al-Saraqusti: 3/1282; No: 590; Shu'ab al-Iman by Al-Bayhaqi: 4/509; No: 2891; Tarikh Dimashq: 18/287; and the report is suspended in Alf Ba' by Abu Al-Hajjaj Al-Balawi (2/398), quoting from Al-Saraqusti. 
5. He is: Zubaid bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Karim Al-Ayyami, trustworthy. See: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 3/450; No: 1499; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 3/623; No: 2818; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 9/289; No: 1957. 
6. Zadhan, he is: Abu Umar. And it is said: Abu Abdullah Al-Kindi their client, Al-Kufi Al-Bazzar. See: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 3/437; No: 1455; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 3/614; No: 2781.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: as if he were a trunk [1] that had been dug in for (1). 199 - He said (2): Mu'adh bin Mu'adh [2] narrated to us, he said: Ibn [3] Awn [4] narrated to us, he said: I saw Muslim bin Yasar praying [5] as if he were a peg (wadd) (3). 200 - He said (4): Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrated to us, he said: Sulaiman bin Al-Mughirah (5) narrated to us, from Ghailan bin Jarir (6), he said: I saw Muslim bin Yasar praying, as if he were a discarded garment (7).
foot_note:
1. [1] (Sad): 'Jada''. [2] (Sad): 'Mu'ad bin Mu'ad'. [3] (Sad): 'Bin'. [4] Alf Ba': 'Awf'; misspelling. [5] In Al-Tarikh: 'Standing praying'; so 'Standing' was added. _________ 
1. Sawwar Al-Anbari followed the author from his Sheikh in Hilyat al-Awliya' (4/199). And Waki' followed Al-Khuraybi from Ali in Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythamah (Segment of Kufans): 83-84; No: 124; and Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah (and the identification of Waki's sheikh was confused in it between 'Hasan' or 'Sufyan'): 5/92; No: 7324. In both of them with the wording: 'As if he were a piece of wood'. 
2. Tarikh Amr bin Ali: 294; Al-Dala'il by Qasim bin Thabit bin Hazm Al-Saraqusti: 3/1281; No: 590; Alf Ba': 2/18; suspended: 2/398 (quoting from Al-Dala'il). 
3. See: Tarikh Dimashq: 58/132, 58/133; Siyar A'lam al-Nubala': 4/511. And 'Al-Wadd' with Fathah, is the peg (Watad) in the dialect of the people of Najd. See: Al-Mashuf Al-Mu'lam: 2/814. We went far in interpreting it in the book Al-Tarikh (294), so let it be corrected, and let one resort to what is here. 
4. Tarikh Amr bin Ali: 295. 
5. Al-Fallas said in Al-Tarikh (378): 'Al-Qaisi, his Kunya is Abu Sa'id'. He is trustworthy. See: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 4/38; Bio: 1887; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 4/144; Bio: 626; Kuna Muslim: 1/358; Bio: 1301; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 12/69-72; No: 2567. 
6. Ma'wali Basri, trustworthy. See: Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 7/101; No: 455; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 7/53; No: 297; Tahdhib al-Kamal: 23/130-131; No: 4700. 
7. What was attributed to the author in other than Al-Tarikh based on his misspelling: 'Khalaqan' (old/worn out), is more appropriate if he intended that he is like a worn-out garment due to his extreme stillness; because a garment when it becomes worn out loses its folds and becomes soft. If the narration supported this it would be permissible, but the narration came as 'Mulqa' (discarded/thrown) and it is more correct.

book_title: A Book Containing the Ills of Hadith and Knowledge of Reliable Jurists from the Weak, upon which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 201 - And he said (1): And Mu'adh [1] bin Hisham (2) narrated to us, he said: My father narrated to me [2], from Qatadah, he said: Muslim bin Yasar used to be counted as the fifth of five of the jurists of Basra. 202 - He said (3): And Abu Dawud narrated to us, he said: Al-Rabi' bin Sabih narrated to us, he said: Makhul said to me: I saw a master from your masters enter the Kaaba, and he stood at the red marble slab [3], [and he recited] [4] around [5] forty verses, then he bowed and prostrated, and he wept [6] in his prostration until he wet the marble [7]. I heard him saying in his prostration: 'My Lord, forgive me my sins, and what my hands have sent forth.' Al-Rabi' said: So I said to Makhul: Who is he? He said: Muslim bin Yasar (4). 203 - He said: And Mu'tamir narrated to us, he said: Kahmas (5) narrated to us, from Abdullah bin Muslim bin Yasar (6), from his father, that when he prostrated, he would start with his knees, then his hands, then his head, and when he rose, he would raise his head before his hands, then his knees, and he would not lean on anything.
foot_note:

Al-Bukhari: He is weakened in Hadith. (Al-Du'afa via narration of Musabbih: 7 - b). And Abu Hatim said: 'I heard Abu Nu'aym Al-Fadl bin Dukain say: Shu'bah said to Laith bin Abi Sulaim: How did you ask Ata, Tawus, and Mujahid all in one sitting?. He said: Ask this hoof of your father!. Abu Muhammad said: Thus Shu'bah's asking Laith bin Abi Sulaim about the meeting of these three for him in one issue indicates; he was like one disapproving of him (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 1/151; No: 64). I say: And his answer is more convincing in Al-Kamil (9/7; No: 14366), and it resulted in Shu'bah avoiding him afterwards. And Ahmad bin Hanbal said: Disturbed in Hadith, but people narrated from him (Ilaluhu: 2/379; No: 2691); his hadith is not rejoiced at (Tartib Ilal Al-Tirmidhi: 293; No: 543). And he is from the men of Sahih Muslim by Ibn Manjuwayh (2/160; No: 1399). And Muslim's narration from him alone is not a modification removing the impugnment from him, for he only coupled him with Abu Ishaq Al-Shaibani, from Ash'ath bin Abi Al-Sha'tha' in the Book of Clothing and Adornment, Chapter on Prohibition of using gold and silver vessels for men and women... (3/1636; No: 2066), which is a single place. And this is from Muslim's methodology, may Allah have mercy on him, in that he follows the reports of the precise ones, with reports in whose chains occur some who are not described with memorization and precision... although they, even if they are below them as we described, the name of cover (satr), truthfulness, and engaging in knowledge encompasses them; like Ata bin Al-Sa'ib, Yazid bin Abi Ziyad, and Laith bin Abi Sulaim' (Sahihuhu: 1/5). So we conclude from what passed that Laith, in his combining disturbance with weakness due to his mixing up at the end, has exhausted the paths of escape, so he is not among those whose narration is good independently if he is alone, but if he is followed up from a sound face it is permissible; as Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, did. See: Tartib Ilal Al-Tirmidhi: 390; Tarikh Asma' al-Du'afa wal-Kadhdhabin: 162; No: 531; Ilal Al-Hadith by Ibn Abi Hatim: 1/414-415; No: 12; Al-Du'afa wal-Matrukin by Al-Nasa'i: 230; No: 511; Al-Kamil: 9/6; No: 14360; Al-Majruhin: 1/468; 2/231.

1. Abu Dawud (2/ 108; No: 1269): Abu Al-Walid Al-Tayalisi said: No one spoke against Al-Rabi' except that Al-Rabi' was above him. Ahmad bin Hanbal said: Al-Rabi' bin Sabih, there is no harm in him, a righteous man. (*Turar Ibn Shaqla*: 97; No: 96). Al-Bukhari said: Abu Al-Walid said: Al-Rabi' used not to obfuscate (Tadlis), and Al-Mubarak bin Fadalah obfuscated more than him. 'And it occurred in the origins of *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir* (3/ 278; No: 952) and the manuscript narration of Musabbih bin Sa'id (4 - Z): "Ibn Al-Mubarak"; and this assumption is incorrect at all as it is incoherent, for Ibn Al-Mubarak was among the severest people in denouncing those who obfuscate, until the famous saying about him: He obfuscated his hadiths for the people, and Allah does not accept obfuscation' (*Ma'rifat Ulum Al-Hadith* by Al-Hakim: 164). If added to this that Mubarak bin Fadalah is famous for obfuscation as passed with us from Abu Dawud's words, and as is in *Ta'rif Ahl Al-Taqdis* (43, No: 93), we know that what occurred is purely an illusion, and it appeared corrected on the main road in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil* by Ibn Abi Hatim (3/ 464; No: 2084); because he brought the report from which Al-Bukhari derived the preference, and its text is: 'Abd al-Rahman told us, Salih bin Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, Ali bin Al-Madini told us, he said: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan: I do not see you narrating anything from Al-Rabi' bin Sabih?. He said: No, and Mubarak bin Fadalah is more beloved to me than him.' I say: Based on this, Al-Bukhari's phrase is an explanation of Al-Qattan's words, which is a valid direction. Add to that, much of what is obscure in *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*, its explanation is often included in Ibn Abi Hatim's book. What cuts off the dispute is the occurrence of the speech by the author about Al-Rabi', immediately after the speech about Mubarak, indicating that comparison between them among the critics is a common practice. 
2. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 3/ 465; No: 2084; *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 100 A. Mughlatay benefited from this text (4/ 342; No: 1550) and added: 'He is not strong'. Ibn Shaqla quoted it in passive voice without attribution in his margins on the Aya Sofya copy of Ibn Hibban's *Majruhin*: 97; No: 96. 
3. Abu Dawud (2/ 108; No: 1269): They claimed that the issues of Ata and Al-Hasan became confused for him.

1. [1] *Tabaqat Abi Al-Shaykh*; *Tarikh Baghdad*: Yahya bin Sa'id. [2] (Saad): 'Mubarak'; *Tarikh Baghdad*: 'And he mentioned Mubarak bin Fadalah'. [3] (Saad): 'Al-Thana'. [4] 'He said And': not in *Tabaqat Abi Al-Shaykh*. [5] *Al-Jarh*: 'Yahya bin Sa'id'; *Al-Majruhin*: 'Yahya bin Ma'in'. [6] Added in *Al-Jarh*: 'Bin Mahdi'. _________ 
1. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 8/ 338; No: 1557; *Al-Kamil*: 6/ 320; and added after it: 'And Mu'tamir, Yazid bin Zurai' and a group narrated from him'; *Tabaqat Al-Muhaddithin bi-Asbahan*: 1/ 399; *Tarikh Baghdad*: 15/ 282; and with its meaning in *Tanqih Al-Tahqiq*: 3/ 104. Compare this report with another report about Mubarak bin Fadalah which says: that Yahya and Ibn Mahdi together do not narrate from him; and there is problematic aspect in it, and Al-Khatib realized it, so he presented the latter report immediately after the report above. Amr bin Ali said: I heard Affan say: Mubarak was trustworthy, and he was, and he was. From *Tanqih Al-Tahqiq*: 3/ 104. 
2. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/ 251; No: 1053; *Tarikh Dimashq*: 65/ 80; *Al-Majruhin*: 3/ 98; up to 'Al-Raqashi'. 
3. Al-Fallas said in *Al-Tarikh* (383): Yazid Al-Raqashi, is Yazid bin Aban. See: *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 64 - 76/ 32; No: 6958. 
4. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 2/ 271; No: 978; *Al-Du'afa* (C) Folio 5 B; *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 171. Al-Hafiz Mughlatay quoted in his *Ikmal* (2/ 232; No: 559) Al-Fallas's words and added to it from its beginning: 'He used not to memorize, and he is a truthful man', and in its middle after 'Sawar': 'And Al-Thawri has narrated from him'.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Al-Ash'ath [1] bin (1) Sawar [2], and I saw [3] Abd al-Rahman strike out [4] his hadith. 229 - He said (2): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from Isma'il bin Abd (3) Al-Malik [5]. And I saw [6] Abd al-Rahman say: I seek Istikharah from Allah [7] to strike out his hadith; he says from Ata [8]: 'Only the draught that intoxicates [9] is forbidden'; and this (4) is the saying of the people of Kufa.
foot_note:
1. [1] *Al-Jarh*; *Al-Du'afa*; *Al-Majruhin*: 'Ash'ath'. [2] (Saad): 'Shawar'; a misspelling. [3] Added in *Al-Du'afa*, before 'And I saw', the phrase 'Abu Hafs said'. [4] (Saad): 'Yahazz'. [5] Added in *Al-Jarh*: 'Bin Abi Al-Sufayra'. [6] *Al-Majruhin*: 'He said: And I saw'. [7] 'I seek Istikharah from Allah' repeated in *Al-Du'afa* and *Al-Majruhin*. [8] (Saad): 'Ata'. [9] *Al-Majruhin*: 'Askaratka' (intoxicates you). _________ 
1. See *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 3/ 264 - 270; No: 524; *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 2/ 233 - 236; No: 560. 
2. *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 122; *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 20 A, to 'Askarat'; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 2/ 186; to 'Abd al-Malik'; but with a chain contrary to what is known from him in citing Al-Fallas's words; which is: 'Abd al-Rahman told us, he said: I heard Ali bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Junayd say: I heard Amr bin Ali'. And he added after it from the narration of Muhammad bin Ibrahim, contradicting the original: 'I saw Abd al-Rahman - meaning: Ibn Mahdi - mention Isma'il bin Abd al-Malik, and he had carried from Sufyan from him, so he said: Strike out his hadith'. I say: And in it is additional clarification. And in Ibn Adi's narration there is addition and difference, for he said: Ibn Al-Mahdi said: I seek Istikharah from Allah, I seek Istikharah from Allah to strike out his hadith: He says from Ata from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: "Every intoxicant is forbidden", and from Ata: "Only the draught that intoxicates him is forbidden"; and this is the saying of the people of Kufa, and he carried it from Sufyan from him, and Yahya used not to narrate from him'. 
3. See *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 3/ 141 - 143; No: 464; *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 2/ 190 - 191; No: 504. 
4. It appears that this last phrase is from the words of Al-Fallas, not Ibn Mahdi.

A man said to him: This is Abu Dawud (6). He said: He did not name him. 232 - He said (7): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from Abd al-Karim Al-Mu'allim (8).

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: He said [1]: So they mentioned [2] once in the presence of Yahya in the Mosque [3] of the Congregation on Friday [4] while I was present [5], resting (Tarwih) [6] in prayer; so he said: They mention from Muslim bin Yasar and Abu Al-Aliyah (1). So Affan Al-Saffar [7] said to him: From whose hadith? He said: Hisham told us - then he said to him between him and him [quietly] while I was listening [8] from Abd al-Karim, from Umair bin Abi Yazid - between him and him [9]. As for (2) Abd al-Rahman, I asked him in the assembly, about a hadith from the hadith of Muhammad bin Rashid (3), from Abd al-Karim [10], so he said: Leave him! When he stood up,
foot_note:
1. [1] 'He said': not in *Kuna Al-Hakim*. [2] *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 'And they mentioned'. [3] *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*: A mosque. [4] *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 'On Friday in the Mosque of the Congregation'; inverted order. [5] What is between the brackets is added from Ibn Abi Hatim. [6] *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*; *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 'Al-Tarwih'. [7] 'Al-Saffar': not in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil* nor in *Kuna Al-Hakim* nor in *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*. [8] Context in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: So he said between him and him while I was listening: Hisham bin Abi Abdullah told us, from Abd al-Karim Al-Mu'allim, so Hisham entered the scope of secrecy; and what is in the original is more correct; because the place of covering is only for the sake of Al-Mu'allim, as for Hisham bin Abi Abdullah Al-Dastuwa'i Al-Basri, he is a firm trustworthy narrator whose name should not be whispered. The parenthetical sentence in its entirety is missing from *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*. And in *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*: Hisham bin Abi Abdullah; and it does not contain the parenthetical sentence. [9] The parenthetical sentence is missing from Ibn Abi Hatim's book; and it is in Al-Hakim's book, with the addition 'while I was listening'. [10] Al-Hakim added: 'Al-Mu'allim'. _________ 
1. The hadith is in Ibn Abi Shaybah in *Al-Musannaf* (4/ 429; No: 6619), from his hadith from Waki', from Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i, from Abd al-Karim Abu Umayyah, from Umair, he said: I rested between Abu Al-Aliyah and Muslim bin Yasar, so they forbade me. 
2. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 6/ 59; No: 311; abbreviated; and from him Al-Biqa'i in *Al-Nukat Al-Wafiyyah*: 1/ 616. 
3. The object of rejection is Al-Mu'allim, not Muhammad bin Rashid, for this one, despite Al-Fallas saying in other than this book of ours =

He said: And he was Munkar al-Hadith (objectionable in Hadith). 234 - And (4) Yahya [3] used not to narrate from (Al-Sari) [4] bin Isma'il (5). 235 - And I heard (6) Yahya say: Sufyan told us, he said: Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd (7) told me, from Al-Sha'bi, that he disliked buying (8) goldsmiths' dust.

It appears it is from the original but missed by the copyist.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 236 - He said (1): And I heard Waki' [1] say: Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd told us, from Al-Sha'bi, that he disliked [2] buying [3] goldsmiths' dust with silver (2). Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd said: And my father used to buy it, not with goods [4]. He said (3): And I never heard Abd al-Rahman mention this Sheikh [5].
foot_note:
1. [1] In the Algeria and Al-Zahiriyyah copies of *Al-Du'afa*: 'Yahya'; which is a clear error attributed originally to Abu Ja'far Al-Uqayli, and the copyists are innocent of it. [2] *Al-Du'afa* (C): 'Harrama' (Forbidden). And it is likewise in *Lisan Al-Mizan*; because Ibn Hajar quotes from the same copy (C), as confirmed by the presence of his handwriting on it in more than one place. [3] In *Al-Du'afa*: 'Shara'. [4] Thus in the original; and perhaps it is a misspelling of 'Bi-urudin' (with goods), necessitating that the requirement is fleeing from silver, and this is only [possible] with goods, and what is in the original contradicts it, so we judged it as contradicting the standard. [5] (Saad): 'Yadkur hadha al-sikh'. _________ 
1. *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 329 A. Ibn Abi Shaybah followed the author regarding Waki' in *Al-Musannaf* (11/ 295; No: 22367) with the wording: 'From Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd, he said: I asked Al-Sha'bi about buying the dust of goldsmiths; so he disliked it and said: It is risk (Gharar). Muhammad said: And my father used to buy it with goods'. 
2. Ibn Ma'in pointed in his history (3/ 471; No: 2319) to his narration of this report, saying: 'And he is the one who narrates in the story of the goldsmiths' dust'. Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaibani said in *Al-Asl* (3/ 40): [Abu Hanifa] told us, from Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd, he said: I asked Amir about selling goldsmiths' dust, so he said: There is no good in it, and it is risk (Gharar), like selling fish in the water. 
3. Ibn Asakir (22/ 186) quoted this phrase verbatim, in the biography of Sulaiman bin Arqam, while the speech here is about Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd; and the assumption is strong that the quote is erroneous; because the speech in the copy about Sulaiman bin Arqam comes immediately after the speech about Ibn Abi Al-Ja'd, and that is a cause for confusion and ambiguity. The source of it apparently is from someone above Ibn Asakir. Mughlatay fell into the same confusion in his *Ikmal* (6/ 37; No: 2153); and that was also attributed to Ibn Hajar in *Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib*: 4/ 148; No: 297. Al-Uqayli quoted correctly from the author in the entry of Muhammad bin Abi Al-Ja'd, so he did not mix him up with Sulaiman bin Arqam.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 237 - He said (1): And Sufyan [1] Al-Thawri [2] used to narrate from Abu Mu'adh, from Al-Hasan - [meaning] [3]: Ibn Arqam (2). Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Ansari said (3): When we were young, we used to be forbidden [4] from sitting with him; and he mentioned [5] a grave matter regarding him. 238 - He said (4): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from Al-Hasan bin
foot_note:
1. [1] (Saad): 'Sufyan'. [2] (Saad): 'Al-Turi'. [3] What is between the brackets is missing from the original. And the intended is Sulaiman, as in the documentation sources. [4] (Saad): 'Nanha'; *Al-Kamil*: 'Tunha'. [5] *Al-Kamil*; *Tarikh Dimashq*: 'Fa-dhakara'. _________ 
1. *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 119 B; *Al-Kamil*: 3/ 250; *Tarikh Dimashq*: 22/ 185; 22/ 186; *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 328; from 'Muhammad bin Abdullah said' to 'grave'. 
2. It occurred in *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil* (4/ 100; No: 450) - which is also in *Al-Kamil* and *Tarikh Dimashq* (22/ 188) -: that Al-Fallas said: 'Indeed Sulaiman bin Arqam - and his Kunya is Abu Mu'adh - is not trustworthy; he narrated objectionable hadiths'. I say: Ibn Abi Hatim quoted from Al-Fallas the rest of the report, so what he brought and we cited which we do not have is a reasoned critical judgment, supported and reinforced by Al-Ansari's words. Ibn Shaqla said in his margins (110; No: 122): Amr bin Ali said: Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from him. He narrated from Al-Hasan, that Aisha and Hafsa woke up fasting. And he narrated from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abu Salamah, from Aisha, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "No vow in disobedience, and its expiation is the expiation of an oath". Al-Bukhari said in his *Du'afa* (Narration of Musabbih bin Sa'id: 5 - F): They abandoned him. Abu Dawud (2/ 195; No: 1578): Abandoned in Hadith. See: *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 11/ 351 - 354; No: 2491; *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 6/ 37 - 39; No: 2153. 
3. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 4/ 100; No: 450; and his wording is: 'They used to forbid us from him while we were young, and he mentioned a grave matter'. 
4. *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim (The Manuscript Section: Folio 172 B; *Al-Du'afa* by Al-Uqayli (C): Folio 57 B; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 3/ 12; No: 37. And to 'Dinar' in *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 232. And it occurred in *Al-Kamil* (2/ 296) - and *Al-Lisan* followed it (3/ 40; No: 2269) - the quotation from the author =

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: Dinar; and Sufyan Al-Thawri used to say [1]: 'Abu Sa'id Al-Sulaiti (1)' [2].
foot_note:
1. [1] Added in this place in the book of Ibn Abi Hatim and Ibn Hibban's *Majruhin* and Al-Hakim's *Kuna*: 'Thana' (He told us); and it did not occur in the trustworthy copy of *Al-Du'afa*; and confirming it implies the occurrence of Tadlis from Sufyan. [2] Ibn Abi Hatim added 'Meaning: Hasan bin Dinar'; and likewise Ibn Hibban saying: 'He means Al-Hasan bin Dinar'; and this is not from Al-Fallas's words. _________ = is longer than what is in the original; and its context is: 'Al-Hasan bin Dinar is: Al-Hasan bin Wasil, Dinar was his stepfather, and he is a client of Banu Sulait, Sufyan Al-Thawri narrated from him and used his Kunya' saying: 'Abu Sa'id Al-Sulaiti told us'. 
1. Attribution to Banu Sulait (*Mukhtasar Al-Kamil* by Al-Maqrizi: 264; No: 446). Al-Bukhari quoted Sufyan's benefit, and established the narrator's abandonment by Yahya and Ibn Mahdi in the two histories (2/ 292; No: 1513, 3/ 593; No: 908). Al-Fallas said: 'I heard Abu Asim say: I heard Hammad bin Zaid narrate from him with two hadiths; I said to him: You narrate from this one?!. He said: Do you see him lying in two hadiths?!'. (*Al-Kamil*: 3/ 451; No: 445). Amr bin Ali also said: 'I heard Abu Dawud [Al-Tayalisi] say: We were with Shu'bah, so Al-Hasan bin Dinar came, so Shu'bah said: O Abu Sa'id, here, so he sat, and said: Humaid bin Hilal told us, from Mujahid, he said: I heard Umar bin Al-Khattab say. He said: So Shu'bah started saying: Mujahid heard Umar!. So Al-Hasan stood up and left' *Al-Kamil*: 3/ 451; No: 445; to its end; *Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil*: 392 - 393; No: 399; with slight difference that does not harm; - and quoted in *Al-Lisan* from Ibn Adi (3/ 40; No: 2269) -; *Al-Marasil* by Ibn Abi Hatim: 204; No: 754; to 'and left'; and quoted by Mughlatay: 11/ 8; No: 4425; to the same amount. Amr bin Ali said: 'Al-Hasan bin Dinar, Abu Dawud narrated from him in Isfahan, and started saying: Al-Hasan bin Wasil told us; and in my view he is not among the people of lies, but he was not a Hafiz'. Some of what passed is present in *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim (The Manuscript Section): 47. Al-Bukhari said: 'Waki' and Ibn Al-Mubarak abandoned him (*Du'afauhu*, narration of Musabbih: 3 - F). Abu Dawud Al-Sijistani said about him (1/ 390; No: 746): 'He is nothing' (2/ 33; No: 1024): 'Not trustworthy'. I say: It is gathered from their sayings that Abu Asim did not see narrating from him, and that Hammad bin Zaid only narrated two hadiths from him, deeming it unlikely he would lie in both, so he did not narrate much from him. Waki' and Ibn Al-Mubarak abandoned him, and Shu'bah denied some of his hadith and left him, and his two students Yahya Al-Qattan and Ibn Mahdi abandoned him, and Al-Tayalisi denied lying from him but accused him of bad memory, and Abu Dawud Al-Sijistani declared him weak: so he is weak inevitably.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: He said: And I heard Abu Dawud say: Al-Hasan bin Wasil told us; and he is Al-Hasan bin Dinar. 239 - He said (1): And Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from Husam (2) bin Misak [1]. He said (3): And Abu Dawud used to say: Abu Sahl Al-Azdi told us [2], and he is Husam bin Misak (4). 240 - He said (5): And I spoke to Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi: 'About Abu Dawud,
foot_note:
1. [1] (Saad): 'Misr'; which is a misspelling, and it will come correctly from the copyist shortly after. Added in this place from Al-Uqayli's book: 'Anything'; and the original is devoid of it. [2] *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 'He told us from him so he said: Told us'. _________ 
1. *Al-Kamil*: 2/ 433; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 3/ 317; No: 1419; and in it is 'Al-Husam bin Al-Misak'; *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 80 A; *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim (The Manuscript Section) Folio 194 A; and in it is 'Al-Misak'; *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 272; and in it is 'Al-Misak', with the definite article, and likewise in the place after it. Ibn Adi quoted from Al-Fallas more fully than here so refer to it; and Mughlatay from him (4/ 51; No: 1254) with abbreviation. 
2. Al-Bukhari said: Not strong according to them (*Al-Du'afa* narration of Musabbih: 4 - F). And from Abu Ubaid Al-Ajurri from Abu Dawud (1/ 434; No: 912) 'It was said: Is Husam trustworthy? He said: No'. And in it also (2/ 113; No: 1282): Al-Hasan bin Ali told us, from Shababah, he said: I said: I said or it was said to Shu'bah: What is the matter with Husam bin Misak?. He said: I saw him urinating facing the Qiblah. Abu Dawud said: Shu'bah narrated two hadiths from him, and he is Munkar Al-Hadith (objectionable in Hadith). See for details: *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 6/ 5 - 8; No: 1184; *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 4/ 51 - 52; No: 1254. 
3. *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 3/ 317; No: 1419; *Al-Majruhin*: 1/ 272; *Al-Kamil*: 2/ 433. 
4. Abu Dawud (d. 204 AH) was not unique in this clarification, but Zaid bin Al-Hubab Al-Ukli (d. 230 AH) followed him; as occurred in *Ilal Al-Imam Ahmad* (3/ 66; No: 4195): 'Zaid bin Al-Hubab told us, he said: Abu Sahl Al-Azdi Husam informed me, from Qatadah ...'. End of intended quote. See: *Mawsu'at Aqwal Al-Daraqutni*: 1/ 193; No: 902; And these have been followed in the naming by the later scholars. Among those famous with this Kunya and attribution is Al-Nadr bin Kathir, and he is more known by them.

foot_note: 1. = Al-Awsat (3/639; No: 985): 'Abu Dawud said: Qais was only compromised because of his son, and his son used to take people's hadiths and insert them into the gaps of Qais's book, and the Sheikh did not know that.' Ibn Abi Hatim did not cite criticism against him, but rather brought reports containing Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj's praise of him for diligence in seeking knowledge. See: Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 1/150; No: 63. In Tarikh Baghdad (14/469), Shu'bah said: 'Qais discussed with me the hadith of Abu Hasin, and I wished the house would fall on me and him until we died, due to the abundance of strange things (Gharib) he presented to me.' I say: Shu'bah's admiration of him is coupled with his defect, which is his narrating strange things, and narrating strange things is not what testifies to trustworthiness, and whatever the case, even if it is permissible in discussion, it is avoided in narration. Above what passed, judgment is usually given to Yahya's verdict on a narrator if he shared knowledge of him with his teacher Shu'bah, over what Shu'bah held independently, for his domain was narration, and there is no entry then for Yahya's opinion. Evidence for what we just said is that Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi said: They differed one day in front of Shu'bah, so they said: Appoint a judge between us and you, he said: I am satisfied with the cross-eyed one (Al-Ahwal) - meaning: Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan - so we did not leave until Yahya came; so they sought his judgment, and he ruled against Shu'bah, so Shu'bah said: And who can withstand your criticism, O Ahwal? (Tarikh Baghdad: 16/205; No: 7413). Despite this, he knew his opinion on Qais and rebuked him for it saying: 'O Ahwal, you mention Qais Al-Asadi?!' as if disapproving of him. (Dhikr man Ikhtalafa al-Ulama...: 81; No: 37). It seems this was not Shu'bah's opinion alone, for Al-Fallas narrated reports from him with this meaning and from Abu Al-Walid Al-Tayalisi and Abu Dawud as well, saying: 'I heard Abu Dawud say: I heard Shu'bah say: How strange for this Ahwal, he does not approve of Qais bin Al-Rabi' - meaning: Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan'. And he said: I said to Abu Al-Walid: You praise Qais bin Al-Rabi' a lot? He said: Because he - by Allah - used to fear Allah. Or something like this; I doubt the oath'. And he said: 'When Yazid bin Harun came to Basra and narrated to us from Qais, I said: Narrate to us from someone else, so it reached Abu Dawud, and he got angry with me until I apologized to him. And I said to him: I write Qais from you, and I write from Yazid the senior Sheikhs (Masa'il Harb bin Ismail Al-Kirmani; Marriage to end of book): (3/1333-1334; No: 2402, 2403, 2404). In Tarikh Baghdad (14/469): 'Affan said: I said to Yahya bin Sa'id: Did you hear Sufyan say anything about him regarding a mistake, or speak about him with anything? He said: No. I said to Yahya: Do you accuse him of lying? He said: No. Affan said: So he brought no proof regarding him'. I say: As for Sufyan, he mentioned him based on what he knew of his state, and perhaps what indicated the weakness that befell him later did not reach him yet, whether by confusion or otherwise, which escaped Shu'bah and Sufyan, and supporting this is that Ibn Mahdi followed them =

foot_note: 1. = in having a good opinion of Qais so he narrated from him, then when he tested his hadith he retracted from that, so he gained knowledge by accompanying him that they did not get, while affirming that the status of Shu'bah and Sufyan is higher and more significant. None of the critics said that a critic's judgment on a narrator during his life is eternal and irreversible, such that it is conceded to Shu'bah forever. As for Yahya negating lying from him, it is not a modification (Ta'dil) nor does it necessitate it, for the cause of abandoning a narrator is not always lying, but includes frequent delusion, apparent confusion, bad memory, loss of original books... And Yahya Al-Qattan's silence on bringing proof for abandoning him is not proof of its absence, nor evidence of his hand being empty of what testifies to it, but Affan sensed it from what preceded, and in my opinion if he had confronted him with a question about the cause he would have cited it; so there is no proof in this report at all to negate the existence of a cause for criticism by Yahya, and it is apparent that he tested Qais's hadith and flaws appeared to him in it which appeared to Ibn Mahdi later leading him to retract his agreement, supported by the saying of the Sheikh of the Art Ali bin Al-Madini: 'Only a son of his destroyed him, he reversed things in his hadith, and Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrated from him for a time then abandoned him' (Tarikh Baghdad: 469/14). Ibn Numair added: 'He had a son who was his bane, the Hadith scholars looked into his books and rejected his hadith, and suspected that his son had changed them' (Al-Majruhin: 78/1). Furthermore, Affan later realized what he denied on Yahya, so it was not appropriate to cite his earlier speech without the later one, for he said: 'I used to hear people mentioning Qais, and I did not know what his defect was, so when we came to Kufa we went to him, sat with him, and his son started prompting him saying to him: Husain, so he says: Husain, then another man says: And Mughirah, so he says: And Mughirah, another says: And Al-Shaibani, so he says: And Al-Shaibani (Al-Majruhin: 219/2). In his speech is a great benefit, which is that the talk about Qais was widespread, not in a narrow circle. Ibn Hibban said: I have tested the reports of Qais bin Al-Rabi' from the narration of the early and later scholars and tracked them, so I saw him truthful and trustworthy when he was young, but when he grew old his memory worsened and he was tested with a bad son, who used to insert hadith upon him and he would answer him trusting his son, so when rejected reports (Manakir) overwhelmed his authentic hadith and could not be distinguished, he deserved to be avoided in argumentation. So whoever praised him among our Imams and encouraged [narrating from] him, that was from them because they looked at the upright things he narrated from his hearing. And whoever weakened him among them, that was because they knew of the rejected reports in his hadith that his son and others inserted upon him' (Al-Majruhin: 2/219).

Abu Zur'ah Al-Iraqi attributed it in Al-Tuhfah (245) and Al-Ala'i in Al-Jami' (245) to Ibn Abi Hatim, and the latter introduced it with a passive voice. More comprehensive than that is Al-Juzjani's saying in Ahwal al-Rijal (33): 'It is common among the people of Hadith that Abu Ishaq did not hear from [Al-Harith] except three or four. I heard Ibn Hanbal say: Abu Ishaq married Al-Harith's wife, so his hadith fell to him. And they say: He did not hear from Al-Harith except three or four. I heard Abu Bakr bin Ayyash say: Ahmad said'; words to this effect. And Abu Khaythamah said in his son's history {Segment of Kufans: 114; No: 227}: 'Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan used to narrate from the hadith of Al-Harith what Abu Ishaq said in it: I heard Al-Harith'. 
4. Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 3/79; Bio: 363; and there is awkwardness in the phrase, compare necessarily with what is in Al-Uqayli's book, and 'He said' is missing from his Du'afa. The transfer is correct and brief in Ibn Adi's book.

text: 262 - He said (1): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman [1], used to not narrate from [Salim bin Abi Hafsah (2). Then I heard [2] Yahya one day say: He said [3]: Narrated to us] [4] Sufyan, he said: Abu Yunus (3) narrated to me [5], from Mundhir Al-Thawri (4). So a man from our companions said to him: This is Salim bin Abi Hafsah. He said: No. He said: Yes [6]; Sufyan [7] bin Uyainah [8] narrated it to us; he said [9]:
foot_note:
1. [1] Added in Al-Jarh: 'Bin Sa'id', and 'Bin Mahdi'. [2] Al-Du'afa: 'Fa-sami'ahu' (So he heard him). Al-Kamil: 'Wa-sami'tu' (And I heard). [9] Missing from Al-Majruhin and Al-Kamil. _________

2. Al-Fallas said: 'Salim bin Abi Hafsah, he is: Salim Abu Yunus, excessive in Shi'ism, weak in Hadith' (Al-Kamil: 344/3). And Al-Bukhari transmitted in Al-Kabir (4/111; Bio: 2140): 'Amr bin Ali said to me: I heard Ali say: Na Yahya bin Sa'id, Na Ibn Uyainah, Na Salim bin Abi Hafsah, Abu Yunus. Yahya said: If it were Salim I would not have written it.' End. See for details: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 10/133-137; No: 2143; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 5/182-183; No: 1805. 
3. Ahmad said in his Jawabāt to Abu Dawud (179; No 59) Sufyan, from Abu Yunus; he is: Salim bin Abi Hafsah. And perhaps he used his Kunya. 
4. He is: Mundhir bin Ya'la, Abu Ya'la Al-Thawri; Humaid bin Zanjawaih said it. See: Tabaqat Ibn Zanjawaih (65 my verification); Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: 7/357; No: 1540; Al-Kuna wal-Asma' by Muslim: 2/928; No: 3786.

text: Salim bin Abi Hafsah, Abu Yunus, narrated to us [this hadith] [1]. 263 - He said: And I heard Mu'tamir say: Sufyan [2] narrated to us, he said: Salim narrated to me, from Ibrahim [3], he said: A man asking [4] 'Are you a believer?' is an innovation, without doubt!. I mentioned that to Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi, so he said: This is the hadith of Al-Hasan bin Ayyash, from Al-Mughirah (1), from Ibrahim (2), he said: A man asking [5] 'Are you a believer?' is an innovation. He said: And I do not know Abd al-Rahman except that he said: And he narrated it from Sufyan from him. 264 - He said (3): And Waki' narrated to us, he said: Sufyan narrated to us, from a Sheikh from the people of Khurasan, from Ikrimah, regarding a man who bequeathed [6] a share of his wealth to a man, but did not name anything. He said: There is nothing for the bequeathed [7] to; this is unknown (Majhul) [8]. So I asked Abd al-Rahman about it, and he said: Sufyan heard it from Ibn [9] al-Mubarak. Abd al-Rahman narrated to us, he said: Ibn [10] al-Mubarak narrated to us, from Ya'qub bin al-Qa'qa', from Muhammad bin Suhaib, from Ikrimah, he said: [No] [11] thing for him (4).

text: 265 - He said (1): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used to not narrate from Uthman Abu Al-Yaqzan (2). 266 - He said (3): And I heard Yahya, he said: I heard Ismail say: Abu Salih (4) was
foot_note:
1. Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat (From narration of Al-Khaffaf, and in narration of Zanjawaih: 'Do not narrate from Uthman bin Al-Yaqzan Abu Al-Yaqzan'. I say: And the phrase 'Ibn Al-Yaqzan', is a slip of the pen as if a repetition occurred in the copy): 3/329; No: 508; Al-Du'afa (J): Folio 255b; Al-Majruhin: 2/95; Al-Kamil: 5/168; and in it is the addition of Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 6/161; Bio: 884; and his phrase is: 'Yahya bin Sa'id did not approve of Abu Al-Yaqzan nor did he or Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrate from him'; which is the result of combining two separate texts; one passed, and this is the second. 
2. Abu Dawud said it (1/223; No: 248) about Ibn Mahdi alone - without Yahya.. Ibn Zanjawaih said in his Tabaqat (70; my verification): 'Abu Al-Yaqzan: Uthman bin Umair Al-Bajali'. See: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 19/469-472; No: 3851; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 9/177-179; No: 3645. 
3. Al-Kamil: 2/69; but 'Yaktubu' (writes) occurred in it; perhaps a misspelling. See: The following comment. 
4. Al-Fallas said in his Tarikh (334): Abu Salih, client of Umm Hani, his name is Badhan, and they said: Badham'. Al-Bukhari said in his weak narrators from narration of Musabbih bin Sa'id: 2 - (b): 'Muhammad bin Humaid said: From Hakim bin Bashir, from Amr bin Qais Al-Mula'i, he said: Mujahid used to forbid the Tafsir of Abu Salih'. And it occurred in Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir (2/144; Bio: 1988): 'Hakam bin Bashir', and perhaps it is correct, due to the support of copies for it, and the singularity of Musabbih's copy. Al-Saji said in the weak narrators from the Meccans: 'Abu Salih from whom Ismail bin Abi Khalid narrated, his name is Badhan, client of Umm Hani, and he is the one from whom Al-Kalbi, Al-Suddi, Mansur, Sayyar, Ismail bin Salim, Abd al-Aziz bin Rufai', Abu Makin, Firas, Muhammad bin Juhadah, Simak bin Harb, and Husain narrated. And Ali bin Al-Madini said: I heard Yahya bin Sa'id say: I have not seen any of our companions abandon Abu Salih client of Umm Hani nor have we heard anyone say anything against him, and neither Shu'bah nor Za'idah nor Abdullah bin Uthman abandoned him'. (Margins of Ibn Shaqla on the Aya Sofya copy of Al-Majruhin by Ibn Hibban: 59; No: 28). See for details in the biography: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 4/6-8; No: 636; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 2/345-348; No: 669.

foot_note:
1. [1] In the original: 'Mukattib'; and the correct is 'Mukattiban'; but something similar to the original occurred in the trusted copy of Du'afa Al-Uqayli (J: Folio 42b); so we established it as is; and its context is: 'Abdullah bin Ahmad narrated to us, he said: Abu Bakr bin Khallad narrated to us, he said: I heard Yahya bin Sa'id, he said: Ismail bin Abi Khalid narrated to us, he said: Abu Salih was a scribe (Mukattib), so I never asked him about anything except that he explained it to me'. The origin of the report is in Kitab Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal by Ahmad, from his son's narration (2/450; No: 3000, 3/223; No: 4972); but with the wording 'Mukattiban' properly vocalized as appears in the Aya Sofya copy. The intent of this citation is that there is evidence for what is in our copy, justifying its retention of an approximate image from the trusted original it was copied from. And something like this has a permissible justification among grammarians, which is deleting the Alif of Tanwin Nasb according to the dialect of Rabi'ah. [2] Added in Al-Jarh: 'Bin Sa'id'. [3] Added in Al-Jarh: 'Bin Mahdi'. [4] In Al-Kamil: 'When he mentioned him he would say'. _________

Al-Dhahabi transferred in Al-Tarikh (4/327; No: 62) the first half of the report, and said following it: 'Yahya bin Sa'id's strictness regarding men is known, yet after this he narrates from Mujalid, and strengthens him.' 
2. Al-Yashkuri, Abu Al-Khattab Al-Basri. See: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 5/524-526; No: 1156; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 4/24; No: 1227.

4. Al-Tamimi Al-Basri Al-Bazzaz, Ibn Zanjawaih attributed his lineage in his Tabaqat (105) as Minqari. See: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 14/116-118; No: 3077; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 7/166-167; No: 2686. 
5. Meaning: He is not satisfactory to him; and it contains an avoidance of explicit weakening mostly. Indicating this is Al-Bukhari's saying in Al-Du'afa (Narration of Musabbih: 6 - b) and Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir (6/36; No: =

text: 269 - He said: I never heard Yahya nor Abd al-Rahman narrate anything from Isa (1) Al-Khayyat. 270 - He said (2): And Yahya used to not [1] narrate from Hammam (3), whereas Abd al-Rahman used to narrate from him (4).
foot_note:
1. [1] Its place is punctured in the original. _________ = (1608): 'Ibn Mahdi narrated from him, and Yahya Al-Qattan abandoned him'. And Abu Hatim (Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 6/79; No: 406) criticized Al-Bukhari for entering his name in the book of weak narrators and said: It should be moved from there. 
1. Thus in the original we left it as is, and we did not find anyone who transmitted it, nor is it supported by what is in Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil (4/185; Bio 799) and Kitab Al-Majruhin (1/342), and Du'afa Al-Uqayli (2/565; No: 2318) and Kamil Ibn Adi (3/344) mentioning 'Salim Al-Khayyat' not Isa. Perhaps the report is unique to the book. Among the indications of misspelling is that Al-Fallas's report regarding Yahya's specific stance on Isa has passed, and it is quoted from him in the aforementioned books, unlike his speech about the stance of the two Sheikhs regarding him here, for it is not in any of them, yes... you find it exactly but about Salim, and Allah knows best. And Isa, definition of him has passed. 
2. Al-Du'afa (J): Folio 392a; Al-Kamil: 7/129. 
3. He is: Hammam bin Yahya bin Dinar Al-Awdhi. It appears Yahya had a bad opinion of him, for Al-Fallas said (Tarikh al-Islam: 4/534; No: 419): 'Yahya did not approve of his book nor his memory, and did not narrate from him.' It seems the generalization that Yahya did not narrate from him needs exception, for he did not narrate from him in audition circles, but he used to bring his hadith in discussion or debate circles for consideration or otherwise; as indicated by Ahmad's saying in Al-Jawabāt (335-336; No: 491): 'Yahya used to narrate from Aban Al-Attar, and not narrate from Hammam, then - they claimed - Mu'adh bin Hisham arrived, and narrated hadiths in which he agreed with Hammam. Affan said: So Yahya used to say to me after that: How did Hammam say in this hadith?, discussing it between them.' 
4. And with its meaning from Ali bin Al-Madini in Tarikh Al-Muqaddami (202; No: 1000). The aspect of Ibn Mahdi's narration from him is understood, combined with another report by Al-Fallas about him - transmitted by Al-Dhahabi (4/534; No: 419) - which is that Abd al-Rahman restricted what he narrates from him to 'If Hammam narrates from his book then it is =

text: 271 - He said (1): And I heard Mu'adh bin Mu'adh [1] - and Salih bin Abi [2] Al-Akhdar (2) was mentioned - so he said: I heard him say: I heard [from] [3] Al-Zuhri and I read to him, and I do [not] [4] know this from this? So Yahya bin Sa'id [5] - who was next to him - said: If this was like this, it would have been good [6], but [7] he heard, and presented, and found something written, so he said: I do not know this from this! (3).
foot_note:
1. [1] Added in Al-Majruhin: 'Al-Anbari'. [2] In Al-Kamil: 'Bin Abi Salih Al-Akhdar'. [3] From Al-Du'afa, Al-Majruhin, and Al-Kamil. [4] Al-Majruhin: 'Fa-la' (So not). [5] Bin Sa'id is not in Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli. [6] Al-Majruhin: 'If it were like this it would be better'; Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli: 'Good'. [7] Dropped from Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli; and in Tarikh Dimashq: 'But he'. _________ = correct. Although Imam Ahmad said in his Jawabāt (335; No: 490): 'The hearing of those who heard from Hammam at the end is more correct; that is because he was afflicted with something like chronicity, so he used to narrate to them from his book. So the hearing of Affan, Hibban, and Bahz is better than the hearing of Abd al-Rahman; because he used to narrate to them - meaning: to Abd al-Rahman; i.e., in their days - from memory.' It appears that Ibn Mahdi had a book containing [narrations] from Affan, and he had stripped its benefits and selected them in his mind, so Ali bin Al-Madini asked him for it and said: 'Show it to me so I can write something from it. He said: No, but let me dictate to you what I see you will benefit from, so when I finish I will give it to you to look at. He said: So he dictated to me hadiths from it that I benefited from, then he gave me the book so I looked into it and did not benefit anything from it' (Tarikh Al-Muqaddami: 202-203; No: 1001). See for details in the narrator's biography: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 302/30-310; No: 6602; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 12/165-168; No: 4967. 
1. Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli (J): Folio 144b; Al-Majruhin: 368/1; Al-Kamil: 4/64; Tarikh Dimashq: 307/23; and Ibn Asakir combined the contexts of the narrations. 
2. See Tahdhib al-Kamal: 13/8-22; No 2795; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 6/317-318; No: 2434. 
3. Perhaps because of that, Yahya refrained from narrating from him (Su'alat Al-Ajurri: 1/421; No: 859). Ibn Ma'in said about him: He is nothing (Al-Daqqaq: 67; No: 173). Al-Bukhari said: =

text: 272 - He said (1): And when Abu Bakr bin Ayyash (2) was mentioned in his presence [1], Yahya bin Sa'id would scowl (3) and turn away [2], whereas Abd al-Rahman used to narrate from him. 273 - He said: And I heard Yahya say: What I wrote from Sufyan from Al-A'mash is more beloved to me than what I wrote myself from Al-A'mash; because he was stronger [3] on Al-A'mash than me (4).
foot_note:
1. [1] In the original: 'Anhu' (from him); correction from Al-Du'afa. [2] 'And turn away': Missing from Al-Kamil and Tarikh Baghdad. [3] (Sad): 'Aqwa'. _________ = Lenient (Al-Du'afa: 5 - b). Evidence of his confusion in Al-Zuhri's hadith is Ibn Shaqla's statement in his margins (130-131; No: 153): 'Ahmad bin Hanbal weakened him; he narrated from Al-Zuhri from Aisha: 'That Aisha and Hafsah woke up fasting... so he mentioned the hadith. And Ibn Uyainah narrated it from him. Ibn Uyainah said: Then I heard it from Al-Zuhri and he did not attribute it - meaning: from Urwah.. So Salih bin Abi Al-Akhdar said to him: Rather it is from Urwah. So Al-Zuhri said to him: No; and raised his voice. Ibn Uyainah heard it from Salih bin Abi Al-Akhdar with a chain (Musnad), then heard it from Al-Zuhri correctly without a chain (Ghair Musnad)'. It occurred in Ikmal Mughlatay: From Al-Daraqutni: A Basran not considered; because his hadith from Ibn Shihab is presentation, writing, and hearing. It was said to him: Can one distinguish between them? He said: No.' 
1. Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli (J): Folio 142a; Al-Kamil: 4/25; Tarikh Baghdad: 16/550. In Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil (9/349; Bio: 1565), it was restricted to saying: 'That Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrates from Abu Bakr bin Ayyash'. 
2. Amr bin Ali said in Al-Tarikh (403): 'Abu Bakr bin Ayyash; some said: His name is Salim, and some said: He has no name [other than Kunya]'. Al-Mizzi said: 'The correct view is that his name is his Kunya'. Ibn Zanjawaih listed him among the hadith scholars of Kufa, and said in his Tabaqat (84; my verification): 'And Abu Bakr bin Ayyash; client of Banu Asad'. See critics' speech on him in Tahdhib al-Kamal: 33/129-135; No: 7252. 
3. He said in Al-Jamharah (1/563): 'Kalaha... if his lips contract from distress'. 
4. He refers to Sulaiman's [Al-A'mash] harshness on students, and his difficulty in narration. Supporting the above report is what is in Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil (1/64): 'Amr bin Ali said: I heard Abu Muawiyah say: Sufyan used to come to me here, discussing Al-A'mash's hadith with me, and I never saw anyone more knowledgeable about Al-A'mash's hadith than him'.

foot_note:

1. Al-Asami wal-Kuna by Al-Hakim: 2/426; No: 968; Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli (J): Folio 267a; Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil: 6/223; Bio: 1239; Al-Kamil: 5/121; Al-Majruhin: 2/76; to 'narrate from him'. Its editor modified the text without need. 
2. See: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 21/553-558; No: 4333; Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal: 10/137-138; No: 4067. 
3. Al-Anazi agreed with him (Tahdhib al-Kamal). 
4. Abu Al-Miqdam, Thabit bin Hurmuz Al-Haddad. 
5. You find examples of this narration scattered in Tafsir Al-Tabari, Sunan Sa'id bin Mansur, and Tafsir Ibn Abi Hatim...
