It occurred in Kitab Al-Du'afa (J: Folio 193a): 'Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used to not narrate from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad'; but what is in the original regarding Ibn Mahdi's sole refusal to narrate, and silence regarding Yahya, does not support this, nor does what is in the books of Ibn Hibban and Ibn Adi, so the correctness of Al-Uqayli's transmission should be verified, as it is in the copies of his book, perhaps the source is directly from him, and this phrase is in Al-Dhahabi in Al-Tarikh (4/677; No: 172), he quoted it from Al-Uqayli as I reckon. Ibn Shaqla said in his margins (157; No: 191): Ibn Mahdi narrated from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad, then he crossed out his hadith. 
7. He is: Abd al-Rahman bin Dhakwan. Ibn Zanjawaih counted him among the hadith scholars of Medina, and said in his Tabaqat (38): 'Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad, client of Banu Taim'. See about him: Tahdhib al-Kamal: 17/95-101; No: 3816.

He said [1]: And Sufyan and Shu'bah [2] used to narrate from him. 277 - He said (4): And I never [3] heard Yahya nor Abd al-Rahman narrate anything at all from Ya'qub bin Ata (5). 278 - He said (6): And Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used to not narrate from Muslim Al-A'war; and he is Muslim bin Kaisan [4], Abu Abdullah (7). foot_note:

This Abdullah is one of the author's sheikhs; he mentioned him in his Tarikh (412) saying: 'Abdullah bin Idris Al-Awdi was born in the year one hundred and fifteen, and died in the year ninety-two'. His father was also a trustworthy narrator as understood from Shu'bah's statement addressing Abdullah: 'Your father used to benefit me' (Su'alat Abi Dawud: 295; No: 352); and benefiting Shu'bah - considering who he is - is no small thing, for he is a critical Hafiz.

Ibn Jurayj also narrated it from Abu Al-Zubair Muhammad bin Muslim bin Tadrus, who heard Ibn Umar raising it (to the Prophet), in *Juz' fi Qira'at Al-Nabi* by Al-Duri (162; No: 118 - 119), and *Fada'il Al-Quran* by Abu Ubaid (2/ 140 - 141; No: 685) - he added in it: Hajjaj said: 'Ibn Jurayj did not hear from Mujahid other than this letter (Hadith) ... The origin of the Hadith without the addition is in *Sahih Muslim* (4/ 138; No: 3743) with a fuller context. The author's statement is witnessed by Ibn Al-Junayd's question to Yahya bin Ma'in: Did Ibn Jurayj hear from Mujahid? He said: A letter or two in recitation; he did not hear other than that. Al-Bardiji and others said likewise (*Tuhfat Al-Tahsil*: 212). The truth is that Ibn Jurayj did not hear anything from Ibn Shihab, rather he presented (Arad) to him, as Ibn Al-Madini said in *Al-Ma'rifah wa Al-Tarikh* by Al-Fasawi (2/ 139), but Al-Zuhri is of the doctrine of equating hearing and presentation as he said: 'Presentation of the book and Hadith are equal' (*Al-Kifayah*: 265); so Al-Qattan's statement is not absolute then in limiting what Ibn Jurayj heard from Al-Zuhri. This is supported by what occurred in *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir* by Ibn Abi Khaythama (Volume Three: 1/ 256; No: 882): Ali claimed: Yahya said: Sufyan bin Habib told me: That Ibn Jurayj validated this hadith from Al-Zuhri: 'That people from the Jews, fought with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him'. Yahya said: So I said to Ibn Jurayj: Did you hear this from Al-Zuhri?. He said: Or I read it'.

5. The speech is all previously attributed to Yahya bin Sa'id.

text: Al-Sabah, who is Sulaiman [1] bin Yasir (1), and he is weak, he narrated from Hammam bin Al-Harith [2] objectionable hadiths; among them: from Ibrahim (2), [and] [3] from Hammam bin Al-Harith [4], regarding reading in the bathroom) [5]. And I do not memorize anything from Sufyan from him [6].
foot_note:
1. [1] In the original: 'Nasir'; a misspelling; and it is clearly written with Damma on the Ya in the copy of *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* by Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim. [2] (Saad): 'Al-Harth'. [3] Without this estimated added Waw the speech is not straight; for the meaning is that Sulaiman narrated from Hammam coupled with Ibrahim, both from Abdullah. [4] (Saad): 'Al-Harth'. [5] It seems what is between the parentheses is inserted in Al-Fallas's speech, and it is more likely to be from the readers' comments; so verify it. If it is proven to be from his speech, it is an addition unique to the book. And it occurred in *Ilal Ibn Abi Hatim* (4/ 644; No: 1701), he said: 'I asked my father about a hadith narrated by Abu Nu'aym Abd al-Rahman bin Hani, from Sulaiman bin Yasir, from Ibrahim, from Hammam, he said: He was asked about reading in the bathroom, so Abdullah said: Why is that my son?. My father said: This hadith is objectionable (Munkar); it is only Ibrahim's speech, and I suspect the error is from Abu Nu'aym Abd al-Rahman'. [6] (Saad): 'Shay''. _________ = in the author's original, evidenced by its occurrence in Al-Maqrizi's summary as well (187; No: 264). The illusion in this is older than Ibn Adi, it occurs with Ibn Abi Hatim as well (4/ 150; No: 647): 'Sulaiman bin Yasir, Munkar Al-Hadith, weak in Hadith, narrated from Hammam bin Al-Harith objectionable hadiths'. It appears that what we said is correct, that Ibn Adi himself (3/ 271) returned and quoted Al-Fallas's saying: 'Ibn Dawud used to say: Sulaiman bin Yasir, from Hammam bin Al-Harith, and Ibrahim, from Abdullah: Disliked reading in the bathroom'.

2. He is: Al-Nakha'i, client of Sulaiman bin Yasir, and Ibrahim said: 'There is no harm in reading in the bathroom'; and there was disagreement regarding it from him; Ibn Al-Mundhir said this in *Al-Awsat*: 2/ 124 - 125; No: 661.

Imam Ahmad and Abu Musa Al-Anazi quoted it in *Al-Du'afa* by Al-Uqayli (C): Folio 341 B. Ibn Abi Khaythama quoted it in his history (Volume Three: 2/ 287; No: 2955) from his father and Yahya bin Ma'in, except that the questioner is Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan, and part of Malik's answer was: He was a liar' and once he said: 'He was not satisfactory (Radiy)'; and this report is more reliable and consistent with Al-Fallas's practice of quoting from other than his Sheikh Yahya, and if it had reached him from him it would have sufficed him. Ibn Al-Madini quoted it from Yahya (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 1/ 23), and likewise it occurred for Al-Bukhari in *Al-Du'afa* (122; No: 346) from Ibn Abi Al-Aswad; and in it is: 'He was not satisfactory'.

See for details: *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 7/ 324 - 325; No: 1751; *Tarikh Ibn Abi Khaythama*: Volume Three: 2/ 287; No: 2954 - 2958.

The same answer occurred in *Al-Kamil* (4/ 55), but the questioner is Al-Fallas, and the answerer is Yahya Al-Qattan, and the attribution of the report to Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Barri implies that it is from the book of *Al-Ilal*, but it is only found attributed to Bishr, and the answerer is Malik, which implies that what is in Ibn Adi's book has something [wrong], and Allah knows best. 
5. Bishr's questioning of Malik is in *Al-Kamil* also from the narration of Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal from his father. Perhaps the reason for that is in Ahmad's words in *Su'alat Abi Dawud* (208; No: 159): 'Malik met him - they claimed - after he grew old'. He added in *Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal* (from his son's narration: 2/ 311; No: 2382): 'And he had become confused or he is old'. Ibn Hibban said: 'His later hadith mixed with his old hadith and was not distinguished, so he deserved abandonment'. Ibn Shaqla criticized him in his margins (129; No: 149)

Yahya said: He said: Al-Ash'ath told us [3], from Al-Hasan, 'that the Messenger of Allah [4] forbade [5] praying between graves'. And he mentioned the hadith of Al-Hasan from Anas, that [Umar] [6] saw him praying facing the grave [7] and said: He narrated from Al-Hasan, that he saw [8] Uthman [9] shading [10] himself while in Ihram. Abu Hafs said: And he narrated more objectionable than this!; I heard Abd al-Samad bin Abd al-Warith [11] say: Sahl Al-Sarraj told us, from Al-Hasan, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not validate the divorce of the sick (3). And he narrated from Al-Hasan in Tafsir, good [12] hadiths.

foot_note: 1. = and we would discuss Al-A'mash's hadith with him, and he did not know a letter of it (*Du'afa Al-Uqayli*: 531/ 3; No: 3521; *Al-Kamil*: 375/ 8; No: 13346). If there was speech against him by a speaker, Abu Zur'ah would not have criticized Abdullah bin Salamah Al-Aftas for speaking against him and Yahya Al-Qattan, making that one of his criticisms against him (*Su'alat Al-Bardha'i*: 79; No: 17). Perhaps this is one of the foundations of Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi's statement in *Bayan Al-Wahm wa Al-Iham* (328/ 5): 'Trustworthy, no defect was found against him'. Al-Nasa'i said: There is no harm in him (*Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 18/ 454; No: 3585). Ibn Abd al-Barr: 'They agreed, there is no disagreement among them regarding Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad that he is a firm trustworthy narrator; Mughlatay quoted it (364/ 8; No: 3390), and said shortly after: This and its like scratches Abu Umar's saying: "They agreed", so it should be looked into'. I say: If we remove from the biography Al-Uqayli's statement in which he erred, and Al-Bazzar's statement which was misspelled from him - as will come - Ala' al-Din's critique would have no face, and Allah knows best. Al-Hakim: They both relied on him - meaning: the two Sheikhs - heavily, and he, may Allah have mercy on him, is worthy of being relied upon (*Al-Madkhal*: 182/ 4). I say: Perhaps in Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad's nature, there was something that kept him away from fame and contributed to lack of knowledge about him, for he was Yazid bin Zurai's companion with Yunus, without his name being known, so when he heard his narration from Yunus later he would deny it and label him a liar, then when he met him on some road he recognized him, Ahmad said: I heard Affan, he said: They used to mention Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad to Yazid bin Zurai' and he would say: Who is this liar who narrates from Yunus?; I do not know him. He said: Then he met him one day on some road, and it was said to him: This is Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad. He said: This was our companion with Yunus. So they said: This is Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad (*Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 1/ 355; No: 675). It is strange how the transmitters reported Al-Fallas's words about his Tadlis (obfuscation), and did not report Ibn Mahdi's words in 'accepting him'. As for what Al-Uqayli reported in the biography of Abu Bishr Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad Al-Abdi, from Uthman bin Sa'id, he said: I asked Yahya about Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad, so he said: He is nothing (*Al-Du'afa*: 531/ 3; No: 3523), it contradicts what preceded from Yahya regarding his authentication, so what is here is an error in transmission necessitated by misspelling, and illusion was possible in it, for the intended by Yahya in weakening is Abd al-Wahid bin Zaid the Basran Preacher, and this one is weak without disagreement, and in his entry in Ibn Ma'in's history, the above report occurred to Uthman bin Sa'id Al-Darimi (147; No: 506), and Ibn Shahin reported it from him correctly in *Tarikh Asma Al-Du'afa wa Al-Kadhdhabin* (132; No: 413). So it passed unnoticed by Al-Uqayli then, and Al-Dhahabi followed him in *Al-Mizan* (672/ 2; No: 5287) and *Al-Siyar* (8/ 9), and *Al-Tarikh* (4/ 686; No: 188) and *Diwan Al-Du'afa* =

I say: What prompted me to verify these places, is that the gap between Ibn Ma'in's judgment and the rest of the critics is usually not wide-ranging, but rather close, so due to the severity of the contrast I examined it, and lo, the matter involves a hidden misspelling. This report of Ibn Mahdi implies the good condition of Abd al-Wahid, and Abu Dawud's report - coming after one report - removes him from that condition by Tadlis (obfuscation), indeed Yahya denies his knowledge of Al-A'mash's hadith entirely, in his saying: 'I never saw Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad seek hadith at all, neither in Basra, nor in Kufa. text: 310 - He said (1): And I heard Abd al-Rahman [1], the day Abd al-Aziz Al-Ammi (2) died, say: No Sheikh of yours has died since (3) such and such who resembles him.
foot_note:
1. [1] Added in *Al-Siyar* and *Al-Tarikh*: 'Bin Mahdi'. And 'Yaqulu' (Say) is advanced in it after 'Abd al-Rahman'. _________ = And that is apparent from his saying: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id and the hadith of Al-A'mash, from Muslim, from Masruq, from Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah was mentioned in his presence. So Yahya said: Masruq, from Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah?! - twice or thrice - so Yahya denied it most strongly. Abdullah bin Ahmad said: I said to my father: Who corroborated him?. He said: More than one; I think among them is Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad ... (*Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal*: 122/ 3; No: 4520). Combining these stances is possible if we count a lapse of time between them, for each of them described the reality of the narrator's matter at his time, so Al-Qattan's words when discussing Al-A'mash's hadith with Abd al-Wahid are carried on his early days in narration, and Abu Dawud's words about his Tadlis are carried on when his condition improved in it and he ascended in knowledge and trustworthiness, and Ibn Mahdi's stance is carried on when he deserved to be 'among those who increase in good', so he transforms from the weak to the trustworthy, and in it is invalidation of Yahya's stance. And in the phrase above, there is a clear stipulation of the reason for the critical retraction, for he expressed it in the present tense form indicating his increase in good and persistence on it. And it is not said: that this phrase is not a text in the place of dispute; because it is a value judgment unrelated to narration; because we say: in it is an indication to the hypothetical recipient of the sender's knowledge of the judgments of critics preceding him, that's why he didn't say: 'Indeed there is good in him', nor 'there was good in him', because of what is in them of refraining from declaration, suitable for maintaining what was as it was - i.e., in weakness - so it doesn't indicate an improvement in condition, so his choice of the phrase then is intended as produced by the styles of Arabic. It remains that Ibn Mahdi's phrase about Ibn Ziyad might be carried - contrary to what passed - on righteousness and worship.

The investigator - may he be blessed - estimated that there is an omission in the text, and whatever the case; its meaning is affirming hearing for Al-A'mash from Mujahid, but Yahya's induction of what he narrated from him of hadiths, showed that four or five - in Al-Duri's narration (3/ 327; No: 1570) - are what he truly heard, as for the rest which are many, they are not so, so his saying: 'Everything he narrates ...', is a predominant judgment not absolute; and then the text appears straight with no crookedness or curvature God willing. And the rectification is from Al-Uqayli, and in *Al-Kamil* and *Tarikh Dimashq*: 'Alaihi' (Upon him); and there is a difference, the meaning in the second is that people hear from him and accept him and frequent him. And in the first, that some of them do and some do not. See for details: *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 16/ 84 - 78; No: 3543; *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 8/ 178 - 182; No: 3182. _________ = I say: Perhaps Yahya avoiding the Mursals of Yahya bin Abi Kathir, is due to their weakness, as decided by the Imam of the craft Ali bin Al-Madini when he said: 'The Mursals of Yahya bin Abi Kathir are like the wind'; Al-Muqaddami stated this in *Al-Tarikh*: 201; No: 992. See for details *Marasil Ibn Abi Hatim*: 240 - 244; No: 444; *Tuhfat Al-Tahsil*: 347 - 346; *Jami' Al-Tahsil*: 299; No: 880. 
1. *Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 6/ 180; No: 2315. 
2. See: *Al-Tarikh* by Al-Fallas: 375; *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*: 4/ 134; No: 2228 (and his Kunya 'Abu Ruh' was misspelled to 'Abi Nuh'); *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 4/ 258; No: 1117; *Kuna Muslim*: 1/ 312; No: 1100; *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 12/ 294 - 297; No: 2662. 
3. *Al-Du'afa* (C): Folio 178 A; *Al-Kamil*: 4/ 128; *Tarikh Dimashq*: 32/ 261; *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 5/ 154; No: 706; to 'Aqil'. And what is in *Al-Majruhin* (2/ 3) contradicts what is in the original; for in it is: 'Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used not to narrate from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil'.

book_title: A Book Containing Defects of Hadith and Knowledge of Trustworthy Jurists from the Weak Ones, Upon Which the Scholars of Basra Agreed
publisher: Ihsan Center for Sunnah Studies, Jeddah - Saudi Arabia
text: 315 - Abu Hafs said: And [Abd al-Rahman narrated to me from] [2] Abdullah bin Dawud [1], from Sufyan, from Mansur, from Ibrahim, from Shurayh, he said: 'The Qarin performs Tawaf twice, and Sa'i [3] twice'; he said: This is only the hadith of Ziyad bin [4] Labid, from Shurayh, he said: 'If you combine Hajj and Umrah, then nothing prohibited shall become lawful for you (until) [5] the Day of Sacrifice (Nahr)' (1). And the Exampler of those who have insight into Hadith said: Ask Yahya bin Sa'id; so I asked him, and he said as Ibn [6] Mahdi said. 316 - And I saw (2) Yahya and heard him say to a man from Banu Dabbah, called: Abu Rashid - he holds the view of Qadar, a man from the Arabs -: I saw you with Mahdi bin Hilal; do not come to him [7] for he is a liar (3).
foot_note:
1. [1] (Saad): 'Hadith'. [2] Inserted rectification in the margin. [3] (Saad): 'Wa yas'a'. [4] (Saad): 'Ibn'. [5] Perforation in the original the size of two words rectified from *Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah*. [6] (Saad): 'Bin'. [7] (Saad): 'Ta'tihi'. _________ 
1. Al-Khuraybi, Sheikh of Al-Fallas, was followed regarding Mansur by Abd al-Razzaq in *Akhbar Al-Qudah* by Waki' (280/ 2), and Jarir bin Abd al-Hamid Al-Kufi, from the trustworthy Sheikhs of Ibn Abi Shaybah in *Al-Musannaf* (627/ 8; No: 15358), and the wording is his - and his context is fuller than the first - he said: 'Jarir told us, from Mansur, from Ibrahim, from Ziyad bin Labid, he said: Shurayh said: "If you assume Ihram for Umrah and Hajj, then arrive at Mecca, nothing prohibited shall become lawful for you until the Day of Sacrifice; for they will say to you: If you perform Tawaf for your Umrah and your Hajj then exit Ihram, so do not obey them in that". 
2. Ibn Hibban abbreviated (30/ 3) half of the author's speech saying: I saw Yahya bin Sa'id saying to a man: I saw you....'. And the report occurred with Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim in *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* (The Manuscript Section: Folio 266 A) and Ibn Adi in *Al-Kamil* (467/ 6) with this wording: 'I heard Yahya bin Sa'id say to a man from Banu Dabbah called: Abu Rashid: I saw you yesterday in the Friday [prayer], with Mahdi bin Hilal. He said: Yes; I hear from him. He said: Do not write from him; for he is a liar'. 
3. Yahya bin Sa'id: Not trustworthy (*Al-Du'afa* by Al-Bukhari: 129; No: 379). Abu Dawud (391/ 1; No: 748) Liar. And Ibn Shaqla said in his quotes from Al-Saji (265; No: 359): =

text: 317 - He said (1): And I never heard from Yahya nor Abd al-Rahman, a hadith [1] from Yunus bin Khabbab (2), anything at all. 318 - He said (3): And I heard Mu'adh bin Mu'adh say: I said to Al-Ash'ath: O Abu [2] Hani', what prevented you from asking [3] Ata, when you had many questions with you?. He said: I have not seen anyone after Al-Hasan, except that he appeared small in my eyes. 319 - He said: And I heard Mu'adh bin Mu'adh, and Amr Al-Anmati (4) said to him: O Abu [4] Al-Muthanna, kill Ibn [5] Abi Adi (5) four times; for he is a Jahmi. He said: Be silent, I have known him for forty years for virtue, goodness, and Sunnah, stand up ...!.
foot_note:
1. [1] *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna*: 'Haddatha'. [2] (Saad): 'Yaba'. [3] (Saad): 'Tasal'. [4] (Saad): 'Yaba'. [5] (Saad): 'Bin'. _________ = Mahdi bin Hilal client of Al-Azd, was a Qadari among the callers. And Yahya bin Ma'in said: Mahdi bin Hilal was a liar. 
1. *Al-Asami wa Al-Kuna* by Al-Hakim: 3/ 110; No: 1149; *Al-Du'afa* by Al-Uqayli (C): Folio 411 A; and in it: 'I did not hear Yahya ...'; without 'from'; *Al-Majruhin*: 3/ 140. 
2. Abu Dawud (1/ 222; No: 247): Yunus bin Khabbab, had an evil opinion. He added in the hadith of the grave - hadith of Zadan: And Ali is my Wali. (1/ 224; No: 254): A curser of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. And one who heard Ali told me saying: I do not narrate from him until I pillow my right hand. Abu Dawud said I have seen Shu'bah's hadiths from him are straight and the Rafidah are not like that. See: *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 9/ 238; No: 1001; *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 32/ 503 - 506; No: 7174 
3. Al-Mizzi suspended it from Mu'adh, with slight difference in wording in *Tahdhib Al-Kamal*: 6/ 108. It did not appear in this context except in our book. 
4. This is among those whom Al-Fallas benefited from and heard from, and he reports from him; so perhaps he is one of his companions in seeking knowledge. See: *Al-Kamil*: 4/ 156; No: 5735; *Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil*: 317; *Al-Jami' li-Akhlaq Al-Rawi*: 2/ 169; No: 1510. He narrated from Hammad Al-Maliki (*Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*: 3/ 153; No: 665). 
5. Preceded.

text: The Book is completed [1] by the praise of Allah and His aid, and may Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and his family, and send much peace. 320 - And Abu Asim told us, he said: Juwairiyah [2] bin Asma' told us, he said: Ash'ab Al-Tamma' [3] told us, he said: Salim bin Abdullah said: 'Beware of begging [4], for a man does not cease to beg [5] until he meets [6] Allah on the Day of Resurrection, and there is not a shred of flesh on his face.' The Book is completed [7] with Abu Muhammad [8]. This book was copied, for the Great High Judge Abu Zakariya Yahya bin Muhammad, may Allah revive his mention, and fulfill his hope, and perpetuate his happiness, and immortalize his days. [And the completion of it was] on the first [9] of the beginning of seventy-four and seven hundred (774 AH), may Allah make us know its good, and suffice us its evil (1).
foot_note:
1. [1] (Saad): 'Thumma'. [2] In the original: 'Hawbar'; a misspelling. And this is among those whom Abu Asim narrated from. [3] (Saad): 'Ash'ath Al-Tama''. [4] (Saad): 'Wal-Mas'alah'. [5] (Saad): 'Yasal'. [6] (Saad): 'Yalqa'. [7] (Saad): 'Thumma'. [8] It occurred in the original, confusing between being as we established or being 'Abu Umar'; and the most likely is that the copyist transferred the comments found on his copy, and its owner compared between the narration of Abu Muhammad Qasim bin Asbagh and others. [9] Inserted in the margin. _________
